Hyperlinked Riftbound Core Rules

These rules are effective as of December 1st, 2025
The rules were parsed from the official rules at riftbound.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/news/rules-and-releases/gameplay-guide-core-rules/
Check out their FAQs posted at riftbound.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/news/rules-and-releases/riftbound-origins-faq/
Also take a look at their Tournament Rules at riftbound.leagueoflegends.com/en-us/news/organizedplay/riftbound-tournament-rules/

Rules

000.
Golden and Silver Rules ğŸ“
001.
Golden Rule ğŸ“
002.
Card text supersedes rules text. Whenever a card fundamentally contradicts the rules, the card's indication is what is true. ğŸ“
050.
Silver Rule ğŸ“
051.
Card text uses different terminology than rules. Card text should be interpreted according to these rules, not as though it were text within these rules. ğŸ“
052.
Card, when written in card effects, is shorthand for "Main Deck card." Runes, legends, and battleï¬elds are not considered cards when executing the abilities and effects of game objects. They are considered cards for the purposes of these rules. ğŸ“
053.
Cards refer to themselves in the ï¬rst person. ğŸ“
053.1.
* Units and legends say "I," "me," etc. ğŸ“
053.2.
* Gear and spells say "this." ğŸ“
053.3.
* Battleï¬elds say "here." ğŸ“
054.
â€œCanâ€™t beats Canâ€ ğŸ“
054.1.
Cards that forbid actions or effects, as a broad method of determination, supersede cards that allow or permit that same action or effect. ğŸ“
055.
When executing card text, do as much as you can, ignoring impossible instructions. ğŸ“
055.1.
If all of a cardâ€™s instructions are impossible, it is still played and resolved, but nothing happens. ğŸ“
100.
Game Concepts ğŸ“
101.
Deck Construction ğŸ“
102.
Riftbound is a Trading Card Game where a player must provide their own cards to play against other players. ğŸ“
103.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battleï¬elds determined by the Mode of Play. ğŸ“
103.1.
1 Champion Legend ğŸ“
103.1.a.
This is placed in the Legend Zone at the start of the game. ğŸ“
103.1.b.
This will dictate the Domain Identity of the Main Deck. ğŸ“
103.1.b.1.
Cards included in your Deck must abide by your Domain Identity. ğŸ“
103.1.b.2.
Your deckâ€™s Domain Identity is dictated by the domains of your Champion Legend. In the default card frame, these domains appear as symbols in the legendâ€™s upper left corner. ğŸ“
103.1.b.3.
If a card has a single Domain, then that card is permitted in the Domain Identity that corresponds to the same Domain. ğŸ“
103.1.b.4.
If a card has more than one Domain, then that card is permitted only in a Domain Identity that contains all of the indicated Domains on that card. ğŸ“
103.2.
A Main Deck of at least 40 cards 1 Chosen Champion Unit Units Gear Spells ğŸ“
103.2.a.
Chosen Champion ğŸ“
103.2.a.1.
This will be placed in the Champion Zone at the start of the game. ğŸ“
103.2.a.2.
Must be a champion unit with a champion tag that matches the tag on your Champion Legend. Example: Loose Cannon has the tag Jinx. Therefore, a player could choose Jinx, Rebel or Jinx, Demolitionist as their Chosen Champion, because they also have the tag Jinx. Example: Tibbers has the tag Annie, but it is a signature unit, not a champion unit. It cannot be your Chosen Champion, even if your Champion Legend has the tag Annie. ğŸ“
103.2.a.3.
A playerâ€™s Chosen Champion is both the speciï¬c card chosen for this slot during Deck Building and also any Champion Unit with the same name as the speciï¬c card selected for this speciï¬c slot during the course of play. Example: A player chose Jinx, Rebel as their Chosen Champion. One copy of Jinx, Rebel starts the game in their Chosen Champion zone. Any additional copies of Jinx, Rebel in their Main Deck, their hand, their trash, or on the board also count as their Chosen Champion for any game rules and effects that care about Chosen Champion status during the game. ğŸ“
103.2.b.
Your Main Deck can include up to 3 copies of the same named card. ğŸ“
103.2.b.1.
This includes your Chosen Champion. Example: A deck could include Volibear, Furious as its Chosen Champion and still include 2 more copies of Volibear, Furious. ğŸ“
103.2.b.2.
Cards have different names even if they represent the same character. Example: A deck could include 3 copies of Yasuo, Remorseful and 3 copies of Yasuo, Windrider, because they have different names. ğŸ“
103.2.c.
Subject to Domain Identity. ğŸ“
103.2.d.
Your deck may only contain 3 total Signature cards that have the same Champion tag as your Champion Legend. ğŸ“
103.2.d.1.
Regardless of name, a deck may only contain a sum total of 3 Signature cards. ğŸ“
103.2.d.2.
All of the Signature cards must have the Champion tag that corresponds to the Champion Legend of the deck. ğŸ“
103.2.d.3.
Signature cards are not Champion units and cannot be placed in the Champion Zone. ğŸ“
103.2.e.
During Gameplay, the Main Deck is Secret Information. ğŸ“
103.2.e.1.
It cannot be looked through or revealed unless instructed by a card effect. ğŸ“
103.3.
Rune Deck ğŸ“
103.3.a.
12 Rune Cards ğŸ“
103.3.a.1.
Cards in this deck must be of the Domain Identity of your Champion Legend. ğŸ“
103.3.b.
Must be shufï¬‚ed and kept separate from the Main Deck. ğŸ“
103.4.
Battleï¬elds ğŸ“
103.4.a.
The number will be dictated by your Mode of Play. ğŸ“
103.4.b.
Subject to Domain Identity if applicable. ğŸ“
103.4.c.
Cannot include more than one of a Battleï¬eld of the same name when there are more than one required for the deck. ğŸ“
104.
Setup ğŸ“
105.
Spaces ğŸ“
106.
The Play Area includes a space for Game Objects referred to as The Board. ğŸ“
106.1.
The Board is divided into several Zones. ğŸ“
106.2.
The Base ğŸ“
106.2.a.
One per player. ğŸ“
106.2.b.
The space each player always has access to play their Units and Gear to. ğŸ“
106.2.c.
Each Base is a Location. ğŸ“
106.2.d.
Other players cannot have Game Objects they control in another player's Base. ğŸ“
106.2.e.
The Base also houses each player's Runes that are on The Board. ğŸ“
106.3.
The Battleï¬eld Zone ğŸ“
106.3.a.
Multiple Battleï¬elds will be here, typically one per player, but occasionally less. ğŸ“
106.3.b.
The space where Battleï¬elds are located during gameplay. ğŸ“
106.3.c.
Each Battleï¬eld is individually a Location. ğŸ“
106.4.
The Facedown Zones ğŸ“
106.4.a.
Each Battleï¬eld is associated with a sub-zone called a Facedown Zone, a single logical space that a card can be put facedown in through various Game Effects. ğŸ“
106.4.b.
Each Facedown Zone has a maximum occupancy of one card. ğŸ“
106.4.c.
Cards can only be placed in or occupy the Facedown Zone if the controller of the card also controls the associated Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information. ğŸ“
106.4.e.
Facedown Zones are not locations. ğŸ“
106.5.
The Legend Zone ğŸ“
106.5.a.
The space for each player's Champion Legend. ğŸ“
106.5.b.
This is not a location. ğŸ“
106.5.c.
The Champion Legend here is a Game Object. See rule 119. Game Objects for more information. ğŸ“
106.5.d.
The Champion Legend cannot be removed, moved, or displaced from this zone. ğŸ“
107.
The Play Area also includes Non-Board Zones. ğŸ“
107.1.
The Trash ğŸ“
107.1.a.
This space is where cards are placed when they are killed or discarded, when they ï¬nish being executed as spells, when they are moved to the trash as an effect, etc. ğŸ“
107.1.b.
Represents cards that have been used or spent. ğŸ“
107.1.c.
Each player has a separate trash. ğŸ“
107.1.d.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into a trash of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's trash instead. ğŸ“
107.1.e.
The cards in the Trash are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized. ğŸ“
107.1.f.
The cards in any player's Trash are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information. ğŸ“
107.2.
The Champion Zone ğŸ“
107.2.a.
The space each player puts their Chosen Champion at the start of the game. ğŸ“
107.2.b.
The Chosen Champion here cannot be returned to this zone by normal means. ğŸ“
107.2.b.1.
If a Chosen Champion is instructed to be returned to this zone, it can only do so if there is not a card already in this zone. ğŸ“
107.2.c.
The Chosen Champion can be played from here as normal, following the rules of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
107.3.
The Main Deck Zone ğŸ“
107.3.a.
The space for the player's Main Deck. ğŸ“
107.3.b.
Primarily houses the face-down deck during gameplay. ğŸ“
107.3.c.
The order of cards in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information. ğŸ“
107.4.
The Rune Deck Zone ğŸ“
107.4.a.
The space for the player's Rune Deck. ğŸ“
107.4.b.
Primarily houses the face-down runes during gameplay. ğŸ“
107.4.c.
The order of runes in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information. ğŸ“
107.5.
Banishment ğŸ“
107.5.a.
This space is where cards are placed when they are banished by a spell or effect. ğŸ“
107.5.b.
Represents cards that have been removed from play in a more difï¬cult-to-recover way, or a temporary space to hold cards while effects are being processed. ğŸ“
107.5.c.
Each player has a separate banishment. ğŸ“
107.5.d.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into the banishment of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's banishment instead. ğŸ“
107.5.e.
The cards in the banishment are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized. ğŸ“
107.5.f.
The cards in any player's Banishment are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information. ğŸ“
107.5.g.
Some spells or effects may reference cards placed into banishment directly. ğŸ“
107.5.h.
Effects that reference cards in banishment only do so by means of also putting the cards there. ğŸ“
107.5.i.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Choosing. ğŸ“
107.5.j.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Attachment. ğŸ“
107.6.
The Hand ğŸ“
107.6.a.
Each player has a collection of cards they may Play cards from. ğŸ“
107.6.b.
This is the location cards go when Drawn. ğŸ“
107.6.c.
The cards in a player's hand are Private Information. ğŸ“
107.6.d.
The number of cards in a player's hand is Public Information. ğŸ“
107.6.e.
The hand can be targeted as a zone, and cards there can be affected by spells and effects when speciï¬ed. ğŸ“
107.6.f.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into the hand of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's hand instead. ğŸ“
108.
All Game Objects in the collective Play Areas are Public Information. ğŸ“
108.1.
Any player may view, or be provided with the details of the face-up information printed on the cards in the Play Area. ğŸ“
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc. ğŸ“
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted. ğŸ“
110.
Setup Process ğŸ“
111.
Each player separates their Champion Legend and places it in the Legend Zone. ğŸ“
112.
Each player separates their Chosen Champion and places it in the Champion Zone. ğŸ“
113.
Each player sets aside their Battleï¬elds. ğŸ“
113.1.
Your Mode of Play will dictate how these are used and placed into the Battleï¬eld Zone. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information. ğŸ“
114.
Each player shufï¬‚es their decks, separately, then places them into their respective Zones. ğŸ“
114.1.
The Main Deck is placed in the Main Deck Zone. ğŸ“
114.2.
The Rune Deck is placed in the Rune Deck Zone. ğŸ“
115.
Determine Turn Order using any fair random method agreed on by all players. ğŸ“
115.1.
Turn Order is established as a repeating set of the players. ğŸ“
115.1.a.
The Mode of Play will specify how to determine a First Player. ğŸ“
115.1.b.
If not otherwise speciï¬ed, Seating then determines the sequence, play proceeding clockwise from the First Player. ğŸ“
115.1.b.1.
The First Player is the player who becomes the Turn Player ï¬rst. ğŸ“
115.1.c.
Turn Order repeats until the game ends. ğŸ“
115.2.
See the selected Mode of Play for any adjustments to each player's ï¬rst turn. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information. ğŸ“
116.
Players each draw 4. ğŸ“
117.
In turn order, players perform their Mulligan. ğŸ“
117.1.
A player may choose up to two cards in their hand. They set those cards aside. ğŸ“
117.2.
Then, that player draws as many cards as they set aside. ğŸ“
117.3.
Finally, that player Recycles the cards that were set aside. See rule 403. Recycle for more information. ğŸ“
118.
Begin play with the First Player taking their turn. ğŸ“
119.
Game Objects ğŸ“
120.
A Game Object is any game piece that can produce one or more Game Effects or grant prerequisites for players to take Game Actions. ğŸ“
121.
A Game Object does not include nor preclude any inherent properties beyond the ability to produce, or act as the prerequisite for, Game Effects and Game Actions. ğŸ“
122.
A Game Object can be a literal object or a logical object. ğŸ“
123.
Game Objects include, but are not limited to, the following: Main Deck cards in any zone Runes in any zone Legends Battleï¬elds Tokens Abilities of any type on the chain Buffs and other status markers ğŸ“
124.
Cards ğŸ“
125.
Riftbound games are composed of players playing the cards in their respective decks. ğŸ“
126.
Ownership ğŸ“
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice. ğŸ“
127.
Privacy ğŸ“
127.1.
A card will always exist in one of the many Zones described during Setup. ğŸ“
127.2.
A card will have a different level of Privacy based on where it resides at a given time ğŸ“
127.3.
Secret: This level of Privacy indicates that neither player may read or look at the face of the card. ğŸ“
127.4.
Private: This level of Privacy indicates that only the controller of a card on the board or the owner of a card in any other zone may read or look at the face of the card. Example: Cards in a player's hand are owned by that player. Only that player may read or look at their faces. Example: If a player controls a facedown card at a battleï¬eld, that player and only that player may read or look at that card's face, regardless of who owns that card. ğŸ“
127.5.
Public: This level of Privacy indicates that any player may read or look at the face of the card. ğŸ“
128.
Back Side ğŸ“
128.1.
The back side of a card is the side with the Riftbound logo. ğŸ“
128.2.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battleï¬elds and Champion Legends. ğŸ“
128.3.
The back side of a card is presented to conceal information for Private and Secret information cards. For example, cards in the Main Deck and cards in hand have their back side presented. ğŸ“
128.4.
The term facedown is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's back side presented on the Board. A facedown cardâ€™s front side is considered Private Information. ğŸ“
129.
Front Side ğŸ“
129.1.
The front side of a card is the opposite of its back. ğŸ“
129.2.
This is also referred to as a front face. ğŸ“
129.3.
This can be identiï¬ed in situations where the back is not easily discernible by the presence of the Play Cost in the upper left corner of the card. ğŸ“
129.4.
Cards, when played, are played with their front face presented. ğŸ“
129.5.
The term face up is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's front face presented ğŸ“
129.6.
Cards are considered to be Public Information while in this state, even if obscured by other cards in a pile. Example: The Trash is Public Information because all cards there have their front face presented even while stacked. ğŸ“
130.
Cost ğŸ“
130.1.
Main Deck cards have a Cost, listed in the upper left corner of the front face of the card. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information. ğŸ“
130.2.
Energy Cost ğŸ“
130.2.a.
The numeral listed in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card. ğŸ“
130.3.
Power cost ğŸ“
130.3.a.
The symbols, listed vertically, in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card. ğŸ“
130.3.b.
This section may not be present on every card. ğŸ“
130.4
Effects that need to determine a cardâ€™s cost for any purpose always use its base cost, even if that cost is altered or ignored as the card is played. Example: Sky Splitter is a spell that costs 8 Energy and says in part â€œThis spell's Energy cost is reduced by the highest Might among units you control.â€ Lux, Illuminated is a unit that says â€œWhen you play a spell that costs 5 or more, give me +3 [M] this turn.â€ If a player who controls Lux plays Sky Splitter, Luxâ€™s ability will trigger, regardless of how much was actually paid for Sky Splitter. ğŸ“
131.
Name ğŸ“
131.1.
Each card has a name that identiï¬es it uniquely. ğŸ“
131.2.
This is usually located in the middle of the card. ğŸ“
131.3.
Cards that are printed in different languages but represent the same card are considered to have the same name for the purposes of deckbuilding and gameplay. Example: Chemtech Enforcer in English and its counterpart in Chinese are considered the same card, despite the Name element on the card reading differently. ğŸ“
131.4
Some cards have both a short name and a subtitle. For all purposes, including rules and deckbuilding, such a cardâ€™s name is â€œ[Short Name], [Subtitle]â€. Example: Kaiâ€™Sa, Evolutionary and Kaiâ€™Sa, Survivor both have the short name Kaiâ€™Sa, but they have different names. You can include 3 of each in your deck under normal deckbuilding rules. If one of them is your Chosen Champion, the other is not. ğŸ“
132.
Category ğŸ“
132.1.
A card can have one or more Categories and Sub-Categories based on the properties of its front and back sides. ğŸ“
132.2.
These Categories and Sub-Categories dictate the behaviors of the card during play. ğŸ“
132.3.
Spells and other effects can refer to categories, sub-categories, supertypes, card types, tags, and other characteristics inclusively or exclusively. Example: A "non-unit card" is any card that is not a unit. Example: A "unit" is any game object that is a unit, regardless of any other categories it belongs to. ğŸ“
132.4.
Main Deck Cards begin the game in the Main Deck or (in the case of a Chosen Champion) the Champion Zone. ğŸ“
132.4.a.
Permanents ğŸ“
132.4.a.1.
An umbrella sub-category encompassing Main Deck Game Objects that remain on the board after being played. ğŸ“
132.4.a.2.
Unit and Gear are permanent types. ğŸ“
132.4.b.
Spells ğŸ“
132.4.b.1.
A sub-category encompassing Main Deck cards with the spell type, which do not remain on the board after being played. ğŸ“
132.5.
Rune Deck Cards begin the game in the Rune Deck. ğŸ“
132.5.a.
Runes ğŸ“
132.5.a.1.
A sub-category encompassing cards with the rune type. These are channeled rather than played. They remain on the board after being channeled, but they are not permanents, as they are not Main Deck cards. ğŸ“
132.6.
Non-Deck Cards are not part of any deck and begin the game in a zone determined by their type. ğŸ“
132.6.a.
Battleï¬elds ğŸ“
132.6.a.1.
A sub-category encompassing cards with the battleï¬eld type. They are not played or channeled. They start the game on the board. ğŸ“
132.6.b.
Legends ğŸ“
132.6.b.1.
A sub-category encompassing cards with the legend type. They are not played or channeled. They start the game in the Legend Zone and cannot leave it during play. ğŸ“
132.7.
Supertypes are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed before a cardâ€™s type. ğŸ“
132.7.a.
Champion is a supertype that applies exclusively to units. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding. See rule 103.2.a. Chosen Champion for more information. ğŸ“
132.7.b.
Signature is a supertype that may apply to game objects of any card type. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding. See rule 103.2.d.for more information about Signature cards. ğŸ“
132.7.c.
Token is a supertype applied to temporary game objects of any card type. See rule 173. Tokens for more information. ğŸ“
132.8.
Tags are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed after a cardâ€™s type. ğŸ“
132.8.a.
Tags have no innate rules meaning, but may be referenced by game rules and card effects. ğŸ“
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags. ğŸ“
133.
Domain ğŸ“
133.1.
Most cards belong to one or more of six Domains, identiï¬ed by one or more symbols in the lower right corner. ğŸ“
133.2.
Each Domain has an associated color, a unique symbol, and a shorthand used to represent that symbol in written text. ğŸ“
133.2.a.
Fury is associated with the color red and represented by a circular symbol with three projecting points. Its shorthand is [R]. ğŸ“
133.2.b.
Calm is associated with the color green and represented by a symbol resembling a leaf. Its shorthand is [G]. ğŸ“
133.2.c.
Mind is associated with the color blue and represented by a symbol resembling a sun and moon. Its shorthand is [B]. ğŸ“
133.2.d.
Body is associated with the color orange and represented by a blocky diamond-shaped symbol. Its shorthand is [O]. ğŸ“
133.2.e.
Chaos is associated with the color purple and represented by a hexagonal symbol with swirls emanating from its center. Its shorthand is [P]. ğŸ“
133.2.f.
Order is associated with the color yellow and represented by an angular winged symbol. Its shorthand is [Y]. ğŸ“
134.
Rules Text ğŸ“
134.1.
All cards have a section that describes how they affect the game. This section is known as the Rules Text of the card. ğŸ“
134.2.
This section may contain: ğŸ“
134.2.a.
Abilities ğŸ“
134.2.a.1.
Abilities are discrete pieces of text that describe what a card may or must do. See rule 357. Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
134.2.a.2.
They may appear on any card. ğŸ“
134.2.b.
Instructions ğŸ“
134.2.b.1.
Instructions are a type of text that appears on spells and within abilities. ğŸ“
134.2.b.2.
They describe the actions to be taken as the spell or ability resolves. ğŸ“
134.2.c.
Keywords ğŸ“
134.2.c.1.
Keywords are short words or phrases that represent longer abilities or instructions. See rule 726. Keywords for more information. ğŸ“
134.2.c.2.
Keywords may or may not have reminder text. ğŸ“
134.2.d.
Reminder Text ğŸ“
134.2.d.1.
Reminder text appears in italics and parentheses. ğŸ“
134.2.d.2.
Its purpose is to summarize relevant rules, including keywords and other rules. ğŸ“
134.2.d.3.
The presence, absence, or exact wording of reminder text has no effect on game function. ğŸ“
134.2.e.
Symbols ğŸ“
134.2.e.1.
Rules text sometimes contains symbols that express game concepts. Each symbol also has a shorthand used to represent it in written text. ğŸ“
134.2.e.2.
The cost of Exhausting a Permanent is represented by the â€œexhaust symbol,â€ which resembles a card turning sideways. Its shorthand is [E]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [T].) ğŸ“
134.2.e.3.
Might is represented by the â€œMight symbol,â€ which resembles a sword and shield. Its shorthand is [M]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [S].) ğŸ“
134.2.e.4.
Power of a speciï¬c Domain is represented by its domain symbol and the corresponding shorthand. See rule 133. Domain for more information. ğŸ“
134.2.e.5.
Power of any Domain is represented by a swirling rainbow symbol. Its shorthand is [A]. ğŸ“
134.2.e.5.a.
When required as a cost, [A] can be paid by Power of any Domain. ğŸ“
134.2.e.5.b.
When Added to a playerâ€™s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain. ğŸ“
134.2.e.6.
Power of a domain corresponding to a cardâ€™s own Domain is not represented by a symbol, but appears in these rules similarly to other symbols. Its shorthand is [C]. ğŸ“
134.2.e.6.a.
When a [C] shorthand is printed on a card as reminder text, it assumes that cardâ€™s usual Domain, but it still means â€œone Power of this cardâ€™s Domain.â€ ğŸ“
134.2.e.6.b.
A [C] shorthand on a card with no Domain or with multiple Domains is processed as [A] instead. ğŸ“
134.3.
Rules text can be blank. ğŸ“
134.4.
A cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information. ğŸ“
134.4.a.
The presence of text, rules, Keywords, and other effects can still be referenced and detected by other game effects, even while Rules Text is Inactive. ğŸ“
135.
Effect Text ğŸ“
135.1
Some cards have a separate section of text below the Rules Text. This is referred to as the Effect Text. ğŸ“
135.2
Effect Text can contain additional Abilities. ğŸ“
135.2.a
Effect Text can be blank. ğŸ“
135.2.b
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information. ğŸ“
135.2.c
The abilities in the Effect Text section of a card are appended to the Rules Text of the card to which the card with the Effect Text is Attached. ğŸ“
136.
Might Bonus ğŸ“
136.1
Some cards have a Might Bonus in their lower right corner, expressed as an operator plus an integer. ğŸ“
136.2
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus can be +0. ğŸ“
136.3
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
136.3.a
The Might Bonus is applied while Attached and stops applying as soon as the card with the Might Bonus is no longer Attached. ğŸ“
136.3.b
If the card to which a card with a Might Bonus is Attached has no Might value, the Might Bonus is ignored. ğŸ“
137.
Flavor Text ğŸ“
137.1.
Flavor text is text that appears at the bottom of some cards to provide aesthetic enjoyment. It conveys no gameplay information. Example: The card Void Seeker features a quote from the character Kai'Sa. It does not have the Kai'Sa tag and has no gameplay connection to the Champion unit Kai'Sa. ğŸ“
137.2.
Flavor text is located at the bottom of the section provided for rules text, usually in a shaded bar. It appears in italics. ğŸ“
138.
Illustration ğŸ“
138.1.
Each card has an illustration. It conveys no gameplay information. ğŸ“
139.
Units ğŸ“
140.
Unit is: ğŸ“
140.1.
A Game Object ğŸ“
140.1.a.
While on the Board: ğŸ“
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base. ğŸ“
140.1.a.2.
Units and their details are Public Information while on the Board. ğŸ“
140.1.a.3.
Units can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, affects, or game actions that specify Units. ğŸ“
140.1.a.4.
Units can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information. ğŸ“
140.1.b.
While in the Trash: ğŸ“
140.1.b.1.
Units are treated as Cards, similar to when in the Hand. ğŸ“
140.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being a Unit, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that target Units on the Board. ğŸ“
140.1.b.3.
Units can be affected by spells and game effects that target Units in the Trash. ğŸ“
140.2.
A Card Type ğŸ“
140.2.a.
This is a unique identiï¬er that some spells or abilities will use to restrict what they can choose or affect. ğŸ“
140.2.b.
The card type is relevant in all zones. ğŸ“
141.
Damage is a marked value that is applied to Units. ğŸ“
141.1.
Damage is not a Game Object. ğŸ“
141.2.
Damage is a value tracked per-Unit. ğŸ“
141.3.
Damage tracks how close a Unit is to being Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information. ğŸ“
141.4.
Damage can be Healed. See rule 405. Heal for more information. ğŸ“
142.
Units have multiple Intrinsic Properties unique to them: ğŸ“
142.1.
Tag: A Unit has zero or more Tags representing one or more champions, regions, factions, or species it belongs to. ğŸ“
142.1.a.
These have no intrinsic rules or behaviors by themselves. ğŸ“
142.1.b.
Spells, abilities, and game actions can reference these types as part of their execution. ğŸ“
142.2.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects. ğŸ“
142.2.a.
If a Unit ever has nonzero damage marked on it equalling or exceeding its Might, it is Killed. ğŸ“
142.2.b.
If a unit's Might is ever less than 0, it is treated as 0 for all purposes. ğŸ“
142.3.
Units can have damage marked on them. ğŸ“
142.3.a.
When spells, abilities, or other game effects deal damage, Units mark that damage on them temporarily. This can be tracked with coins, dice, or other markers, or by memory. ğŸ“
142.3.b.
Damage is Healed from Units at two speciï¬c times: ğŸ“
142.3.b.1.
At the end of each player's turn. ğŸ“
142.3.b.2.
During a Combat Cleanup. See rule 444.1.for more information about Combat Cleanups. ğŸ“
142.4.
Units enter the Board exhausted. ğŸ“
142.4.a.
This can be altered by Accelerate or similar game effects. See rule 731. Accelerate for more information. ğŸ“
143.
Units have the Inherent Ability to perform a Standard Move. ğŸ“
143.1.
This action is limited in when it can be performed. ğŸ“
143.1.a.
This action can be done any time during a player's Action Phase. ğŸ“
143.1.b.
This action cannot be performed during a Closed State. ğŸ“
143.1.c.
This action cannot be performed during a Showdown. ğŸ“
143.2.
Exhausting the Unit is the Cost for this action. ğŸ“
143.3.
Players may perform multiple Units' standard move simultaneously. ğŸ“
143.3.a.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the units' Destination must be the same. ğŸ“
143.3.b.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the Origins do not need to be the same. ğŸ“
143.3.c.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously. ğŸ“
143.4.
The Destinations where Units can Move to with their Standard Move are restricted: ğŸ“
143.4.a.
Units may move from their Base to a Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
143.4.a.1.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present. ğŸ“
143.4.b.
Units may move from a Battleï¬eld to their Base. ğŸ“
143.4.c.
Ganking is a unique ability that affects a Unit's Standard MoveğŸ“
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information. ğŸ“
144.
Units may have Activated Abilities. ğŸ“
144.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown. ğŸ“
144.2.a.
This follows the same process as playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
144.2.a.1.
This behaves, once activated, like a spell without an associated card. ğŸ“
145.
Gear ğŸ“
146.
Gear are: ğŸ“
146.1.
A Game Object ğŸ“
146.1.a.
While on the Board. ğŸ“
146.1.a.1.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base. ğŸ“
146.1.a.2.
Gear and their details are Public Information while on the Board. ğŸ“
146.1.a.3.
Gear can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, effects, or game actions that specify Gear. ğŸ“
146.1.a.4.
Gear can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information. ğŸ“
146.1.b.
While in the Trash ğŸ“
146.1.b.1.
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand. ğŸ“
146.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being Gear, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that affect Gear on the Board. ğŸ“
146.1.b.3.
Gear can be affected by spells and game effects that affect Gear in the Trash. ğŸ“
146.2.
A Card Type ğŸ“
146.2.a.
This is a unique identiï¬er that some spells or abilities will use to restrict what they can choose or affect. ğŸ“
146.2.b.
The card type is relevant in all zones. ğŸ“
147.
Gear have several Intrinsic Properties unique to them. ğŸ“
147.1.
Gear enters play Ready. ğŸ“
147.2.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base. ğŸ“
147.3.
If a Gear is at a Battleï¬eld for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action. See rule 432. Recalls for more information. ğŸ“
148.
Gear may have Activated Abilities. ğŸ“
148.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown. ğŸ“
148.2.a.
This follows the same process as playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
148.2.a.1.
This behaves, once activated, like a spell without an associated card. ğŸ“
149.
Spells ğŸ“
150.
Spell is a card type. ğŸ“
151.
A spell can be played during an Open State Outside of Showdowns on its controller's turn. ğŸ“
152.
A spell is controlled by the player who played it. ğŸ“
153.
A spell creates a game effect according to its instructions and is then placed in the Trash of the player who owns it. ğŸ“
154.
When a spell is successfully played, a player executes the rules text of the spell. This is called Resolving the spell. ğŸ“
154.1.
Spells have their rules text executed from top to bottom when they are Resolved. ğŸ“
154.2.
If a later part of a spell applies a Replacement Effect that alters earlier parts of the spell, apply those replacement effects as appropriate. Example: A spell says "Choose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn." and "[Legion] â€” Kill it now instead. (Get the effect if you've played another card this turn.)" If the Legion condition is satisï¬ed, the unit is killed immediately and the instruction to kill it the next time it takes damage is ignored, even if the unit remains on the board somehow. ğŸ“
154.3.
While a spell or ability on the chain is Resolving, no other spells or abilities can be ï¬nalized on the chain or resolved, including triggered abilities or game effects that would occur as a result of the execution of the spell. ğŸ“
154.3.a.
Finish resolving all effects of a spell before addressing anything the spell may have triggered or caused through execution. ğŸ“
155.
Certain Keywords on spells are not executable rules text, but instead intrinsic properties of the spell. ğŸ“
155.1.
These determine inherent properties and behaviors of the spell before being played or while on the chain. ğŸ“
155.2.
These keywords are: ğŸ“
155.2.a.
Action ğŸ“
155.2.a.1.
This indicates that, in addition to being able to be played during an Open State, this spell may also be played during Open States during Showdowns. ğŸ“
155.2.b.
Reaction ğŸ“
155.2.b.1.
Grants all cases and rules of Action. ğŸ“
155.2.b.2.
In addition to all prior cases, may also be played during all forms of Closed State. ğŸ“
155.2.b.3.
This will result in this spell resolving before spells and abilities that are already on the chain. ğŸ“
156.
Runes ğŸ“
157.
Rune is a Card Type. ğŸ“
157.1.
A Rune is not a Main Deck card. ğŸ“
157.1.a.
This means, despite remaining on the Board until Recycled or otherwise removed from the board, it is not a Permanent. ğŸ“
157.2.
Runes are kept in the Rune Deck. ğŸ“
157.2.a.
Exactly 12 Rune cards chosen during Deck Construction. See rule 103.3. Rune Deck for more information. ğŸ“
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information. ğŸ“
158.
Runes produce the resources needed to pay costs. ğŸ“
159.
Runes produce Energy and Power. ğŸ“
159.1.
Energy is used to pay numeric Energy costs. ğŸ“
159.1.a.
Energy has no Domain. ğŸ“
159.1.b.
Energy has no type. ğŸ“
159.2.
Power is used to pay Domain-associated Power Costs. ğŸ“
159.2.a.
Power has a Domain. ğŸ“
159.2.a.1.
Power's Domain usually corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that produced it. ğŸ“
159.2.b.
Some Power is Universal and can be used to pay for costs of any Domain. ğŸ“
160.
Basic Runes ğŸ“
160.1.
There are six Basic Runes, each with a Domain corresponding to its name: Fury Rune Calm Rune Mind Rune Body Rune Chaos Rune Order Rune ğŸ“
160.2.
A Basic Rune always has the following two Abilities: ğŸ“
160.2.a.
[E]: [Reaction] â€” Add [1]. ğŸ“
160.2.b.
Recycle this: [Reaction] â€” Add [C]. ğŸ“
160.2.b.1.
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled. ğŸ“
161.
Rune Pools ğŸ“
162.
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs. ğŸ“
162.1.
When a card adds Energy or Power, it is added to the controlling player's Rune Pool. ğŸ“
162.2.
Players must ï¬rst add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs. ğŸ“
162.3.
Energy and Power do not have a physical marker or tracker, although players may wish to use a physical tracker if they are retaining unspent Energy and Power over the course of their turn. ğŸ“
163.
Every player's Rune Pool empties at the end of each player's draw phase and the end of each player's turn. ğŸ“
163.1.
Any unspent Energy or Power are lost. ğŸ“
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information. ğŸ“
165.
Battleï¬elds ğŸ“
166.
Battleï¬elds are Game Objects. ğŸ“
166.1.
Battleï¬elds are Owned by a player. ğŸ“
166.2.
Battleï¬elds are not shufï¬‚ed into Decks at the start of a game. ğŸ“
166.2.a.
Battleï¬elds are not played during the course of regular play. ğŸ“
166.2.b.
Battleï¬elds are established at the start of a game and remain in place for the duration of regular play. ğŸ“
166.3.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Killed during the course of regular play. ğŸ“
166.4.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Moved. ğŸ“
166.5.
Battleï¬elds are Locations. ğŸ“
166.5.a.
Battleï¬elds can be Origins of moves. ğŸ“
166.5.b.
Battleï¬elds can be Destinations of moves. ğŸ“
166.6.
Any number of Units can be present at a Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
166.7.
Battleï¬elds can be targeted by spells or game effects. ğŸ“
166.8.
Battleï¬elds can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
166.9.
Battleï¬elds can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
167.
Battleï¬elds are not Permanents. ğŸ“
168.
The number of Battleï¬elds on the Board is determined by the Mode of Play. ğŸ“
169.
Legends ğŸ“
170.
Legends are Game Objects. ğŸ“
170.1.
Legends are Owned by a player. ğŸ“
170.2.
Legends are not shufï¬‚ed into Decks at the start of a game. ğŸ“
170.2.a.
Legends are not played during the course of regular play. ğŸ“
170.2.b.
Legends are established at the start of a game, and remain in place for the duration of regular play. ğŸ“
170.3.
Legends cannot be Killed during the course of regular play. ğŸ“
170.4.
Legends cannot be Moved. ğŸ“
170.5.
Legends can be targeted by spells or game effects. ğŸ“
170.6.
Legends can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
170.7.
Legends can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
170.8.
Legends can have Activated Abilities. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
171.
Legends are not Permanents. ğŸ“
172.
Legends may have one or more Domains. ğŸ“
172.1.
The Legend determines the Domain Identity of cards its owner can include. See rule 101. Deck Construction for more information. ğŸ“
173.
Tokens ğŸ“
174.
Tokens are Game Objects created by spells and abilities during play. ğŸ“
175.
Tokens can be represented by anything. Printed tokens are included in Riftbound booster packs, but they are not required to play a token. ğŸ“
176.
A token's controller is the controller of the spell or ability that created it, unless the token's type innately determines control or that spell or ability speciï¬es that a different player is the token's controller. ğŸ“
177.
A token's owner is the player who controlled the effect that created it. ğŸ“
178.
The effect that creates a token may specify the conditions or circumstances under which it enters the board. These stipulations may alter the usual steps for playing a card. ğŸ“
178.1.
The effect may state that the token enters ready or exhausted, if that state is contrary to the default for the token's type. ğŸ“
178.2.
The effect may restrict the location to which the token may be played. ğŸ“
178.3.
The effect may grant temporary abilities or modiï¬cations to the token. ğŸ“
179.
Tokens are not cards. ğŸ“
179.1.
Tokens have some properties in common with cards. ğŸ“
179.1.a.
Tokens are played by their owner if their card type is played, following all the applicable steps for playing a card plus any restrictions or modiï¬cations from the effect that created the token. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
179.1.b.
Token units have a Might. ğŸ“
179.1.c.
Tokens may have one or more tags. ğŸ“
179.1.d.
Tokens have a type. They follow all rules for their type unless otherwise speciï¬ed. Example: A token unit is a unit. It enters exhausted, can take the standard move action, deals damage equal to its Might in combat, is destroyed if it takes damage equal to or greater than its might, can be chosen or otherwise affected by spells or abilities that choose or affect units, etc. ğŸ“
179.2.
Tokens differ from cards in some ways. ğŸ“
179.2.a.
Tokens do not have costs. ğŸ“
179.2.b.
Tokens do not have domains. ğŸ“
180.
Tokens are created on the board and cannot exist elsewhere. ğŸ“
180.1.
If a token is put into any Non-Board Zone, it ceases to exist immediately after moving to its new zone. ğŸ“
181.
The spell or ability that creates a token speciï¬es some of its characteristics. It may have other characteristics, as listed below. ğŸ“
181.1.
A 1[M] Recruit token is a domainless unit token with 1 Might and the Recruit tag. ğŸ“
181.2.
A 3[M] Sprite token with Temporary is a domainless unit token with 3 Might, the Fae tag, and the Temporary keyword. See rule 742. Temporary for more information. ğŸ“
182.
Control ğŸ“
183.
Control is the concept of a player having inï¬‚uence of a Game Object and applies differently to different card types. ğŸ“
184.
Battleï¬elds ğŸ“
184.1.
Control is established over Battleï¬elds through the course of play. ğŸ“
184.2.
Control is a binary state for Battleï¬elds and an Identiï¬er for players. ğŸ“
184.2.a.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled or Uncontrolled. ğŸ“
184.2.b.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled by a speciï¬c player or Controlled by no one. ğŸ“
184.3.
Control can be Contested through the course of play. ğŸ“
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there. ğŸ“
184.3.a.1.
Units moving to or being played to a battleï¬eld apply Contested status if that battleï¬eld is not already contested and that Unitâ€™s controller does not already control that battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
184.3.b.
A Battleï¬eld remains Contested until Control is established or re-established. ğŸ“
184.3.c.
While a Battleï¬eld remains Contested, Control of a Battleï¬eld cannot change. ğŸ“
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change. ğŸ“
184.3.e.
At this time Game Effects cannot reference this status. ğŸ“
184.4.
Control is established by having Units at a Battleï¬eld at the end of a Showdown or Combat after applying the contested status. ğŸ“
184.4.a.
If a player controls Units at a Battleï¬eld, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battleï¬eld for as long as they have Units at that Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
184.4.b.
A player maintains control of a Battleï¬eld while it is being Contested by an opponent. ğŸ“
184.4.c.
If a player has no Units at a Battleï¬eld, they lose Control of that Battleï¬eld immediately, unless it is Contested. ğŸ“
184.5.
Control is a constant state. ğŸ“
184.6.
Control of a Battleï¬eld determines Control of its Abilities. ğŸ“
184.6.a.
While a Battleï¬eld is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed. ğŸ“
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability. ğŸ“
184.6.c.
â€œYouâ€ in a battleï¬eldâ€™s abilities refers to the battleï¬eldâ€™s Controller, as does the implied â€œyouâ€ in instructions like â€œdraw 1.â€ If the battleï¬eld has no Controller, â€œyouâ€ refers to no one, and all such instructions are ignored. ğŸ“
185.
Everything Else ğŸ“
185.1.
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.ğŸ“
185.2.
For Spells, they are the Spell's Controller.ğŸ“
185.2.a.
That player chooses targets. ğŸ“
185.2.b.
That player chooses modes. ğŸ“
185.2.c.
That player pays costs. ğŸ“
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.ğŸ“
185.3.a.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Inherent Abilities.ğŸ“
185.3.b.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Unique Abilities.ğŸ“
185.3.c.
That player may make decisions about any game effects or decisions necessary while the card is being played. ğŸ“
185.3.d.
That player may make decisions about any game effects created from "When you play me" effects of Permanents. ğŸ“
185.4.
For Abilities, they are the Abilityâ€™s Controller. ğŸ“
185.4.a.
By default, the Controller of an Abilityâ€™s Source is the Controller of that Ability. ğŸ“
185.4.b.
Changes to Control of an Abilityâ€™s Source do not change Control of that Ability. ğŸ“
185.4.c.
That player chooses targets. ğŸ“
185.4.d.
That player chooses modes. ğŸ“
185.4.e.
That player pays costs. ğŸ“
186.
When a game effect or rules text refers to the Controller of a speciï¬c object, it can be referring to either context interchangeably. ğŸ“
186.1.
The method of assignment of control is different, but the status of Control is the same across all Game Objects. ğŸ“
300.
Playing the Game ğŸ“
301.
The Turn ğŸ“
302.
Play continues cyclically until one player wins. ğŸ“
303.
The phases of a turn are rigid, but the actions taken during those steps can be done in any order, unless otherwise speciï¬ed. ğŸ“
303.1.
Game Actions of any nature are performed one at a time and are executed completely. ğŸ“
303.2.
Game Actions cannot be performed simultaneously for any reason. ğŸ“
303.2.a.
If one or more actions, game effects, or Triggered Abilities are activated simultaneously, then Turn Order is referenced to organize the sequence of actions. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
304.
The Turn Player is the player taking the current turn. ğŸ“
305.
When there are no items on the Chain and the Turn Player cannot or chooses not to perform any Discretionary Actions, the current phase or step of the turn ends and the next phase, step, or turn begins. ğŸ“
306.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn. ğŸ“
307.
States of the Turn ğŸ“
308.
At any given time, the turn is in either a Neutral State or a Showdown State. ğŸ“
308.1.
If a Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Showdown State. ğŸ“
308.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Action or Reaction keywords can be played or activated in a Showdown State. ğŸ“
308.2.
If no Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Neutral State. ğŸ“
309.
At any given time, the turn is in either an Open State or a Closed State. ğŸ“
309.1.
If a Chain exists, the turn is in a Closed State. ğŸ“
309.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Reaction keyword can be played or activated in a Closed State. ğŸ“
309.2.
If no Chain exists, the turn is in an Open State. ğŸ“
310.
These descriptions can be combined, such that the turn is always in one of these four states: ğŸ“
310.1.
Neutral Open: There is no Showdown in progress and no Chain exists. ğŸ“
310.1.a.
By default, cards can be played and abilities activated only when a player has priority on their turn in a Neutral Open state. ğŸ“
310.2.
Neutral Closed: There is no Showdown in progress and a Chain exists. ğŸ“
310.3.
Showdown Open: A Showdown is in progress and no Chain exists. ğŸ“
310.4.
Showdown Closed: A Showdown is in progress and a Chain exists. ğŸ“
311.
Priority and Focus ğŸ“
312.
At any given time, up to one player has Priority. ğŸ“
312.1.
Priority is the singular exclusive right to take Discretionary Actions. See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information. ğŸ“
312.1.a.
The player with Priority can take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions. ğŸ“
312.1.b.
If no player has Priority, no player can take Discretionary Actions. ğŸ“
312.1.b.1.
Players can always take and make choices for Limited Actions when instructed, regardless of Priority. ğŸ“
312.2.
A player receives Priority at the following times: ğŸ“
312.2.a.
When the turn is in a Neutral Open State during their Action Phase. ğŸ“
312.2.b.
When the turn is in a Showdown State and they gain Focus. ğŸ“
312.2.c.
When the turn is in a Closed State and they control the next item on the Chain. ğŸ“
312.2.d.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes. ğŸ“
312.3
When a player is granted Priority, it is either created if no player has it or taken from the player with Priority. ğŸ“
313.
At any given time, up to one player has Focus. ğŸ“
313.1.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information. ğŸ“
313.1.a.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed. Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords. ğŸ“
313.2.
A player who gains Focus also gains Priority. ğŸ“
313.3.
A player who passes Priority retains Focus. ğŸ“
313.4
A player may not make discretionary actions with Focus unless they also possess Priority. ğŸ“
313.5.
If the turn is in a Neutral State, no player has Focus. ğŸ“
314.
Phases of the Turn ğŸ“
315.
Start of Turn ğŸ“
315.1.
Awaken Phase ğŸ“
315.1.a.
The Turn Player readies all Game Objects they control that are able to be readied. See rule 402. Ready for more information. ğŸ“
315.2.
Beginning Phase ğŸ“
315.2.a.
Beginning Step ğŸ“
315.2.a.1.
At the start of Beginning Phase game effects take place. ğŸ“
315.2.b.
Scoring Step ğŸ“
315.2.b.1.
Holding occurs at this time. See rule 445. Scoring for more information. ğŸ“
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player. ğŸ“
315.2.c.
Speciï¬c game effects or abilities will reference this timing and phase as necessary. ğŸ“
315.3.
Channel Phase ğŸ“
315.3.a.
The Turn Player gains their additional runes for the turn. ğŸ“
315.3.b.
The Turn Player channels 2 runes from their Rune Deck. See rule 417. Channel for more information. ğŸ“
315.3.b.1.
If there are fewer than 2 runes in the Rune Deck, they channel as many as possible. ğŸ“
315.3.c.
Perform any actions as instructed by game objects during this time. ğŸ“
315.4.
Draw Phase ğŸ“
315.4.a.
The Turn Player gains their additional card for the turn. ğŸ“
315.4.b.
The Turn Player draws 1. ğŸ“
315.4.b.1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information. ğŸ“
315.4.b.2.
After completing the Burn Out the Turn Player still Draws 1. ğŸ“
315.4.c.
Perform any actions as instructed by game objects during this time. ğŸ“
315.4.d.
As the Draw Phase ends, each player's Rune Pool empties. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information. ğŸ“
316.
Action Phase ğŸ“
316.1.
When all steps of the Start of Turn have been completed, the Action Phase begins. ğŸ“
316.2.
The Action Phase has no deï¬ned structure. ğŸ“
316.2.a.
A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions they are able to perform during this phase. See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information. ğŸ“
316.2.b.
This is denoted as a Neutral Open State, and only the Turn Player has the ability to play spells or activate abilities. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information. ğŸ“
316.2.b.1.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction. ğŸ“
316.2.c.
In Modes of Play with Teammates, spells may be played by Teammates of the Turn Player during this time, but the actions of the Turn Player take precedence. ğŸ“
316.3.
As a result of a player taking Discretionary Actions, one or more structured phases may occur. ğŸ“
316.4.
Combat ğŸ“
316.4.a.
A Combat phase occurs as a result of Units controlled by opposing players being present at the same Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
316.4.b.
This could be the result of a Standard Move Standard Action, a Spell, or other Game Effect. ğŸ“
316.4.c.
The source effect does not change the structure or ï¬‚ow of Combat once initiated. ğŸ“
316.4.d.
A Combat can only occur between two players. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
316.4.e.
Play proceeds following the steps of combat. See rule 441. Steps of Combat for more information. ğŸ“
316.4.f.
Combat will also include a Showdown. ğŸ“
316.5.
Showdowns ğŸ“
316.5.a.
A Showdown occurs when a Combat occurs. ğŸ“
316.5.a.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of Combat are a Sub-Phase of Combat. ğŸ“
316.5.b.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battleï¬eld when the Contested status is applied to a Battleï¬eld with no current controller. ğŸ“
316.5.b.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of a player moving to an empty Battleï¬eld are a stand-alone Phase and do not create a Combat. ğŸ“
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information. ğŸ“
316.6.
When a player has no more Discretionary Actions they wish to execute, they must indicate they are ending their turn. ğŸ“
316.6.a.
This ends the Action Phase. ğŸ“
316.6.b.
Play proceeds to the End of Turn. ğŸ“
317.
End of Turn Phase ğŸ“
317.1.
Ending Step ğŸ“
317.1.a.
At the end of the turn Game Effects take place. ğŸ“
317.1.b.
Speciï¬c game effects and abilities will reference this timing and phase as necessary. ğŸ“
317.2.
End of Turn Cleanup ğŸ“
317.2.a.
Invoke an End of Turn Special Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. ğŸ“
317.2.b.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€ ğŸ“
317.3.
Expiration Step ğŸ“
317.3.a.
All "this turn" effects expire simultaneously. ğŸ“
317.3.b.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost. ğŸ“
317.4.
The Turn Player then becomes the next player in Turn Order. ğŸ“
318.
Cleanups ğŸ“
319.
A Cleanup occurs at the following times: ğŸ“
319.1.
After the game transitions to or from an Open or Closed state ğŸ“
319.2.
After the game transitions between Phases ğŸ“
319.3.
After a Pending Item becomes a Legal Item on the Chain ğŸ“
319.4.
After a Chain Item is removed from the Chain for any reason ğŸ“
319.5.
After any number of Game Objects enter or leave the Board ğŸ“
319.6.
After the status of any number of Game Objects changes for any reason ğŸ“
319.7.
After a Move is completed ğŸ“
320.
While a Cleanup is occurring, Chain Items cannot be Resolved. ğŸ“
320.1.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded. ğŸ“
321.
If an event occurs during a Cleanup that qualiï¬es for a Cleanup, another Cleanup will occur immediately after the ï¬rst completes, repeating until a Cleanup occurs with no new change in the gameâ€™s state. ğŸ“
322.
When a Cleanup occurs, the following steps occur in order: ğŸ“
322.1.
1. If a player has as many points as the Victory Score, that player wins. ğŸ“
322.2
2. Handle outstanding board state ğŸ“
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information. ğŸ“
322.4.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash. ğŸ“
322.5.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress ğŸ“
322.5.a.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now ğŸ“
322.5.b.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but have the opposite designation of their controller, they lose that designation, and gain the same designation as their controller now ğŸ“
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now ğŸ“
322.6.
4. Battleï¬elds with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled. ğŸ“
322.7.
5. Recall all Gear at Battleï¬elds. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battleï¬elds that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash. ğŸ“
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled. ğŸ“
322.8.a
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battleï¬eld that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested ğŸ“
322.9
6a. If Units of an opposing player are present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Showdown staged before it can be Opened, the Showdown will cease being Staged ğŸ“
322.10.
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players. ğŸ“
322.10.a.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battleï¬eld as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there. ğŸ“
322.11
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged ğŸ“
322.12.
8. Finalize any Pending Items on the Chain ğŸ“
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there. ğŸ“
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there. ğŸ“
323.
Special Cleanups are Cleanup steps invoked at speciï¬c times that have additional steps not present in a normal Cleanup. ğŸ“
323.1.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and deï¬ned by the sub-section that invokes it. Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section deï¬nes what steps are added to the Cleanup. ğŸ“
323.2.
If events during a Special Cleanup require another Cleanup, a normal Cleanup is invoked, not another iteration of the Special Cleanup. ğŸ“
324.
Chains and Showdowns ğŸ“
325.
Players can act during the following Windows of Opportunity that occur during the course of regular play: ğŸ“
325.1.
During a Chain ğŸ“
325.2.
During a Showdown ğŸ“
326.
Chains ğŸ“
327.
The Chain is a Non-Board Zone that temporarily exists whenever a card is played or an ability is activated. ğŸ“
327.1.
Cards are placed here as part of the process of being played. ğŸ“
327.2.
Abilities are queued here as part of the process of resolving. See rule 357. Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
328.
Cards and abilities added to the chain are added as Pending Chain Items that become Finalized Chain Items. ğŸ“
328.1.
Pending Items are on the Chain. ğŸ“
328.2.
Chain Items are Pending until the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
328.3.
When a Pending Chain Item is no longer Pending it is ï¬nalized and becomes a Finalized Chain Item. ğŸ“
329.
The Chain exists as long as a Chain Item is on it. ğŸ“
329.1.
Only one Chain can exist at a time. ğŸ“
329.2.
If a card would begin to be played while a Chain already exists, it is placed on the existing Chain. ğŸ“
330.
The State of the Turn is partially determined by whether or not the Chain currently exists. ğŸ“
330.1.
The turn is said to be in a Closed State if a Chain exists. ğŸ“
330.1.a.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State. ğŸ“
330.1.b.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State. ğŸ“
330.2.
The turn is said to be in an Open State if no Chain exists. ğŸ“
331.
Steps of Resolving Chain Items ğŸ“
332.
Whenever a card or token is played or an ability is activated or triggered, a Chain is created. ğŸ“
332.1.
The player that created the chain becomes the ï¬rst Active Player. ğŸ“
332.2.
The Active Player is a designator similar to, but distinct from, Turn Player. ğŸ“
332.3.
Similar to the Turn Player, this designation will pass between players over the course of play. ğŸ“
333.
Step 1: Finalize ğŸ“
333.1.
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain. ğŸ“
333.1.a.
This process does not pass Priority. ğŸ“
333.1.b.
Each Item is Finalized in the order it was appended to the Chain. ğŸ“
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
333.1.c.1.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State. ğŸ“
333.1.c.2.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, repeat Step 1. ğŸ“
333.1.c.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute. ğŸ“
334.
Step 2: Execute ğŸ“
334.1.
The Active Player may do any the following: ğŸ“
334.1.a.
Play a Card that is legally timed. ğŸ“
334.1.a.1.
Cards, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State. ğŸ“
334.1.a.2.
A Legally Timed Card would be a Card with Reaction. ğŸ“
334.1.a.3.
Other exceptions may be created during regular play. ğŸ“
334.1.a.4.
The card will be added to the chain as a Pending Item, following the steps of playing a card. ğŸ“
334.1.a.5.
This can be an additional card to the item that Started the Chain in the case of the ï¬rst Active Player after creating the Chain. ğŸ“
334.1.a.6.
Whether a Card is legally timed is evaluated during the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
334.1.a.7.
Playing a card will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize. ğŸ“
334.1.b.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
334.1.b.1.
All rules for legally timed cards apply to legally timed abilities. ğŸ“
334.1.b.2.
Activating abilities will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize. ğŸ“
334.1.c.
Pass Priority ğŸ“
334.1.c.1.
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass. ğŸ“
335.
Step 3: Pass ğŸ“
335.1.
If all players have passed Priority without adding any items to the Chain, proceed to Step 4: Resolve. ğŸ“
335.2.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute. ğŸ“
336.
Step 4: Resolve ğŸ“
336.1.
The newest item on the Chain resolves. Execute its game effects in their entirety. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information on resolving spells. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information on resolving abilities. ğŸ“
336.2.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State. ğŸ“
336.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, return to Step 1: Finalize. ğŸ“
336.4.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute. ğŸ“
337.
Showdowns ğŸ“
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion. ğŸ“
338.1.
Each spell played this way creates a Chain as normal. ğŸ“
339.
The State of the turn is partially determined by whether or not a Showdown is in progress. ğŸ“
339.1.
The turn is said to be in a Showdown State if a Showdown is in progress. ğŸ“
339.1.a.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State. ğŸ“
339.1.b.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State. ğŸ“
339.2.
The turn is said to be in a Neutral State if no Showdown is in progress. ğŸ“
340.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State. ğŸ“
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested. ğŸ“
341.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battleï¬eld gains Focus. ğŸ“
342.
When a Showdown begins, it may or may not begin with an Initial Chain. ğŸ“
342.1.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities. ğŸ“
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain. ğŸ“
342.1.b.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed. ğŸ“
343.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority. ğŸ“
343.1.
Focus does not pass when the last item on the Initial Chain resolves, if there was one. Instead the player with Focus proceeds with play. ğŸ“
344.
During a Showdown, the player with Focus may do one of the following: ğŸ“
344.1.
Play a spell that is legally timed. ğŸ“
344.1.a.
The spell will start a Chain as normal. ğŸ“
344.2.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 357. Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
344.3.
Pass. ğŸ“
344.3.a.
If all Players have passed once in sequence, the Showdown ends. ğŸ“
344.3.a.1.
Perform a Cleanup. ğŸ“
344.4.
Otherwise, Focus passes to the next Player in Turn Order. ğŸ“
345.
If all players pass Focus without playing a spell or activating an ability, then the Showdown Closes. ğŸ“
345.1.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Combat, proceed with the remaining steps of Combat to resolve the phase. See rule 441. The Steps of Combat for more information. ğŸ“
345.2.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Contested being applied to a Battleï¬eld without a controller, do one of the following: ğŸ“
345.2.a.
If only one playerâ€™s Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, and if that player does not already Control the Battleï¬eld, that player establishes Control over the Battleï¬eld. See rule 179. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering. ğŸ“
345.2.a.1.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn. ğŸ“
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
345.2.b.1.
The player who applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat. ğŸ“
346.
Playing Cards ğŸ“
347.
Playing a card is the act of a player utilizing their cards. ğŸ“
347.1.
A card is Played when it has ï¬nished this process in its entirety. ğŸ“
347.2.
Tokens are not cards, but can still be Played. See rule 173. Tokens for more information. ğŸ“
348.
Cards have different behaviors when played. ğŸ“
348.1.
Permanents become Game Objects when Played. ğŸ“
348.2.
Spells create game effects that are executed, then the card is placed in the trash when Played. ğŸ“
349.
Cards have different states during the process of being played. ğŸ“
349.1.
When initially being played cards are Pending, as Pending Chain Items. ğŸ“
349.2.
Near the end of the process cards will cease being Pending and become Finalized Chain Items. ğŸ“
350.
The Process of Play ğŸ“
351.
1. Remove the card from the zone you are playing it from and put it onto the Chain. ğŸ“
351.1.
This Closes the State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information. ğŸ“
351.2.
This item becomes Pending. ğŸ“
351.3.
If another Card Effect or ability is currently resolving, continue resolving it before proceeding with any further steps of this process. ğŸ“
352.
2. Make necessary choices. ğŸ“
352.1.
If the card is a spell, or has an effect that speciï¬es a choice "As I am played," those choices are made now. ğŸ“
352.2.
For Units, choose a valid Location where that Unit will be placed upon being Played. ğŸ“
352.2.a
By default, Valid locations include the controllerâ€™s Base or a Battleï¬eld the controller controls. ğŸ“
352.2.b
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit.. ğŸ“
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed. ğŸ“
352.4.
If a card requires you to speciï¬cally choose one or more Game Objects, that choice is made now. ğŸ“
352.4.a.
This does not include cards that affect one or more Game Objects based on criteria. Example: "Stun a unit at a battleï¬eld" is a Choice. Example: "Kill all gear" is not a Choice. ğŸ“
352.4.b.
This does not include making choices for Triggered Abilities of permanents, even if those abilities trigger when the permanent is played. Example: A unit with a triggered ability that says "When I'm played, kill a unit" does not require you to choose a target as it's played. The target will be chosen when the ability triggers. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
352.5.
Targeting ğŸ“
352.6.
When a card Chooses one or more speciï¬c Game Objects to affect, it is Targeted. ğŸ“
352.7.
In order to put a spell or ability on the chain, valid choices must be made for all targets. ğŸ“
352.8.
A target is a valid choice if it meets all of the following requirements: ğŸ“
352.8.a.
It is a permanent or rune on the board, a spell or ability on the chain, a player or zone, or speciï¬ed explicitly or implicitly as being in some other zone. e.g., â€œKill a unitâ€ targets a unit on the board. e.g., â€œRecycle a unit from your trashâ€ targets a unit card in your trash. ğŸ“
352.8.a.1.
â€œUnit,â€ â€œgear,â€ and â€œruneâ€ refer to objects on the Board unless speciï¬ed otherwise. ğŸ“
352.8.a.2.
â€œSpellâ€ and â€œabilityâ€ refer to objects on the Chain unless speciï¬ed otherwise. ğŸ“
352.8.a.3.
â€œFacedown cardâ€ refers to a card in a Facedown Zone unless speciï¬ed otherwise. ğŸ“
352.8.a.4.
â€œLegendâ€ refers to a legend in the Legend Zone. ğŸ“
352.8.a.5.
â€œChosen Championâ€ and â€œunit in the Champion Zoneâ€ refer to a unit in the Champion Zone unless speciï¬ed otherwise. ğŸ“
352.8.b.
It meets all targeting restrictions. e.g., A unit is a valid target for a spell that refers to a â€œunit at a battleï¬eld,â€ â€œenemy unit,â€ â€œunit you control,â€ or â€œunit with Might 4 or greaterâ€ only if it meets the appropriate criteria. ğŸ“
352.8.c.
It is not the spell or ability itself. e.g., A spell that says â€œCounter a spellâ€ cannot target itself. e.g., An ability of a permanent can target that permanent, because abilities and their sources are separate objects. ğŸ“
352.9.
If a spell or ability requires one or more players to choose objects, players, or zones that are not targets, those choices are made on resolution. ğŸ“
352.9.a.
Passive abilities never have targets. ğŸ“
352.9.b.
Replacement effects never have targets. ğŸ“
352.9.c.
Units and gear never have targets, although their abilities may. ğŸ“
352.10.
A game object, player, or zone mentioned in the text of a spell, activated ability, or triggered ability is a target UNLESS any of the following are true: ğŸ“
352.10.a.
It is in a zone whose information status is not Public. e.g., â€œReady a legendâ€ targets a legend, because the Legend Zone is Public. e.g., â€œReturn a unit from your trash to your handâ€ targets a unit card in your trash, because your trash is Public. e.g., â€œYou may play a unit from your hand, ignoring its costsâ€ does not target a unit card in your hand, because your hand is not a public zone. ğŸ“
352.10.a.1.
Public zones are Battleï¬eld Zones, Bases, Trashes, Legend Zones, Champion Zones, and Facedown Zones. ğŸ“
352.10.b.
It is included only as part of a targeting restriction for another choice. e.g., â€œKill a unit at a battleï¬eldâ€ targets a unit, but not a battleï¬eld, because the units are targets and â€œat a battleï¬eldâ€ is a restriction. e.g., â€œKill all units at a battleï¬eldâ€ targets a battleï¬eld, but not any units. e.g., â€œMove a unit to a battleï¬eldâ€ targets both a unit and a battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
352.10.c.
It is included only as part of a cost, trigger condition, or replacement effect. e.g., â€œAs an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unitâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything. e.g., â€œWhen a friendly unit dies, kill a gearâ€ targets a gear, but not a friendly unit. e.g., â€œWhen you play me, the next time a friendly unit would die this turn, return it to your hand insteadâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything. The replacement effect applies when any friendly unit dies. e.g., â€œChoose a friendly unit. The next time it would die this turn, return it to your hand insteadâ€ targets a friendly unit, because â€œchoose a friendly unitâ€ is not part of the replacement effect. ğŸ“
352.10.c.1.
This includes costs within instructions, identiï¬ed by phrases like â€œ[do X] to [do Y].â€ The cost within that instruction is â€œ[do X].â€ e.g., â€œWhen I hold, you may kill another friendly unit here to draw 1â€ does not target anything. e.g., â€œWhen you play me, you may spend a buff to move a friendly unitâ€ targets the friendly unit, but not the buff. ğŸ“
352.10.d.
It is programmatically selected based on its characteristics rather than chosen by the spell or abilityâ€™s controller. e.g., â€œKill all units at a battleï¬eldâ€ targets a battleï¬eld, but does not target any units. e.g., â€œKill all units at battleï¬eldsâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything. e.g., â€œDestroy a unit. Its controller draws 2 cardsâ€ targets the unit, but not its controller. e.g., â€œReady your legendâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything, because you can only have one legend. e.g., â€œReady a friendly legendâ€ targets a legend, because in a 2v2 game there are two friendly legends. e.g., â€œRecycle all cards in your trashâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything, because it affects all cards and you only have one trash. ğŸ“
352.10.d.1.
This exception applies solely to objects for which no choice is ever possible. ğŸ“
352.10.d.2.
This exception does not apply to objects that are the only valid choice at the moment a spell or ability is placed on the chain, but which would require a choice under other circumstances. e.g., â€œKill a unit at a battleï¬eldâ€ always targets a unit, even if that unit is the only unit currently at a battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
352.10.e.
It is part of a set of objects chosen in whole or in part by other players. e.g., â€œEach player kills a unit they controlâ€ does not target. Each player, including the one who played the spell, chooses a unit to kill as the spell or ability resolves. ğŸ“
352.10.f.
It is identiï¬ed in an instruction that a player â€œmustâ€ complete. e.g., â€œYou must recycle one of your runesâ€ doesnâ€™t target anything. You choose from among your runes as the spell or ability resolves. e.g., â€œRecycle a rune you controlâ€ targets a rune. You choose a rune you control as you put the spell or ability on the chain. ğŸ“
352.11.
Some cards identify a group of Targets with Targeting Requirements that must be met by the group as a whole. ğŸ“
352.11.a.
As theyâ€™re ï¬nalized on the chain, such cards can choose any group of valid targets that collectively fulï¬ll the targeting restriction. ğŸ“
352.11.b.
If the group of targets no longer collectively fulï¬ll the targeting restriction as the spell or ability resolves, that spell or abilityâ€™s controller can choose a subset of the original targets that fulï¬lls the targeting requirement for the spell or ability to affect. Example: A player plays Fox-Fire, a spell that says in part â€œKill any number of units at a battleï¬eld with total Might 4 or less.â€ That player chooses four 1 [M] Recruit tokens at a single battleï¬eld. As a Reaction, another player gives two of those Recruits +1 [M], so the Recruitsâ€™ Mights are 1, 1, 2, and 2. Then Fox-Fire resolves. The Recruits no longer have total Might 4 or less, so Fox-Fireâ€™s controller must choose a legal subset of the original targets to affect. They could choose to kill the two 2 [M] Recruits, or the two 1 [M] Recruits plus one 2 [M] Recruit. The units they choose are Fox-Fireâ€™s remaining legal targets. They canâ€™t choose to affect units at the same battleï¬eld that werenâ€™t initially chosen as targets, and they canâ€™t affect any units that are no longer at the chosen battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
352.12.
If a card speciï¬es that a player may choose some number of Game Objects to be affected by a card, then all choices are considered targeted and chosen independently. ğŸ“
352.13.
If a card speciï¬es that a player chooses â€œany numberâ€ or â€œup toâ€ some number of Game Objects to be affected, they may choose any number of available targets, including zero. If they choose zero, the spell or ability can be played without any targets. ğŸ“
352.14.
Splitting ğŸ“
