352.14.a.
If a card speciï¬es that an amount of damage may be split among some number of Units, then each Unit chosen is Targeted. ğŸ“
352.14.b.
The Targets are chosen when the spell or ability is ï¬nalized on the chain. ğŸ“
352.14.c.
A number of Targets can only be chosen up to, and not exceeding, the initial amount of damage available when the spell is played. Example: A player playing a spell that instructs them to "Split 5 damage" may only choose up to 5 units, but may choose fewer. ğŸ“
352.14.d.
Each Target is valid, and contributes to Chosen triggers individually. ğŸ“
352.14.e.
The choice of how much damage is divided across the split is not decided until the resolution of the spell or ability. ğŸ“
352.14.f.
Each Target must receive a valid amount of damage. ğŸ“
352.14.g.
Valid damage is a positive integer amount, greater than or equal to 1 damage. ğŸ“
352.14.h.
If, at resolution of the spell or effect, there are more Targets than available damage to divide, then the player who controls the effect dealing damage determines which Targets cease being Targets. ğŸ“
352.14.i.
Any costs that were paid, or effects that were triggered as a result of those Game Objects being chosen as Targets remain in effect, paid, or otherwise triggered. ğŸ“
352.15.
These choices cannot be changed after this step. ğŸ“
352.16.
A player may not make choices during this step that will deterministically result in illegal choices or actions later in this process unless they have no choice. Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They control exactly one unit, which is at a battleï¬eld. They can't choose to play Cruel Patron to that battleï¬eld, because by the time they have ï¬nished paying costs, they will no longer control that battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
353.
3. Determine Total Cost. ğŸ“
353.1.
If an ability or instruction allows you to "ignore" one or more of a card's costs, set the appropriate Base Cost(s) of the card to zero. ğŸ“
353.1.a.
If a card allows a player to play a card "ignoring its cost," its base Energy cost and base Power cost are set to zero. ğŸ“
353.1.b.
If a card instructs a player to play a card "ignoring its Energy cost" or "ignoring its Power cost," only the appropriate cost is set to zero, and the remaining cost still applies. ğŸ“
353.1.c.
Further additional costs and/or cost increases applied in subsequent steps may raise the card's Total Cost above zero. Example: Legion Rearguard is a Fury unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and has Accelerate. A player plays Legion Rearguard and is instructed to ignore its costs, but chooses to pay the Accelerate cost. They ignore Legion Rearguard's Base Cost of 2 Energy, but the optional additional cost of 1 Energy and 1 Fury Power is added to its Total Cost and must be paid. ğŸ“
353.2.
Apply additional costs in any order. ğŸ“
353.2.a.
Mandatory Additional Costs ğŸ“
353.2.a.1.
Some Additional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Mandatory, and must be paid to complete playing the card. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and don't include the word "may." Example: A unit has the passive ability "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." To play that unit, a player must kill a friendly unit. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
353.2.a.2.
The cost imposed by the Deï¬‚ect keyword is a Mandatory Additional Cost. See rule 735. Deï¬‚ect for more information. ğŸ“
353.2.b.
Optional Additional Costs ğŸ“
353.2.b.1.
Some Optional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Non-Mandatory, and must be paid only if the player made the choice to pay them in rule 352.They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and the word "may." Example: A unit has the ability "As you play me, you may discard 1 as an additional cost. If you do, reduce my cost by [2]." While playing the unit, its controller declares their intention to pay the additional cost in rule 352, applies that additional cost in rule 353.2, applies the discount granted by paying that cost in rule 353.4, and discards a card to pay that additional cost in rule 354.2.See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
353.3.
Apply cost increases. ğŸ“
353.4.
Apply discounts in any order. ğŸ“
353.4.a.
Discounts may be applied by the card being played or by any other card or effect. ğŸ“
353.4.b.
Discounts may say that cards "cost [amount] less" or that one or more of their costs are "reduced by [amount]." ğŸ“
353.4.c.
If a discount applies a minimum cost, that minimum applies only to that discount. Example: Eager Apprentice says "While I'm at a battleï¬eld, the Energy costs for spells you play is reduced by [1], to a minimum of [1]." A player who controls Eager Apprentice and a unit with 7 Might plays Sky Splitter, a spell that costs 8 Energy and says "This spell's Energy cost is reduced by the highest Might among units you control." That player can choose to apply Eager Apprentice's discount ï¬rst, reducing Sky Splitter's Energy cost to 7, then apply Sky Splitter's discount, reducing its Energy cost to 0. If they applied these discounts in the other order, Sky Splitter's Energy cost would be 1. ğŸ“
353.4.d.
Discounts can reduce additional costs, including to 0. ğŸ“
353.4.d.1.
An optional additional cost was "paid" if the player made the decision in rule 352to pay it. It doesn't matter how much the player actually paid. Example: Clockwork Keeper is a unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and says "As you play me, you may pay [C] as an additional cost. If you do, draw " A player controls a card that says "Units you play cost [A] less." That player plays Clockwork Keeper and chooses to pay the optional additional cost of [C]. They will draw a card, even though the optional additional cost was reduced to 0. ğŸ“
353.5.
Energy and Power costs can't be reduced below 0. ğŸ“
353.6.
Costs may be Energy costs, Power costs, or non-standard costs. Example: A card reads "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." Killing a friendly unit is an additional cost to play that card. ğŸ“
354.
4. Pay the card's costs. ğŸ“
354.1.
In total, pay the combined Energy cost (if any) and Power cost (if any). ğŸ“
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information. ğŸ“
354.2.
In addition, pay any non-standard Cost summed in rule 353.2in any order. ğŸ“
354.2.a.
Costs that are replaced with other events by replacement effects are still considered paid. Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They also control Zhonyaâ€™s Hourglass, which says â€œIf a friendly unit would die, kill this instead. Heal that unit, exhaust it, and recall it.â€ They choose to kill a friendly unit during rule 353.2, but as they pay the cost in rule 354.2, Zhonyaâ€™s Hourglass replaces that unitâ€™s death. The cost is considered paid, and the player can continue playing Cruel Patron. ğŸ“
354.3.
A player may not pay costs during this step that will deterministically result in illegal choices or actions later in this process unless they have no choice. Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They control multiple units, one of which is alone at a battleï¬eld. During rule 352.2., they chose to play Cruel Patron to that battleï¬eld. While paying costs, they can't choose to kill the unit at that battleï¬eld, because then they will no longer control that battleï¬eld and Cruel Patron cannot legally be played there. If they controlled that battleï¬eld with multiple units, any of those units would be a legal choice, because they would still control the battleï¬eld after killing one. ğŸ“
355.
5. Check legality. ğŸ“
355.1.
Check that all chosen targets are legal. ğŸ“
355.2.
Ensure that the outcome of the effect of this card being played would not create an illegal state. Example: Check that a spell's execution does not create a state where a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by 3 different players. ğŸ“
355.3.
If the card, if continued to be played, would create an illegal state, or if a choice or action at this state is illegal, the actions taken in this process are undone and the action is cancelled. ğŸ“
356.
6. Finalize this card and proceed with the card's category of Play. ğŸ“
356.1.
This card is no longer Pending. ğŸ“
356.2.
A Permanent leaves the Chain and becomes a Game Object. ğŸ“
356.2.a.
Any passive abilities become active. ğŸ“
356.2.b.
Execute all rules text on the card, from top to bottom. ğŸ“
356.2.c.
If it is a Unit, it enters the Board exhausted at the Location that was chosen. ğŸ“
356.2.d.
If it is a Gear, it enters the Board Ready at the player's Base. ğŸ“
356.3.
A Spell lingers on the Chain. ğŸ“
356.3.a.
This card becomes a Finalized Chain Item. ğŸ“
356.3.b.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, then the controller of those Pending Items completes Steps 2 through 5 of Playing Cards for those items before continuing. See rule 326. Chains for more information. ğŸ“
356.3.c.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information. ğŸ“
356.3.d.
Otherwise, execute the game effect of the spell, from top to bottom of the rules text of the card and then place the card in the Trash of the owning player. ğŸ“
356.3.e.
Handling illegal and impossible instructions ğŸ“
356.3.e.1.
The spell resolves even if some or all of its targets are illegal. ğŸ“
356.3.e.2.
A target is illegal as the spell resolves if it no longer meets the targeting requirements of the spell, or if it has changed Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone. ğŸ“
356.3.e.3.
If a target ceases to meet the targeting requirements while the spell is on the chain, then meets them again, it's a legal target. Example: A spell targets "a unit at a battleï¬eld." A player reacts with a spell that moves the unit to base, then another player reacts with a spell that moves it back to that battleï¬eld, then the original spell resolves. The unit is a legal target. ğŸ“
356.3.e.4.
If a target changes Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone and then returns to its original zone, it is no longer a legal target, because it's not treated as the same object. Examples: An enemy unit at a battleï¬eld is no longer a legal target if it is no longer an enemy, no longer a unit, or no longer at a battleï¬eld. A unit with 3 or less Might is no longer a legal target if it is no longer a unit or if its Might is greater than 3. Something that's exhausted is no longer a legal target if it is no longer exhausted. (It can't stop being "something.") A spell that's played from hidden can normally only target its own battleï¬eld or something at that battleï¬eld. A target for such a spell may cease to be a legal target if it moves from the battleï¬eld where that spell was played, even if the spell has no location targeting requirement otherwise. ğŸ“
356.3.e.5.
If any of the spell's targets are no longer legal, those targets are unaffected by the spell as it resolves. Example: A player plays Void Seeker, a spell that says "Deal 4 to a unit at a battleï¬eld. Draw 1." The unit's controller uses a Reaction to move the unit to their base. Since the unit is no longer a legal target, it is not dealt any damage. Void Seeker's controller still draws 1. ğŸ“
356.3.e.6.
Instructions that can't be followed, either because of illegal targets or other circumstances, are ignored. ğŸ“
356.3.e.7.
If all of an instruction's Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, that instruction will not execute. ğŸ“
356.3.e.8.
If an instruction has more than one Target and fewer than all of the Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, the instruction will execute, with only the Targets available and valid being operated on. ğŸ“
356.3.e.9.
The process for a card's choice becoming Invalid or Unavailable is referred to as mistargeting. Example: A spell has the instruction "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld." Before that instruction can execute, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The instruction will not be executed, because it speciï¬es that the unit it chooses must be at a Battleï¬eld, and by the time it attempted to execute, the unit was no longer valid as a choice. ğŸ“
356.3.e.10.
It is possible for none of a spell's instructions to be executed as it resolves, due to all of them requiring targets to act on and all of those targets becoming Invalid or Unavailable. In this case, the spell has no effect but is still considered played. Example: A player plays a spell that reads "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld" with no other instructions, and chooses an enemy unit at a battleï¬eld. They also control a unit with the ability "When you play a spell, give me +1 [M] this turn." Before the spell resolves, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The spell resolves and its only instruction cannot be executed, but the unit's ability still triggers as the spell resolves and gives it +1 [M]. ğŸ“
356.3.e.11.
Instructions that can be partially followed are followed as much as possible and ignored otherwise. Example: A player plays a spell that says "Discard 2, then draw 2" If their hand is empty, the instruction to discard 2 will be ignored. They'll still draw 2. If they had 1 card in hand, they would discard it and draw 2. ğŸ“
356.3.e.12.
If the spell checks information about a target that is no longer legal or a card or permanent whose location, zone, or status has changed such that that information is no longer available, that check returns "null" and all calculations based on it are ignored. Examples: A unit that is no longer on the board is treated as having null Might, null cost, etc. A unit that is no longer on the board has no location, is neither exhausted nor readied, etc. Baited Hook says "[1][C], [E]: Kill a friendly unit. Look at the top 5 cards of your Main Deck. You may banish a unit from among them that has Might up to 1 more than the killed unit and play it, ignoring its cost. Then recycle the rest." While Baited Hookâ€™s ability is on the chain, an opponent reacts with a spell that returns the friendly unit to its owner's hand. Because the friendly unit is no longer a legal target, it can't be killed and its Might is treated as null. Baited Hookâ€™s controller reveals the top 5 cards of their Main Deck, but canâ€™t choose any unit from among them. ğŸ“
356.3.e.13.
A spell or ability that moves something to a different zone as a cost or effect can "look back" at its characteristics before it changes zones. ğŸ“
357.
Abilities ğŸ“
358.
An Ability is the structured rules and capabilities of Game Objects or Spells. ğŸ“
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities ğŸ“
359.
A card can have more than one Ability and more than one type of Ability. ğŸ“
360.
Passive Abilities ğŸ“
361.
Conditions, rules, constraints, or statements that affect the course of regular play. ğŸ“
361.1.
These abilities have a wide variety of formats to recognize. Example: "I get +1[M] while you have 2 or more cards in your hand." Example: "Friendly Yordles at my battleï¬eld have [Shield]." ğŸ“
361.2.
They can be recognized by being statements of fact. ğŸ“
361.3.
Passive Abilities can be conditional. ğŸ“
361.3.a.
Conditional Passive Abilities can be recognized by the occurrence of "if" or "while" as part of the statement of the ability. Example: "While I'm attacking or defending alone, I have +2 [M]." Example: "If an opponent controls a battleï¬eld, I enter ready." ğŸ“
362.
Presence on Permanents ğŸ“
362.1.
Passive Abilities of Permanents are typically only active while on the Board. ğŸ“
363.
Presence on Card outside of the Board ğŸ“
363.1.
Passive Abilities of cards in zones that are outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The passive ability "Play me only during an opponent's turn." applies in any zone from which that card can be played. ğŸ“
363.2.
Passive Abilities can alter the costs of cards as they are played. ğŸ“
363.2.a.
These apply at all times in any zone from which the card with the ability can be played. ğŸ“
364.
Replacement Effects ğŸ“
365.
An ability that alters the application of another game effect or game rule. ğŸ“
365.1.
Passive Abilities can be Replacement Effects. ğŸ“
366.
Replacement Effects intercede during the execution of a Game Effect and alter its execution. ğŸ“
366.1.
A Replacement Effect can be identiï¬ed by the presence of the term "instead." Example: Zhonya's Hourglass reads "The next time a friendly unit would die, kill this instead. Recall that unit exhausted." This is a replacement effect that alters the execution of any Game Effect that would kill a friendly unit. ğŸ“
367.
A Replacement Effect can alter the typical ï¬‚ow of play, including other cards' executions. ğŸ“
368.
If more than one Replacement Effect applies to the same event being executed, then the owner of the object being acted on determines the order the Replacement Effects will apply. ğŸ“
368.1.
If it is a player being acted on, that player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply. ğŸ“
368.2.
If the affected object is an Uncontrolled Battleï¬eld then the Current Turn Player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply. ğŸ“
369.
Activated Abilities ğŸ“
370.
Activated Abilities are repeatable effects with a cost. They follow a process of going onto the chain and resolving, similar to Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
370.1.
Activated Abilities are recognized by the presence of a ":" in the text of the card, preceded by a cost and succeeded by an effect. Example: "[2]: Draw 1" is an activated ability. The cost is 2 energy. The effect is to draw 1 card. ğŸ“
370.2.
Activated Abilities use the chain. ğŸ“
370.2.a.
Declare activation of the Ability. ğŸ“
370.2.a.1.
The ability goes on the chain but has no card to represent it, so players need to take note that it is now a Closed State. ğŸ“
370.2.b.
Proceed with executing the Chain. ğŸ“
370.2.b.1.
Follow the steps of â€œPlaying or Activating Abilitiesâ€ in rule 386. This ability will become a Pending Chain Item. ğŸ“
370.2.b.2.
Opponents have an opportunity to respond, as appropriate, as if a card was played onto the chain. ğŸ“
370.2.b.3.
If no further action is taken, execute the Activated Ability. ğŸ“
371.
The controlling player chooses when and whether to activate an Activated Ability. ğŸ“
372.
Activated abilities are present on Game Objects and some Spells. ğŸ“
373.
Can primarily be activated while on the Board. ğŸ“
374.
All Activated Abilities can only be activated on the Controlling Player's Turn and during an Open State. ğŸ“
375.
Triggered Abilities ğŸ“
376.
Triggered Abilities are repeatable effects that happen when a Condition is met. ğŸ“
376.1.
Triggered Abilities can usually be recognized by the word "when" followed by a game action or event; the word "at" followed by a point in time during the turn sequence; or the phrase â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ followed by a game action or event. Examples: "When you conquer here, you may spend a buff to draw 1." "At the end of your turn, ready 2 runes." â€œThe ï¬rst time I move each turn, you may ready something else that's exhausted.â€ ğŸ“
376.1.a.
The phrases that identify triggered abilities do not always appear at the beginning of sentences or abilities. ğŸ“
376.1.b.
If an ability triggers â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ something happens and that trigger condition is met multiple times simultaneously, the abilityâ€™s controller picks one of those instances to serve as the trigger condition. The ability triggers only once, due to the chosen condition. Example: Wraith of Echoes reads â€œThe ï¬rst time another friendly unit dies each turn, draw 1.â€ That ability hasnâ€™t triggered yet this turn. Two other friendly units die simultaneously (say, due to combat damage). The Wraithâ€™s controller chooses one of those deaths to trigger Wraithâ€™s ability. ğŸ“
376.2.
Triggered Abilities have a Condition and an Effect. ğŸ“
376.2.a.
The Condition follows the When. ğŸ“
376.2.b.
The Effect is the Instruction that follows the comma after the Condition. ğŸ“
376.2.c.
The Condition of a Trigger is evaluated after a potentially inciting event has been processed. ğŸ“
376.2.c.1.
If a Game Object with a Triggered Ability that is active in a speciï¬c zone, it is evaluated and subsequently triggered if it enters that zone at the same time that its Triggerâ€™s condition is met. Example: Immortal Phoenix says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ This ability triggers if Immortal Phoenix is in your trash immediately after you kill a unit with a spell, even if the unit you killed with a spell was that Immortal Phoenix. ğŸ“
376.2.c.2.
A Game Object will not be able to successfully be able to evaluate its Trigger Condition, however, if it leaves the zone that its Trigger is active from at the same time that its Trigger is satisï¬ed. Example: Viktor, Leader says â€œWhen another non-Recruit unit you control dies, play a 1 [M] Recruit unit token into your base.â€ This ability triggers if Viktor is on the board immediately after another non-Recruit unit you control dies. It does not trigger if Viktor and another non-Recruit unit you control die during the same game action (for instance, if they are both killed in the same Cleanup due to the damage dealt by Unchecked Power). ğŸ“
376.3.
When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain. ğŸ“
376.3.a.
Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn. ğŸ“
376.3.b.
If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain. ğŸ“
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain. ğŸ“
376.4.
Some Conditions are commonly used and structured in a way that explicitly deï¬nes their use and other properties of the Effect that is associated with it. ğŸ“
376.4.a.
Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board. ğŸ“
376.4.a.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen you play meâ€¦â€ for Units and â€œWhen you play thisâ€¦â€ for Gear. ğŸ“
376.4.a.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ï¬nalized and enters the board. ğŸ“
376.4.a.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Play Effects. ğŸ“
376.4.a.4.
Abilities that trigger when another object is played are not considered Play Effects. ğŸ“
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
376.4.b.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen I conquerâ€¦â€ and â€œWhen you conquerâ€¦â€ ğŸ“
376.4.b.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action. ğŸ“
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering. ğŸ“
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point. ğŸ“
376.4.b.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Conquering is negated or replaced in any way, the Conquer Effect will still trigger. ğŸ“
376.4.b.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Conquer Effects. ğŸ“
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding. ğŸ“
376.4.c.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen I holdâ€¦â€ or â€œWhen you holdâ€¦â€ ğŸ“
376.4.c.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action. ğŸ“
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding. ğŸ“
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point. ğŸ“
376.4.c.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Holding is negated or replaced in any way, the Hold Effect will still trigger. ğŸ“
376.4.c.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Hold Effects. ğŸ“
376.4.d.
Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat. ğŸ“
376.4.d.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen I attackâ€¦â€ ğŸ“
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat. ğŸ“
376.4.d.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Attacker designation multiple times in the same combat. ğŸ“
376.4.d.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Attack Triggers. ğŸ“
376.4.e.
Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat. ğŸ“
376.4.e.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen I defendâ€¦â€ ğŸ“
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat. ğŸ“
376.4.e.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Defender designation multiple times in the same combat. ğŸ“
376.4.e.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Defend Triggers. ğŸ“
377.
Presence on Permanents ğŸ“
377.1.
Typically active while on the Board. ğŸ“
377.2.
Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board. ğŸ“
378.
Presence on Cards outside of the Board ğŸ“
378.1.
Triggered Abilities on cards outside of the Board rely on the Information Level of the zone they are in. ğŸ“
378.2.
Triggered Abilities outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The triggered ability "When you conquer, you may discard 1 to return this from your trash to your hand." triggers while the card it's on is in the trash, and not anywhere else. ğŸ“
379.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers ğŸ“
380.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers are a type of Triggered Ability that create one or more Chain Items when their condition is met. ğŸ“
380.1.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers can be recognized by the phrase â€œDo this:â€ or â€œDo one of the following:â€. ğŸ“
380.1.a.
â€œDo thisâ€ can be followed by â€œN times.â€ The Reï¬‚exive Trigger will thus be added to the chain N times when its condition is met. ğŸ“
380.2.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers will be preceded by their conditions, if any. If no condition is present in the ability then the Reï¬‚exive Trigger will always be added to the Chain. ğŸ“
380.3.
If present, the Condition of a Reï¬‚exive Trigger will follow the same format as a Triggered Ability. ğŸ“
381.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers use the Chain. ğŸ“
381.1.
A new ability is created and added to the chain as a Pending Item. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
381.2.
If a Reï¬‚exive Trigger creates more than one Pending Item it creates them all in order, but does not go beyond the ï¬rst step of adding them to the Chain. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
382.
Delayed Abilities ğŸ“
383.
Delayed Abilities are a type of Ability whose trigger Condition identiï¬es a speciï¬c time during a turn or a speciï¬c event that can occur during a speciï¬c timeframe. ğŸ“
383.1.
Delayed Abilities can be any other type of Ability, and contain all of the properties of that type in addition to the properties of Delayed Abilities. ğŸ“
383.2.
Delayed Triggers are Triggered Abilities that can be recognized by describing a speciï¬c time of the turn, or by structuring a Triggered Ability with a speciï¬c frame of time as a restriction. ğŸ“
383.3.
Delayed Replacements are Replacement Effects that can be recognized by specifying the effect they are replacing at a speciï¬c time, or â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ in the description of the effect as it resolves. ğŸ“
383.4.
Delayed Passive Abilities are Passive Abilities that are applicable only during a speciï¬ed window of time. The time that the Delayed Passive Ability applies will be recognized in the effect that initiates it. ğŸ“
384.
Delayed Abilities will resolve or be active just like the ability they augment, but only during the speciï¬ed time in the effect that created the Delayed Ability. Example: Ravenborn Tome reads â€œThe next spell you play this turn deals 1 Bonus Damageâ€ is a Delayed Passive Ability that passively adds 1 damage to just the next spell played. The next spell is a speciï¬c time, and the 1 Bonus Damage is a passive ability. Example: Noxian Guillotine reads â€œChoose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn.â€ When the chosen unit takes damage is the speciï¬ed time, and killing it is the condition for a Delayed Triggered Ability. ğŸ“
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not. ğŸ“
386.
Playing or Activating Abilities ğŸ“
387.
Playing or activating Abilities follows the same steps of playing cards. ğŸ“
388.
Abilities when added to the Chain become Pending Items until they complete the steps of Playing. ğŸ“
388.1.
When an Ability ï¬nishes the steps of playing it becomes a Chain Item just like a Spell. ğŸ“
388.2.
When an Ability with the [Add] action is ï¬nalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item, like a Unit or Gear. ğŸ“
389.
1. Activate or trigger the Ability ğŸ“
389.1.
Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
389.2.
If there is currently a game effect being resolved, continue resolving the game effect instead of continuing the following steps. ğŸ“
390.
2. Make relevant choices ğŸ“
390.1.
Make all choices required for this ability, such as targets, options, or other relevant decisions. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information ğŸ“
390.2.
If legal options are not available for an Activated Ability, it is not legal to activate it. ğŸ“
390.3.
If there are not enough options to make legal choices for a Triggered Ability that has been put on the chain, remove it from the Chain now. It ceases to be a Pending Item but never becomes a Chain Item. ğŸ“
390.3.a.
This is not an Ability being countered. ğŸ“
390.3.b.
If there are legal options to choose, the abilityâ€™s controller must choose them. They may not decline this stage of playing a Trigger. ğŸ“
391.
3. Determine Total Cost ğŸ“
391.1.
Determine the base cost of the Ability. ğŸ“
391.1.a.
Activated Abilities will have a cost listed before the â€œ:â€ in their text. ğŸ“
391.1.b.
Triggered Abilities will typically not have a base cost associated with them when placed on the chain due to their conditions. ğŸ“
391.2.
Apply cost increases and decreases as a result of choices made in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
391.3.
Apply any other cost increases or decreases as necessary. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
392.
4. Pay Costs ğŸ“
392.1.
Pay costs as determined in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
392.2.
At this stage, players may decline to pay for Triggered Abilities that have incurred a cost. If they do, the ability will cease being a Pending Item and be removed from the Chain. It never becomes a Chain Item. ğŸ“
392.2.a.
This is not an Ability being countered. ğŸ“
393.
5. Check Legality ğŸ“
393.1.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s targets are still legal. ğŸ“
393.2.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s effect would not create an illegal state. If it would, resolve in the same way you would resolve a Card that creates an illegal state. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
394.
6. Proceed with Play ğŸ“
394.1.
This Ability is no longer Pending. ğŸ“
394.2.
This Ability becomes a Chain Item. ğŸ“
394.3.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, their controllers perform the remaining steps of playing now. ğŸ“
394.4.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information. ğŸ“
394.5.
Otherwise, execute the Ability just like a Spell, then clear the Chain Item from the Chain. ğŸ“
395.
Game Actions ğŸ“
396.
Game Actions are actions players may perform at any given time during the game. ğŸ“
397.
A player, unless otherwise speciï¬ed or prompted, may only perform actions on their turn. ğŸ“
398.
There are two types of Game Actions: ğŸ“
398.1.
Discretionary Actions ğŸ“
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information. ğŸ“
398.1.b.
A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions available to them during their turn. ğŸ“
398.1.b.1.
As long as any conditions, if applicable, are met. ğŸ“
398.1.b.2.
As long as any costs, if applicable, are paid. ğŸ“
398.1.b.3.
As long as it does not result in any forbidden action being taken or game state being created. Example: A player can't use the Standard Move discretionary action to move a unit to a Battleï¬eld that's already occupied by Units controlled by two other players. ğŸ“
398.2.
Limited Actions ğŸ“
398.2.a.
A Limited Action is a game action that a spell, ability, or circumstance of the turn's progression causes the player to perform. A player cannot perform these actions at-will. ğŸ“
398.2.b.
These actions can only be taken when a player is instructed to do so as the execution of an effect or during their speciï¬ed occasion during the turn. Example: A player may Draw during the Draw Step of the Beginning Phase of their turn or when instructed to do so by a spell or ability. They can't choose to Draw at any other time. ğŸ“
399.
Types of Actions ğŸ“
400.
Draw ğŸ“
400.1.
Drawing a card takes a single card from the top of the Main Deck and adds it to the player's Hand. ğŸ“
400.2.
This is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
400.2.a.
Each player draws 1 during the Draw Step of their Beginning Phase. ğŸ“
400.2.b.
The player may draw cards when instructed to do so by other game effects. ğŸ“
400.3.
This action, when instructed, is formatted as "Draw X." ğŸ“
400.4.
If a player attempts to draw more cards than are available in their Main Deck, they do the following: ğŸ“
400.4.a.
Draw as many as possible. ğŸ“
400.4.b.
Perform a Burn Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information. ğŸ“
400.4.c.
Draw the remaining cards needed to complete the Draw action. ğŸ“
401.
Exhaust ğŸ“
401.1.
Exhausting is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as "spent." ğŸ“
401.1.a.
To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Readying, so that the orientation of the card is lengthwise in front of you. ğŸ“
401.1.b.
A Unit that is already Exhausted cannot be Exhausted again. ğŸ“
401.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Exhausted while it is already Exhausted, nothing additional happens. ğŸ“
401.2.
"Exhausted" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference. ğŸ“
401.3.
This is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
401.3.a.
Most Exhaust actions will be costs for Activated Abilities or Discretionary Actions. Example: A unit's Standard Move exhausts the unit as a cost. ğŸ“
401.4.
When Exhausting is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A spell says "As an additional cost to play this, you may exhaust a friendly unit." An exhausted friendly unit may not be exhausted again as the additional cost for the spell, and the additional cost has not been paid. ğŸ“
401.5.
In abilities, the Exhaust symbol represents the cost "Exhaust this" or "Exhaust me." It resembles a card turning sideways. ğŸ“
402.
Ready ğŸ“
402.1.
Readying is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as available for action. ğŸ“
402.1.a.
To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Exhausting, so that it is vertically oriented in front of you. ğŸ“
402.1.b.
A Unit that is already Ready cannot be Readied again. ğŸ“
402.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Readied while it is already Ready, nothing additional happens. ğŸ“
402.2.
"Ready" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference. ğŸ“
402.3.
This is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
402.3.a.
A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn. ğŸ“
402.3.b.
The player may also Ready their Game Objects when effects or spells instruct them to do so. ğŸ“
403.
Recycle ğŸ“
403.1.
Recycling cards is the action in which a player takes one or more cards from a speciï¬c zone and then puts it on the bottom of the corresponding deck. ğŸ“
403.1.a.
Main Deck cards are Recycled to the Main Deck. ğŸ“
403.1.b.
Runes are Recycled to the Rune Deck. ğŸ“
403.1.c.
Each player Recycles cards to their own Main Deck and Rune Deck, regardless of which player is instructed to perform the Recycle action. ğŸ“
403.2.
This is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
403.2.a.
The player must Recycle cards from the speciï¬ed zones when instructed to do so by game effects or costs. ğŸ“
403.3.
When Recycling is listed as a Cost, the action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: Vi, Destructive has the ability "Recycle 1 from your trash: Give me +1 [M] this turn." Each time a player activates the ability, they must recycle 1 card from their trash to pay its cost. If they have no cards in their trash, they can't activate the ability, because they can't pay its cost. ğŸ“
403.4.
When Recycling is part of an effect, a player must Recycle as many cards as possible from the speciï¬ed zone or zones. ğŸ“
403.5.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Main Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in a random order. Example: Garbage Grabber has the ability "Recycle 3 from your trash, [1], [E]: Draw " To pay the cost of activating this ability, its controller chooses 3 cards from their trash and places them on the bottom of their Main Deck in a random order. ğŸ“
403.5.a.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Rune Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in the order of their owner's choosing. ğŸ“
403.6.
This action, when instructed, is sometimes formatted as "Recycle X from [Zone]." That means to take X cards of the instructed player's choice from the relevant zone and recycle them. Example: Dr. Mundo, Expert has the ability "At the start of your Beginning Phase, recycle 3 from your trash." As that ability resolves, its controller recycles 3 cards from their trash. If there are fewer than 3 cards in that player's trash, they recycle as many as they can. ğŸ“
404.
Deal ğŸ“
404.1.
Spells, Units, Abilities, and other game effects may Deal Damage to units. ğŸ“
404.1.a.
Assigning Damage during Combat Resolution is not Dealing Damage, but will cause Damage to be Dealt when assignment is complete. ğŸ“
404.1.b.
To Deal Damage to Units, mark the speciï¬ed amount of Damage on the Unit. ğŸ“
404.1.c.
Damage is marked on each unit separately. ğŸ“
404.1.d.
Damage can be Dealt to more than one Unit at the same time. ğŸ“
404.2.
Only Damage can be Dealt. ğŸ“
404.3.
Dealing Damage is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
404.3.a.
Assigning Damage causes Damage to be dealt outside of being directed to Deal Damage. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
404.4.
Dealing can have the intrinsic property of Bonus Damage. ğŸ“
404.5.
Bonus Damage is a property granted to the action of Dealing and alters the amount of Damage distributed by this action. See rule 712. Bonus Damage for more information. ğŸ“
404.6.
Deal actions can originate from one or more sources. ğŸ“
404.6.a.
If a game effect does not specify a source, the game effect describing the Deal action is the source. Example: Void Seeker is a spell that reads â€œDeal 4 to a unit at a battleï¬eld. Draw 1.â€ The damage that Void Seeker instructs you to deal is dealt by Void Seeker. ğŸ“
404.6.b.
If a game effect does specify a source, then that source is what is considered the origin of the Damage for this Deal action. ğŸ“
404.6.b.1.
Units and Spells can be the source of Damage for Deal actions. ğŸ“
404.6.b.2.
Abilities can be the source of Damage for Deal actions. ğŸ“
404.6.b.2.a.
When an Ability is the source of Damage for a Deal action, it is in addition to the Spell or Unit that created that Ability. Example: Iron Ballista is a gear that says â€œ[E]: Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld.â€ This damage is dealt both by a gear and by an ability. ğŸ“
404.6.b.3.
When a spell or ability speciï¬es a Unit as the source of the Damage for the Deal action, it is not in addition to the spell or ability that speciï¬ed it. Example: Challenge is a spell that reads â€œChoose a friendly unit and an enemy unit. They deal damage equal to their Mights to each other.â€ The damage that Challenge causes to be dealt is dealt by the chosen units, not by Challenge. ğŸ“
404.6.c.
Damage Dealt as a result of being assigned during Combat has the Units as its source. ğŸ“
404.6.c.1.
The Damage assigned, and subsequently Dealt, to attackers has the defenders as the source and vice versa. ğŸ“
404.7.
Deal actions can distribute Damage as part of combat actions or non-combat actions. ğŸ“
405.
Heal ğŸ“
405.1.
Damage being cleared from Units is Healing. ğŸ“
405.1.a.
If Damage is cleared for any reason it is considered Healing. ğŸ“
405.2.
More than one Unit can be Healed at the same time. ğŸ“
405.3.
Healing is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
405.3.a.
Players may only Heal units when game effects instruct them to, or at speciï¬c points in the turn. ğŸ“
406.
Play ğŸ“
406.1.
A player Plays cards by paying costs associated with that card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
406.2.
This is a Discretionary Action. ğŸ“
406.2.a.
As long as a player has the resources to pay the costs associated with the card, they may play cards. ğŸ“
406.3.
Game effects may result in cards being played as part of their resolution. ğŸ“
406.3.a.
This treats Play as a Limited Action. ğŸ“
406.3.b.
Treat all steps of Play as normal, except as noted by the game effect creating this Limited Play Effect. ğŸ“
406.3.c.
If there are no eligible cards to Play when instructed to Play in this manner like this, then nothing happens and resolution continues. ğŸ“
406.4.
Some Abilities trigger when cards are played or otherwise check whether cards have been played. ğŸ“
406.4.a.
These abilities trigger when the act of playing the card has been completed by the resolution of the card. ğŸ“
406.4.b.
If a game effect prevents the resolution of the cardâ€”for example, because the card was counteredâ€”the card wasn't played and no abilities that trigger on playing cards trigger. See rule 412. Counter for more information. ğŸ“
407.
Move ğŸ“
407.1.
Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board. ğŸ“
407.2.
Moving is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
407.2.a.
Players may only move Game Objects when instructed to do so by Game Effects or costs. ğŸ“
407.2.b.
The Standard Move inherent to Units may also cause Movement. See rule 142for more information on the Standard Move. ğŸ“
407.3.
The Standard Move inherent to Units is a Discretionary Action. ğŸ“
407.3.a.
The Cost is Exhausting one or more Units. ğŸ“
407.3.b.
The Effect is Moving those Unit. ğŸ“
408.
Hide ğŸ“
408.1.
Hiding a card is the act of placing a card facedown at a Battleï¬eld you control. ğŸ“
408.2.
Hiding is a Discretionary Action. ğŸ“
408.2.a.
The Hidden keyword allows a player to pay a cost to Hide a card any time they have a Hidden card in their hand or Champion Zone and meet the prerequisites. See rule 737. Hidden for more information. ğŸ“
408.3.
Cards that are facedown at Battleï¬elds have their gameplay properties and permissions deï¬ned by the effect that put them there. Example: Cards that players Hide with the Hidden keyword can be Played for [0] on any subsequent turn as a property of the Hidden keyword. ğŸ“
408.4.
If a facedown card would be put into a zone whose Privacy is Private or Secret, or if the game ends, its owner reveals it to all players. See rule 127. Privacy for more information. ğŸ“
409.
Discard ğŸ“
409.1.
Discarding a card is moving it from a player's hand directly into their trash without activating or executing its normal rules text. ğŸ“
409.1.a.
The player who is performing the action chooses which cards to send to their Trash, and may use Private Information to do so. ğŸ“
409.1.b.
â€œWhen I am discardedâ€ abilities or other Triggered Abilities that trigger on discarding are executed after discarding has occurred. ğŸ“
409.2.
Discarding is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
409.2.a.
A player must Discard cards when instructed to do so by game effects or costs. ğŸ“
409.3.
When Discarding is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A card has the ability "Discard 2: Deal 2 damage to a unit at a battleï¬eld." To activate the ability, the card's controller must have at least 2 cards in hand and must be able to discard them. ğŸ“
409.4.
When Discarding is part of an effect, then a player must Discard as many cards as possible from their hand. If instructed to discard more cards than they have in their hand, further discard instructions are ignored. Example: Undercover Agent has the ability "[Deathknell] â€” Discard 2, then draw 2. (When I die, get the effect.)" If Undercover Agent's controller has 2 or more cards in hand, they must discard 2. If they have 1 card in hand, they discard 1, and the rest of the discard instruction is ignored. If they have no cards in hand, the entire discard instruction is ignored. Regardless of how many cards they discard, they then draw 2. ğŸ“
409.5.
This action is formatted as "Discard X." ğŸ“
410.
Stun ğŸ“
410.1.
Stunning is the act of selecting one or more Units on the Board and rendering them Stunned. ğŸ“
410.1.a.
Stunned is a binary state. A Unit is Stunned or it isn't. ğŸ“
410.1.a.1.
A Stunned Unit can not be Stunned again. Example: Eclipse Herald has the ability "When you stun an enemy unit, ready me and give me +1 [M] this turn." Its controller plays a spell that reads "Stun a unit." They may choose a unit that's already stunned, but if they do, Eclipse Herald will not trigger. ğŸ“
410.1.a.2.
Stunned Units lose the Stunned status at the beginning of the next Ending Step. ğŸ“
410.1.b.
A Stunned Unit does not contribute its might to damage in combat. ğŸ“
410.1.c.
A Stunned Unit must still have damage applied to it equal to, or greater than, its full might value to be killed. ğŸ“
410.2.
Stunning is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
410.2.a.
Players may only Stun Units when directed to by Game Effects. ğŸ“
411.
Reveal ğŸ“
411.1.
Revealing is the act of presenting a card to all players from a zone that one or more players do not have access to the information of. ğŸ“
411.1.a.
Revealed is a temporary state and is not a zone. ğŸ“
411.1.a.1.
Other cards, including the card being revealed, can reference the act of being Revealed. ğŸ“
411.1.a.2.
Cards remain in the zone they are being Revealed from. Example: If a card is being Revealed from the top of a player's Main Deck, it is still the top card of that player's Main Deck. ğŸ“
411.1.b.
Unless otherwise described, Revealed cards do nothing else beyond become temporarily known information to all players. ğŸ“
411.2.
Revealing is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
411.2.a.
Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects. ğŸ“
411.2.b.
During the course of a game of Riftbound, a player may choose to show Private information to one or more other players. This does not count as revealing and does not trigger any effects that trigger when cards are revealed. ğŸ“
411.3.
This action is formatted as "Reveal cards from [zone]." Example: "Reveal 2 cards from the top of your Main Deck" would be executed by taking the two cards from the top of your Main Deck, and then presenting them to all players to clearly read and understand at the table. Then, when all players have had a chance to understand the revealed information, return them to the top of the deck in the same order. ğŸ“
411.4.
Game Effects can manipulate or modify the cards Revealed while they are Revealed ğŸ“
411.4.a.
While cards are Revealed, those cards can be further manipulated, or accessed. They can even have their destination modiï¬ed for when the Reveal ends. Example: "Reveal 2 cards from the top of your Main Deck. Put one into your hand and Recycle the other" would be executed by taking the top two cards from your Main Deck to the table, and once every player present has had a chance to understand them you would make the selection of one of them to add to your hand. The one you did not select would then be Recycled to the bottom of the Main Deck. ğŸ“
412.
Counter ğŸ“
412.1.
Countering is the act of negating the execution, activation, or otherwise playing of a card by a player. ğŸ“
412.1.a.
A card that is Countered does nothing and is then placed in the Trash. ğŸ“
412.1.b.
A card that is Countered is not considered to have been played. ğŸ“
412.1.c.
Countering does not refund any costs paid to play a card. ğŸ“
412.1.c.1.
This includes additional costs. ğŸ“
412.2.
Countering is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
412.2.a.
Players may only Counter cards when directed to by Game Effects. ğŸ“
412.3.
This action is formatted as "Counter [a card or ability on the chain]." ğŸ“
413.
Buff ğŸ“
413.1.
Bufï¬ng is the action of placing a Buff counter on a Unit. See rule 701. Buffs for more information. ğŸ“
413.1.a.
A Buff is also an object. ğŸ“
413.1.b.
To Buff a unit, place a Buff Counter on it if it does not have one already ğŸ“
413.1.b.1.
If the unit already has a Buff Counter on it, it does not get another one. ğŸ“
413.1.c.
Units with Buff Counters can still be chosen for actions that Buff units, but will not be Buffed as part of the execution. Example: A spell reads "Buff a unit. Then, if it was buffed this way, draw a card." It will place a buff counter on a unit that has no buff counter, and then its controller will draw a card. However, if the player chooses a unit with a buff counter on it already, then the card will not be drawn. ğŸ“
413.2.
Bufï¬ng is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
413.2.a.
Players may only Buff units when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
413.3.
This action is formatted as "Buff [one or more units]." e.g., "Buff a unit." e.g., "Buff a friendly unit." e.g., "Buff two friendly units at the same battleï¬eld." ğŸ“
414.
Banish ğŸ“
414.1.
Banishing is the action of placing a card from any zone to Banishment. See rule 107.5. Banishment for more information. ğŸ“
414.2.
When a card is Banished it is placed directly into the Banishment zone from its origin. ğŸ“
414.2.a.
Banish is not a subset of Kill. ğŸ“
414.2.b.
Banish is not a subset of Discard. ğŸ“
414.3.
Cards and effects can refer to cards that were banished by the same object. ğŸ“
414.3.a.
Separate instances of an object or effect banishing cards do not reference other banished cards by objects of the same name or effects originating from cards of the same name. Example: A spell reads "Banish the top card of your Main Deck. When you conquer this turn, draw it." This card effect allows you to draw the banished card from banishment if a condition is met. If more than one of these effects is played, each one triggers separately. Each card will be drawn separately. If the turn player passes the turn without playing the card, the card remains in banishment indeï¬nitely. If the same player plays another copy of the same spell, banishes another card, and satisï¬es its condition, they could play the new banished card, but not the original banished card. ğŸ“
414.4.
Banishing is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
414.4.a.
Players may only Banish cards or permanents when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
414.5.
This action is formatted as "Banish [one or more permanents or cards]." e.g., "Banish a card from your hand." e.g., "Banish 2 cards from your trash." e.g., "Look at the top 2 cards of your Main Deck. Draw one of them and banish the other." ğŸ“
415.
Kill ğŸ“
415.1.
Killing is the action of a Permanent going to the trash from the board. ğŸ“
415.1.a.
This can be Active or Passive. ğŸ“
415.1.a.1.
Active Kill is when the action is taken when instructed by a game effect or as a cost for a card or ability. ğŸ“
415.1.a.1.a.
This is referred to as a Kill Instruction. ğŸ“
415.1.a.1.b.
When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction, it ï¬rst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unitâ€™s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ï¬nalized before completing this Kill Instruction. ğŸ“
415.1.a.2.
Passive Kill is when the action is taken as a result of Lethal Damage or as a consequence for any other state. ğŸ“
415.2.
When a permanent is killed it is placed directly in the trash from its place of origin. ğŸ“
415.2.a.
It is only considered Killed if its origin was any zone on the board. ğŸ“
415.2.b.
This is not a subset of Move. ğŸ“
415.3.
Killing is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
415.3.a.
Players may only Kill units when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
415.4.
Killing can also be the result of resolving a Cleanup. ğŸ“
415.5.
Killing can be attributed to one or more Game Objects. ğŸ“
415.5.a.
The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object. ğŸ“
415.5.b.
A spell or ability that contains a Kill instruction is responsible for Killing the Unit or Gear. ğŸ“
415.5.c.
When one or more Units is killed due to a Cleanup, the spell or ability that resolved immediately prior to that Cleanup that applied damage to the Unit or Units is responsible for that Kill action. ğŸ“
415.5.d.
Abilities originating from Game Objects that are responsible for Kill Actions are responsible in addition to the Game Object that created them. Example: Falling Star is a spell that says â€œDo this twice: Deal 3 to a unit.â€ Immortal Phoenix is a unit that says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ A player plays Falling Star while Immortal Phoenix is in their trash. The â€œdo thisâ€ phrasing on Falling Star means that it has a reï¬‚exive triggered ability, which places two triggered abilities on the chain. As each of those triggered abilities resolve, it deals damage to the unit chosen for that ability. If one of these abilities deals lethal damage to a unit, both Falling Star and its ability are considered sources of the damage, and so both Falling Star and its ability are responsible for killing the unit. This means that Falling Starâ€™s controller killed a unit with a spell, so Immortal Phoenixâ€™s ability will trigger. ğŸ“
415.6.
This action is formatted as "Kill [one or more permanents]." e.g., "Kill an enemy unit." e.g., "Kill this, [2]: Draw 1." e.g., "Kill all gear." ğŸ“
416.
Add ğŸ“
416.1.
Adding is the action of putting resources into a player's Rune Pool. ğŸ“
416.2.
Spells, triggered abilities, and activated abilities that Add resources ï¬nalize immediately. ğŸ“
416.2.a.
Priority and Focus will not pass from Add abilities being ï¬nalized, and will resolve before any other outstanding items on the chain are ï¬nalized. ğŸ“
416.3.
Activated abilities that Add resources and have the Reaction tag can be activated during the playing or resolution of other spells and abilities, any time that those spells or abilities require that resources be paid. Example: A player can add Energy and Power through any means before initiating the process of playing a spell. After initiating that process, in the Pay Costs step, they may activate Add Reactions to add Energy or Power to pay costs. ğŸ“
416.4.
Adding is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
416.4.a.
Players may only Add resources when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
416.5.
This action is formatted as "Add [one or more resources]." e.g., "Add [2]." means "Add 2 Energy." e.g., "[E]: Add [Y]." means "Add 1 Power of the Order domain." e.g., "Add [1][G]." means "Add 1 Energy and 1 Power of the Calm domain." ğŸ“
417.
Channel ğŸ“
417.1.
Channeling is the action of taking one or more Runes from the top of a player's Rune Deck and putting them on the board. ğŸ“
417.2.
The Game Effect that instructs a player to channel 1 or more runes may specify the conditions or circumstances under which those runes enter the board. Example: A spell reads "Channel 1 rune exhausted." As that spell resolves, its controller puts the top rune of their rune deck onto the board and that rune enters the board exhausted rather than ready. ğŸ“
417.3.
Channeling is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
417.3.a.
Players may only channel runes when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
417.4.
This action is formatted as "Channel X rune(s)," optionally followed by conditions or stipulations. e.g., "Channel 1 rune." e.g., "When you play me, channel 1 rune exhausted." e.g., "Channel 2 runes exhausted. If you couldn't channel 2 runes this way, draw 1." ğŸ“
418.
Burn Out ğŸ“
418.1.
Burning Out is an action a player must perform if they attempt to move one or more cards from their Main Deck to any other zone in excess of the number of cards remaining in their Main Deck: ğŸ“
418.1.a.
If a player must Draw cards in excess to the number of cards in their deck, they will Draw as many as possible, perform this action, then Draw the remaining amount instructed. ğŸ“
418.1.b.
If a player must put one or more cards from their Main Deck in any other zone, such as the Trash, in excess of the number of cards in their deck they will do so as much as possible, perform this action, and then complete the remaining number required by the instruction. ğŸ“
418.1.c.
If an instruction directs a player to look at or reveal cards in excess to the number of cards in a playerâ€™s Main Deck, that player looks at or Reveals as many as possible, but does not Burn Out, then proceeds with the rest of the instruction. ğŸ“
418.1.c.1.
If there are insufï¬cient cards among the looked at or revealed cards to perform subsequent actions to the revealed or looked at cards, any further instructions are ignored. This does not cause a Burn Out, even if those instructions would cause those cards to change zones. Reminder: Cards are considered in the zone of origin while being looked at or revealed, in this case the Main Deck. ğŸ“
418.2.
To Burn Out, a player does the following in sequence: ğŸ“
418.2.a.
Performs as much of the prescribed action as possible. ğŸ“
418.2.b.
Recycles their trash into their Main Deck. Reminder: When multiple cards are Recycled to the Main Deck at the same time, those cards must be randomized ğŸ“
418.2.c.
Chooses an opponent to gain 1 point. ğŸ“
418.2.d.
Completes the remainder of the action that caused them to burn out. Example: A player attempts to draw 1 during their Draw Phase while their Main Deck is empty. That player instead recycles their trash into their Main Deck, randomizing it as normal, then chooses an opponent to gain 1 point, and then draws 1. ğŸ“
418.3.
A player's Main Deck may remain empty as they Burn Out, usually because their trash is also empty. When they attempt to perform the original action again, it will cause another Burn Out. ğŸ“
418.3.a.
Unless some effect intervenes, this will result in them burning out repeatedly, giving 1 point to an opponent each time, until an opponent passes the Victory Score and wins the game. ğŸ“
418.4.
Burning Out is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
418.4.a.
Players may only burn out when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
418.5.
Burning Out is a Replacement Effect. See rule 364. Replacement Effects for more information. ğŸ“
419.
Double ğŸ“
419.1.
Doubling is the act of increasing a numeric attribute by an amount equal to that attributeâ€™s current value. ğŸ“
419.1.a.
This creates an effect that modulates that attribute by that speciï¬c amount for the duration speciï¬ed by the Game Effect that instructed the player to perform this action. Example: A unit with 3 base Might and Shield 2 is in combat as a Defender. Since Shield applies, its current Might is 5. A player chooses it as the target for Last Stand, a spell that reads in part â€œDouble a friendly unit's Might this turn.â€ Its current Might is 5, so it gets +5 Might this turn, for a current Might of 10. After combat, Shield no longer applies, but the +5 Might from Last Stand does, so the unitâ€™s Might is 8. ğŸ“
419.2
Doubling is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
419.2.a.
Players may only Double when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
420.
Swap ğŸ“
420.1.
Swapping is the act of increasing one numeric value and decreasing another numeric value on some number of Game Objects such that their values are reversed. ğŸ“
420.1.a.
Swapping creates two different effects that apply to each attribute. One that Increases one value and one that Decreases the other. ğŸ“
420.1.b.
To accomplish this, determine the difference between these values and then apply an Increase for that amount to the lower value of the two attributes, and a Decrease of that amount to the higher value of the two attributes. ğŸ“
420.1.c
If both attributes are the same numeric value, Swapping has no effect. ğŸ“
420.2.
Swapping is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
420.2.a
Players may only swap when Game Effects direct them to do so. ğŸ“
421.
Attach ğŸ“
421.1.
Attaching is the act of linking two cards on the board together to combine their effects in some way. This causes one or more cards to become Attached and at least one card to become a Top-Most Card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
421.1.a.
Attaching affects two cards at once. ğŸ“
421.1.a.1.
One card will be designated as the one being Attached, and thus become Attached. The other will become the Top-Most Card. ğŸ“
421.1.b.
This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached. ğŸ“
421.1.b.1.
In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card, they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects. ğŸ“
421.1.c.
The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text. ğŸ“
421.1.d.
The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it. ğŸ“
421.1.e.
Attaching one or more cards will cause those cardsâ€™ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
421.1.f.
Attaching a card will cause it to Detach from any card to which it is currently Attached. ğŸ“
421.2.
Attaching is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
421.2.a.
Players may only Attach cards when directed to by Game Effects. ğŸ“
421.3.
Attaching cards does not inherently choose or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Attach cards may do so. ğŸ“
421.4.
When a card Attaches to a card, its location becomes the same as the new Top-Most Card. ğŸ“
421.4.a.
This is not a Move. ğŸ“
422.
Detach ğŸ“
422.1.
Detaching is the act of unlinking two cards that are currently linked through the act of Attaching. This causes one to cease being Attached, and potentially causes the other to cease being a Top-Most card. ğŸ“
422.1.a.
Detaching affects only cards that are currently Attached to another card. ğŸ“
422.1.a.1.
Game effects that instruct a player to Detach a card that is currently not Attached to anything will do nothing. ğŸ“
422.1.b.
When one or more cards become Detached, they cease to be in the Attached state. ğŸ“
422.1.b.1.
To represent this, these cards should no longer be placed under the card they were previously placed under as Top-Most Card. ğŸ“
422.1.b.2.
If the Top-Most Card no longer has any cards Attached to it after this, it is no longer a Top-Most Card. ğŸ“
422.1.c.
The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive. ğŸ“
422.1.d.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text. ğŸ“
422.1.e.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached. ğŸ“
422.2.
Detaching is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
422.2.a.
Players may only Detach cards when directed to by Game Effects. ğŸ“
422.3.
Detaching cards does not inherently choose, or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Detach cards may. ğŸ“
422.4.
When a card Detaches from a Top-Most Card, its location is the same as the Top-Most Card from which it Detached. ğŸ“
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup. ğŸ“
422.4.b.
If the Attached card was Detached because the Top-Most Card changed zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, then the location that the Attached Card will Detach to is the last location the Top-Most Card was at before changing from a board zone to a non-board zone. ğŸ“
423.
Movement ğŸ“
424.
Moving is a Limited Action. ğŸ“
424.1.
A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move, unless it is caused by a corrective Recall. See rule 407. Move for more information. ğŸ“
424.2.
A card changing game zones does not in itself constitute a Move. ğŸ“
424.3.
Moving is instantaneous. ğŸ“
424.3.a.
There is no state for Permanents between locations. ğŸ“
424.3.b.
Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving. ğŸ“
424.3.c.
Moving does not use the Chain, nor is it able to be Reacted to. ğŸ“
425.
Moving is deï¬ned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations. ğŸ“
425.1.
The Origin is where the Permanent is starting from. ğŸ“
425.2.
The Destination is where the Permanent is going to. ğŸ“
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information. ğŸ“
425.3.
Units are the only Permanents that can Move. ğŸ“
426.
Players may choose to move their Units with the Standard Move. See rule 142.for more information on the Standard Move. ğŸ“
427.
Spells, Abilities, or other effects may cause a Move to occur. ğŸ“
427.1.
The source of the Move will provide details on any restrictions on legality for Destination. ğŸ“
427.2.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present by any means. ğŸ“
428.
The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleï¬eld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved. ğŸ“
429.
Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move. ğŸ“
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved. ğŸ“
430.
Units may cause Combat when they Move. ğŸ“
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
431.
When a Move action is complete, perform a Cleanup. ğŸ“
432.
Recalls ğŸ“
433.
A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move. ğŸ“
434.
Recalls are not Moves. ğŸ“
434.1.
They do not cause Triggered Abilities to trigger that are triggered by Move actions. ğŸ“
434.2.
A Recall causes a Permanent to change locations. ğŸ“
434.3.
A Recall cannot be prevented by actions and Game Effects that restrict or block Movement. ğŸ“
435.
Gear can be Recalled. ğŸ“
435.1.
When an un-attached Gear is created or played at a battleï¬eld, or is at a battleï¬eld for any other reason, it is Recalled to its controller's base during the next Cleanup. Example: An Equipment is attached to a unit at a battleï¬eld, so the Equipment is present at that battleï¬eld. If the unit dies, the Equipment will be recalled during the next cleanup. ğŸ“
436.
Recalls do not affect the state of the Permanent being recalled. ğŸ“
436.1.
Unless otherwise stated by the source of the Recall, Damage, Exhausted Status, Buffed Status, and applied Layer alterations will all remain unaffected by a Recall. ğŸ“
437.
Combat ğŸ“
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players. ğŸ“
439.
Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleï¬eld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated. ğŸ“
439.1.
If more than one Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ï¬rst. ğŸ“
439.2.
If Staged Combats stop being Staged before the Steps of Combat are initiated, they are not resolved or executed. ğŸ“
440.
Combat can only occur between Units controlled by exactly two players. ğŸ“
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations. ğŸ“
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means, ğŸ“
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base. ğŸ“
440.2.b.
Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base, where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting. ğŸ“
440.3.
All choices that would result in a Combat occurring between more than two players simultaneously are invalid and ineligible to be completed. ğŸ“
441.
The Steps of Combat ğŸ“
442.
Step 1: The Showdown Step ğŸ“
442.1.
A Showdown opens at this time. ğŸ“
442.1.a.
Establish who is Attacker and who is Defender. ğŸ“
442.1.a.1.
The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Attacker designation now. ğŸ“
442.1.a.1.a.
This player gains Focus as this Showdown begins. ğŸ“
442.1.a.2.
The Defender is the player who did not apply the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Defender designation now. ğŸ“
442.1.a.3.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Attacker gain the Attacker designation now. ğŸ“
442.1.a.3.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present ğŸ“
442.1.a.4.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Defender gain the Defender designation now. ğŸ“
442.1.a.4.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present ğŸ“
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending. ğŸ“
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player. ğŸ“
442.1.c.
The State Closes if an Initial Chain was created. ğŸ“
442.1.c.1.
Otherwise the Showdown continues, with the State Open as normal. ğŸ“
442.1.d.
Players proceed with any play on the Chain as normal. ğŸ“
442.1.e.
Focus does not pass upon closure of the Initial Chain, if any. ğŸ“
443.
Step 2: The Combat Damage Step ğŸ“
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might. ğŸ“
443.1.a.
The Combat Damage Step only occurs if both Attacking and Defending units remain at the location. ğŸ“
443.1.a.1.
If neither Attacking Units nor Defending Units remain at this stage, the Combat Damage Step is skipped. ğŸ“
443.1.b.
Sum the Might of all Attacking Units. ğŸ“
443.1.c.
Sum the Might of all Defending Units. ğŸ“
443.1.d.
Starting with the Attacker, each player assigns an amount of damage equal to their summed Might among the other's Units. ğŸ“
443.1.d.1.
Assigning Damage is not Dealing Damage. ğŸ“
443.1.d.1.a.
When all Damage is assigned, it will be Dealt simultaneously. These actions are not synonymous. ğŸ“
443.1.d.2.
Abilities or effects may inï¬‚uence the order in which damage is assigned. Reminder: Lethal Damage is non-zero damage equaling or exceeding the Might of a Unit. ğŸ“
443.1.d.3.
Units must have lethal damage assigned to them in full before damage is assigned to a different Unit. Example: If a player has 5 damage to distribute among four 3 Might units, they may not choose to assign 2 damage to one of the units and 1 damage to each of the remaining 3. They must assign at least 3 damage to one, and the remaining 2 to another. ğŸ“
443.1.d.4.
Units cannot have more damage assigned to them than the minimum required to constitute lethal damage unless no further units remain to have damage assigned to them. ğŸ“
443.1.d.5.
A player must obey all requirements and restrictions on damage assignment if able. Example: A player is assigning damage to the following units: a unit with Tank ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."); Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last."); and another unit without any abilities. That player must assign combat damage ï¬rst to the unit with Tank, then to the unit with no abilities, then to Caitlyn. ğŸ“
443.1.d.6.
If multiple Units have abilities or effects that require a player to assign them damage with the same priority, that player may assign damage to those units in any order. Example: A player is assigning damage to the following units: two units with Tank ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst.") and one unit with no abilities. That player chooses one of the units with Tank and assigns combat damage to it. Then they must assign any remaining damage ï¬rst to the other unit with Tank, then to the unit with no abilities. ğŸ“
443.1.d.7.
If a Unit has one or more Abilities or effects applying to it that demand it be assigned damage in a speciï¬c way that is exclusionary, then the assigning player chooses only one of those abilities to apply when assigning damage. Example: Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last.") has been given the Tank ability ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."). A player is assigning damage to this Caitlyn with Tank and two units with no abilities. That player canâ€™t fulï¬ll both of Caitlynâ€™s damage requirements, so they may choose to assign damage to Caitlyn ï¬rst, fulï¬lling the Tank requirement, or last, fulï¬lling Caitlynâ€™s printed requirement. They canâ€™t choose to apply damage to Caitlyn in between the other two units, because that wouldnâ€™t fulï¬ll either requirement. ğŸ“
443.1.d.8.
If there is more than one unit in which this situation applies to, each unit is dealt with individually. The assigning player chooses which ability or effect applies, and then resolves the assignment. If this creates a situation where now more than one unit must be assigned with the same priority, those units may be assigned damage in any order as normal within that priority. Example: Two copies of Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last.") have been given the Tank ability ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."). A player assigning damage to these two Caitlyns and one unit with no abilities could choose to fulï¬ll both Caitlynsâ€™ Tank requirements by assigning them both damage before the other unit. ğŸ“
443.1.d.9.
If a unit cannot be dealt damage, then no amount of damage can be considered lethal. Such a unit is exempt from any considerations of mandatory assignment. Example: Kayn, Unleashed says â€œIf I have moved twice this turn, I don't take damage.â€ While Kayn canâ€™t take damage, it is ignored for the purposes of assigning lethal damage in combat. ğŸ“
443.1.e.
Deal Damage to each unit equal to the amount assigned to it. ğŸ“
444.
Step 3: The Resolution Step ğŸ“
444.1.
1. Perform a Combat Cleanup. ğŸ“
444.1.a.
Invoke a Combat Special Cleanup. ğŸ“
444.1.a.1.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€ ğŸ“
444.1.a.2.
Insert â€œ2d. Recall Attackers present at the Battleï¬eld if Defenders are still present.â€ See rule 432. Recalls for more information. ğŸ“
444.1.a.3.
Insert â€œ2e. Remove Attacker and Defender Designation from all Units and Players.â€ ğŸ“
444.2.
2. If no Showdown or Combat is staged at this location, the player with Units remaining here Establishes Control. ğŸ“
444.2.a.
Clear the Contested Status. ğŸ“
444.2.b.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn. See rule 182. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering. ğŸ“
444.2.c.
This does not have to be the player that applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
444.2.d.
If there are no Units remaining here controlled by any player, the Battleï¬eld becomes Uncontrolled. ğŸ“
445.
Scoring ğŸ“
446.
A player Scores in one of two ways: ğŸ“
446.1.
Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleï¬eld they did not yet Score this turn. ğŸ“
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means. ğŸ“
