446.1.b.
A player will gain control of a Battleï¬eld after establishing Control by applying Contested ï¬rst. ğŸ“
446.2.
Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleï¬eld during their Beginning Phase. ğŸ“
447.
A player may only Score, from either method, once per Battleï¬eld per turn. ğŸ“
448.
When a player Scores, two things occur: ğŸ“
448.1.
The player earns up to one Point, depending on their current score. ğŸ“
448.1.a.
The Final Point has additional restrictions. ğŸ“
448.1.a.1.
Notably, points earned from sources that are not Conquer or Hold are not beholden to these restrictions. ğŸ“
448.1.b.
When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score, and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play, the following occurs: ğŸ“
448.1.b.1.
If the player has Scored through Hold, that player scores the Final Point. ğŸ“
448.1.b.2.
If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleï¬eld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point. If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleï¬eld this turn, that player draws a card. ğŸ“
448.2.
Trigger Score abilities at the Battleï¬eld that Scored. ğŸ“
448.2.a.
Conquer abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Conquered. ğŸ“
448.2.b.
Hold abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Held. ğŸ“
448.2.c.
These will only trigger when the Battleï¬eld is Scored; I.E. These cannot be triggered more than once per turn for a player. ğŸ“
449.
When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play, they Win the Game immediately. ğŸ“
450.
Layers ğŸ“
451.
Layers are the mechanism in which Game Effects alter the Traits, Intrinsic Abilities, or other properties of Game Objects. ğŸ“
452.
Layers are an organizational structure. ğŸ“
452.1.
Layers only serve to structure the application and order that Game Effects apply to Game Objects to maintain consistency. ğŸ“
453.
The layers are applied repeatedly until all effects operating on objects have been applied once and no changes have been processed. ğŸ“
453.1.
Layers are applied in sequence. Each effect in them is applied as soon as able, and only a single time across all sequences. ğŸ“
453.2.
When a sequence of applications completes, recur the process, and evaluate each layer again applying any effects that may now be applicable. ğŸ“
453.3.
The removal or disqualiï¬cation of an effect is separate from the application of the effect, but still can only be applied once. Example: Fiora, Victorious has printed Might 4 and says â€œWhile I'm Mighty, I have Deï¬‚ect, Ganking, and Shield.â€ If a player places a buff on Fiora, her Might is increased in the Arithmetic layer, after the layer for Ability-Altering Effects. The Ability-Altering Effect layer is then re-checked and the abilities Deï¬‚ect, Ganking, and Shield applied. Since each effect has been applied once and there are no other effects to apply, Fioraâ€™s characteristics are ï¬nalized as 5 Might with Deï¬‚ect, Ganking, and Shield. While a buffed Fiora, Victorious is in combat as a defender, an additional +1 Might will be applied in the Arithmetic layer, giving her 6 Might and the 3 keywords. Example: A buffed Fiora, Victorious is in combat as a defender when her buff is removed. Reevaluating the layers in sequence, she no longer gains Deï¬‚ect, Ganking, and Shield during the Ability-Altering Effect layer, so when the Arithmetic layer is evaluated, neither the buff (which is gone) nor Shield (which she no longer has) apply. She goes directly from 6 Might with three keywords to 4 Might with no keywords.. ğŸ“
454.
Layers are applied in the following order: ğŸ“
454.1.
1. Trait-Altering Effects ğŸ“
454.1.a.
This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace inherent traits of Game Objects. Name Super Type Type Tags Controller Cost Domain ğŸ“
454.1.a.1.
Assignment of Might is dealt with in this layer. Example: A spell reads "A unit's Might becomes 4 this turn." The unit's Might is set to 4 in this layer. ğŸ“
454.1.b.
One Game Object becoming a copy of another. ğŸ“
454.1.b.1.
All Traits, including the Rules Text, replace or are added to those of the original Game Object as speciï¬ed by the Game Effect directing the Copy. This is applied in this layer. ğŸ“
454.1.c.
Effects for this layer can be identiï¬ed by the phrase "become(s)", "give," "is," or "are" in the text. Example: A permanent has the ability "Other friendly units are Yordles." Other friendly units gain the Yordle tag in this layer. ğŸ“
454.2.
2. Ability-Altering Effects ğŸ“
454.2.a.
This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace the abilities or rules text of Game Objects. Keywords Passive Abilities Appending rules text Removing rules text Duplicating Rules Text from one Game Object to another ğŸ“
454.2.b.
Effects for this layer can be identiï¬ed by the phrase "become(s)," "give," "lose(s)," "have," "has," "is," or "are" in the text. Example: A permanent has the ability "Other friendly units have [Vision]." Other friendly units gain the Vision keyword in this layer. ğŸ“
454.2.c.
Abilities of Effect Text of Attached cards are appended in this layer. ğŸ“
454.3.
3. Arithmetic ğŸ“
454.3.a.
This layer deals with the mathematics of increasing and decreasing the numeric values of the traits of Game Objects. Might Energy Cost Power Cost ğŸ“
454.3.b.
When an arithmetic effect has a limitation that applies, it is limited at the time of its application, and is â€œrememberedâ€ at that limited level for the duration of its effect. This process is called â€œsnapshotting.â€ Example: If an effect gives a unit â€œ-4 [M] to a min of 1 until end of turnâ€ choosing a unit with 2 [M], then the effect will generate -1 [M] until end of turn. ğŸ“
454.3.c.
Might Bonuses of Attached cards are applied in this layer. ğŸ“
454.3.d.
This layer applies arithmetic in the following way. ğŸ“
454.3.d.1.
1. Increases ğŸ“
454.3.d.1.a.
Positive values, or increases, to Might are applied ï¬rst. ğŸ“
454.3.d.1.b
If there is a restriction or limitation to this increase, the limitation is â€œsnapshottedâ€ for the duration of the effect. ğŸ“
454.3.d.2.
2. Decreases ğŸ“
454.3.d.2.a.
Negative values, or decreases, to Might are applied last. ğŸ“
454.3.d.2.b.
If there is a restriction or limitation to this decrease, the limitation is snapshotted for the duration of the effect. ğŸ“
455.
If more than one effect applies to the same Game Object in the Same Layer, or to each other in the same layer, then both effects will apply but their order may be determined by Dependency. ğŸ“
455.1.
A Dependency is established if: ğŸ“
455.1.a.
Applying one of the effects alters the existence of the other; or ğŸ“
455.1.b.
Applying one of the effects alters the number of objects the other effect can inï¬‚uence ğŸ“
455.1.c.
Applying one of the effects alters the outcome when applying the other non- deterministically ğŸ“
456.
To determine which effect Depends on another, determine which of the prior criteria applies, and then also which effectâ€™s evaluation is altered by the sequence of applications. That effect is said to Depend on the other. ğŸ“
456.1.
To resolve a dependency, the effects within the same layer that created the dependency must be applied such that: 1. Identify which effect Depends on the other within the Layer. 2. Apply the effect that is depended on ï¬rst. 3. Immediately apply the effect that Depends on the ï¬rst effect next. ğŸ“
457.
If more than one effect applies in the same layer but no dependency is established, then Timestamp order is applied to the effects within that layer and sublayer ğŸ“
457.1.
When an effect begins applying, it establishes a time for which it is compared against other Game Effects for purposes of resolving Layered effects as its Timestamp. ğŸ“
457.1.a.
Timestamps are not rote values. ğŸ“
457.1.b.
Timestamps are relative comparisons between effects and when they began applying to the game. ğŸ“
457.1.c.
Timestamps are not referenced by Game Effects in any way. They are only used to ï¬nalize layered effects. ğŸ“
457.2.
When Rules Text becomes Inactive for any reason, it loses its Timestamp. When it ceases to be Inactive, a new Timestamp is established. ğŸ“
457.3.
Effects are applied such that the earliest Timestamp within each Layer and Sublayer applies ï¬rst, followed by other Effects in that Layer and Sublayer in chronological order. ğŸ“
458.
Modes of Play ğŸ“
459.
There are multiple methods of playing Riftbound. ğŸ“
460.
A Mode of Play must deï¬ne several variables for the game. ğŸ“
460.1.
Number of Players: How many people are playing the game. ğŸ“
460.2.
Formation of Players: How the players are organized while playing. ğŸ“
460.2.a.
This deï¬nes if a player is alone or on a team. ğŸ“
460.2.b.
This deï¬nes the number of opponents. ğŸ“
460.3.
Victory Score: The point total a player or team must reach to win. ğŸ“
460.3.a.
Victory Scores can be any positive number. ğŸ“
460.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: Determines how many Battleï¬elds are in play, contributed by players, during play. ğŸ“
460.4.a.
This may inï¬‚uence deck building requirements in competitive settings. ğŸ“
460.4.b.
This may involve utilizing less Battleï¬elds than there are players. ğŸ“
460.5.
Setup: Any changes to initial setup required for this mode. ğŸ“
460.6.
Format: Conditions to win or additional rules added over play. ğŸ“
460.7.
First Turn Process: Adjustments to each player's ï¬rst turn. ğŸ“
460.8.
Unique Rules ğŸ“
460.8.a.
If any, they will be appended here. ğŸ“
461.
Sanctioned Modes ğŸ“
462.
1v1 (Duel) ğŸ“
462.1.
2 Players ğŸ“
462.2.
1v1 1 opponent each No teams ğŸ“
462.3.
Victory Score: 8 ğŸ“
462.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 2 ğŸ“
462.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup. ğŸ“
462.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone. ğŸ“
462.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match. ğŸ“
462.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game. ğŸ“
463.
1v1 (Match) ğŸ“
463.1.
2 Players ğŸ“
463.2.
1v1 1 opponent each No teams ğŸ“
463.3.
Victory Score: 8 ğŸ“
463.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 2 ğŸ“
463.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup. ğŸ“
463.5.
Setup: Each player selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are set aside and will not be used for this round of play. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone. After this game, the Battleï¬elds that were used are to be removed and not selected again for this Match. One of the remaining Battleï¬elds that were set aside must be chosen instead. ğŸ“
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins. ğŸ“
463.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game. ğŸ“
464.
FFA3 (Skirmish) ğŸ“
464.1.
3 Players ğŸ“
464.2.
FFA 2 opponents each No teams ğŸ“
464.3.
Victory Score: 8 ğŸ“
464.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3 ğŸ“
464.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup. ğŸ“
464.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are discarded and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the three Players before play and will be used for this game. ğŸ“
464.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match. ğŸ“
464.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game. ğŸ“
465.
FFA4 (War) ğŸ“
465.1.
4 Players ğŸ“
465.2.
FFA 3 opponents each No teams ğŸ“
465.3.
Victory Score: 8 ğŸ“
465.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3 ğŸ“
465.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. ğŸ“
465.4.b.
The player who is taking the ï¬rst turn removes their Battleï¬elds. They will not be used. ğŸ“
465.5.
Setup: Each player who is not going ï¬rst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game. ğŸ“
465.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match. ğŸ“
465.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game. ğŸ“
466.
2v2 (Magma Chamber) ğŸ“
466.1.
4 Players ğŸ“
466.2.
2v2 2 opponents each 1 teammate ğŸ“
466.3.
Victory Score: 11 ğŸ“
466.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3 ğŸ“
466.4.a.
Each player provides one (1) Battleï¬eld, included in their deck during deck building. ğŸ“
466.4.b.
The player who is taking the ï¬rst turn removes their Battleï¬elds. They will not be used. ğŸ“
466.5.
Setup: ğŸ“
466.5.a.
Each player who is not going ï¬rst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game. ğŸ“
466.5.b.
Turn order alternates teams. ğŸ“
466.5.b.1.
The ï¬rst player will be followed by an opponent, then the ï¬rst player's teammate, then the ï¬rst opponent's teammate, and so on. ğŸ“
466.5.b.2.
If allies are sitting across from each other, turn order proceeds clockwise as normal. ğŸ“
466.5.b.3.
If allies are sitting next to each other, turn order is passed across the table. ğŸ“
466.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match. ğŸ“
466.6.a.
Teammates win or lose together. ğŸ“
466.6.a.1.
If one player Concedes, then the entire team loses. ğŸ“
466.6.a.2.
If one player Loses, then the entire team loses. ğŸ“
466.6.a.3.
If one player Wins, then the entire team wins. ğŸ“
466.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game. ğŸ“
466.8.
Unique Rules ğŸ“
466.8.a.
Players may play spells during their Teammate's Turn.ğŸ“
466.8.b.
Battleï¬elds controlled during the Beginning Phase of a player's turn by that player's teammate are disqualiï¬ed from being scored by that Team, that turn. Example: A player may not induce their partner to retreat, and then conquer a Battleï¬eld their teammate was controlling. ğŸ“
466.8.c.
Control is not shared. ğŸ“
466.8.c.1.
Players may not Hide cards at Battleï¬elds controlled by their Teammate. ğŸ“
466.8.c.2.
Players may not issue Standard Movement to their Teammate's Units. ğŸ“
466.8.d.
Friendly describes controlled Game Objects by a player or their Teammate. Example: "When I am played, ready a friendly unit" could target a player's own Units or their teammate's Units. ğŸ“
466.8.e.
Hands are still Private Information. ğŸ“
466.8.e.1.
Players are not restricted in what they say to their Teammate, however. ğŸ“
466.8.e.1.a.
Feel free to openly communicate, honestly or cryptically. ğŸ“
466.8.e.1.b.
Revealing Cards is still a game action and cannot be done unless instructed. See rule 411. Reveal for more information. ğŸ“
466.8.f.
The Final Point has an adjustment to the criteria when scoring. ğŸ“
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase. ğŸ“
466.8.f.2.
No other changes to Final Point restrictions. ğŸ“
466.8.g.
Teammates may not utilize the same Champion Legend. ğŸ“
466.8.h.
Teammates may not utilize the same Battleï¬elds. ğŸ“
649.
Conceding ğŸ“
650.
A player may concede at any time. ğŸ“
651.
When a player concedes, they are removed from the game in progress. ğŸ“
651.1.
If only one other player is remaining after a player has conceded, the player remaining Wins. ğŸ“
651.2.
If more than one player remains after a concession, follow the steps for the Removal of a Player. ğŸ“
651.3.
Removal of a player involves them no longer being able to make choices or otherwise inï¬‚uence the game. ğŸ“
651.4.
If the player has Teammates due to the Mode of Play, that playerâ€™s Teammates also lose and are removed from the game. ğŸ“
652.
If the game continues, follow these steps for Removal of a Player. ğŸ“
652.1.
Banish all permanents and runes they currently control and all permanents and runes they own. ğŸ“
652.2.
Remove the Battleï¬eld they contributed to the game if it is in use. ğŸ“
652.2.a.
If it was in use, replace it with a token battleï¬eld with no abilities. ğŸ“
652.2.b.
Any units or hidden cards there do not move and are otherwise unaffected by this process. ğŸ“
652.2.c.
If the removed battleï¬eld was applying any continuous effects, those continuous effects immediately cease, which may cause changes in the characteristics of units or hidden cards there. Example: A battleï¬eld reads "Units here have +1 [M]." If that battleï¬eld's owner concedes and the battleï¬eld is removed from the game as a result, units there immediately cease to get +1 [M]. ğŸ“
652.3.
Remove all cards they own from the game. ğŸ“
652.4.
Counter all spells and abilities of all types controlled by the player that has conceded. ğŸ“
652.5.
Proceed with the game. ğŸ“
652.5.a.
Turn ğŸ“
652.5.a.1.
If the removed player was the Turn Player, play proceeds in Turn Order to the next available player in order. ğŸ“
652.5.b.
Focus ğŸ“
652.5.b.1.
If the removed player had Focus in a Showdown, the next Player in order receives Focus. ğŸ“
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed. ğŸ“
652.5.c.
Priority ğŸ“
652.5.c.1.
If the removed player had Priority during a Chain, the next Player in order receives Priority. ğŸ“
652.5.c.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have passed Priority, then the most recent spell or ability on the Chain will resolve with Priority being re-established as appropriate for the state after the resolution of that spell or ability. ğŸ“
700.
Additional Rules ğŸ“
701.
Buffs ğŸ“
702.
Buffs are objects placed on Units. ğŸ“
702.1.
Buffs can be tracked with a buff reminder card from a Riftbound booster pack or with any spare object in your surroundings. ğŸ“
702.2.
Buffs can be added or spent. ğŸ“
702.2.a.
To Buff a Unit, a player chooses a Unit and then places a buff on it. That Unit is Buffed for as long as the buff remains on it. ğŸ“
702.2.b.
Spending a Buff removes a single Buff counter from a Unit. ğŸ“
702.2.b.1.
A buff cannot be spent from a Unit that does not have a buff. ğŸ“
702.2.b.2.
A player can only spend buffs on units they control. ğŸ“
702.3.
There can only be one Buff on a Unit at a time. ğŸ“
702.3.a.
If a Buff is added, or instructed to be added, on a Unit that already has a Buff, it is not placed instead. ğŸ“
703.
Each Buff individually contributes +1 Might to a Unit. ğŸ“
704.
Buffs are Game Objects and may be referenced, counted, or targeted by other effects as speciï¬ed. ğŸ“
705.
If a Unit leaves play, remove all Buffs from it. ğŸ“
705.1.
Champions do not retain Buffs in the Champion Zone, even if they return there somehow. ğŸ“
706.
Mighty ğŸ“
707.
Mighty is a description that applies to some units. Other game effects can check whether a unit is Mighty. ğŸ“
708.
A Unit "is Mighty" as long as its Might is 5 or greater. ğŸ“
709.
A Unit "becomes Mighty" at the moment its Might changes from being less than 5 to being 5 or greater. Example: A Unit with Might 4 that gets +1 [M] becomes Mighty. Example: A Unit with Might 5 that gets +1 [M] does not become Mighty, because it was already Mighty. ğŸ“
710.
Units on the board are evaluated according to their current Might. Example: A unit with a base Might of 3 is targeted by a spell that reads "A unit gets +3 [M] this turn." As that spell resolves, its Might changes from 3 to 6, and it becomes Mighty. When that effect expires at the end of the turn, it will no longer be Mighty. ğŸ“
711.
Units in Non-Board Zones are evaluated according to their inherent Might. Example: A unit in the trash is Mighty if its printed Might is 5 or greater. It doesn't matter if there were effects raising or lowering its might while it was on the board. ğŸ“
712.
Bonus Damage ğŸ“
713.
Bonus Damage is an intrinsic property that can be granted to Deal actions that inï¬‚uence the amount of Damage that the action is distributing. ğŸ“
714.
If more than one instance of Bonus Damage is applied or granted to a Deal action, all instances are summed and applied once. ğŸ“
714.1.
Bonus Damage can only be a positive value, and can only increase the amount of Damage being distributed. ğŸ“
714.2.
If, for any reason, Bonus Damage would be a negative number, then no Bonus Damage is applied to the action. ğŸ“
715.
Bonus Damage applies to the total damage Dealt by one instance of the action. ğŸ“
715.1.
If the Deal action has a single target, the amount of Damage to that target will be increased by the Bonus Damage granted to it. ğŸ“
715.2.
If the Deal action has multiple targets, the amount of Damage dealt to each target is increased by Bonus Damage individually and separately. Example: Singularity is a spell that says â€œDeal 6 to each of up to two units.â€ A player plays Singularity while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Singularity deals 1 Bonus Damage to both of its targets, dealing 7 to each. ğŸ“
715.3.
If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split. This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen. Example: Volibear, Furious is a unit that says in part â€œWhen I attack, deal 5 damage split among any number of enemy units here.â€ A player attacks with Volibear, Furious while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Volibear, Furious now deals 6 damage split among any number of enemy units at its location, and can choose to split that damage among up to 6 units rather than the usual 5. ğŸ“
716.
Attachment ğŸ“
717.
Attaching is a limited action that causes cards to become linked to each other to combine their effects in some way. This causes one card to become Attached and the other to become A Top-Most Card. See rule 421 Attach for more information. ğŸ“
718.
Attached is the state of a card being linked to another card in this way. ğŸ“
718.1.
A card remains in this state until Detached. ğŸ“
718.2.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive. See rule 720 Inactive for more information. ğŸ“
718.3.
While in this state, Abilities in the cardâ€™s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card. ğŸ“
718.4.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by the value listed. ğŸ“
718.5.
Attached cards still have all properties of being a card on the board while in this state. ğŸ“
718.5.a.
Attached cards still have all Types and Tags while Attached. ğŸ“
718.5.b.
Attached cards still can be chosen or targeted by game effects while Attached. ğŸ“
718.6.
Attached cards cannot be moved separately from the Top-Most Card they are Attached to. ğŸ“
718.7.
A card may be Attached only to a single Top-Most card at a time. ğŸ“
718.8.
Attached cards may have different Controllers from their Top-Most card. ğŸ“
718.8.a.
Changes in Control of the Top-Most card do not impact Control of Attached cards and vice versa. ğŸ“
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus. ğŸ“
719.
A Top-Most Card is a card that has one or more cards linked to it through the process of Attaching. ğŸ“
719.1.
The Effect Text of all cards Attached to this card are appended to the Rules Text of this card for as long as they remain Attached. ğŸ“
719.2.
This card ceases being a Top-Most Card when there are no longer any cards Attached to it. ğŸ“
719.3.
A Top-Most Card and all cards Attached to it are at the same location. ğŸ“
719.3.a.
When the Top-Most Card moves, all Attached cards move with it. ğŸ“
719.4.
The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa. ğŸ“
719.5.
When a Top-Most Card changes zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, all Attached cards Detach from it, remaining in their current zones. ğŸ“
719.5.a.
The player that controls the Top-Most Card that changed zones decides the order these cards Detach in, and thus the order of any relevant effects that occur due to the Detach occurring. ğŸ“
720.
Inactive ğŸ“
721.1.
Card text can occasionally be assigned to be ignored, disregarded, or otherwise rendered as not applicable during the course of play. This state is referred to as Inactive. ğŸ“
721.1.a.
Text marked this way is not applied at all while in this state. ğŸ“
721.1.b.
Inactive Abilities do not trigger, do not apply, and cannot be activated. Inactive instructions are not processed. ğŸ“
722.
Inactive text is still present on cards. ğŸ“
722.1.
Cards with Inactive text still have keywords for the sake of Game Effects that want to reference or see if a card has a keyword. ğŸ“
722.2.
Game Effects that parse or interpret text to determine target eligibility may still parse Inactive text for the sake of eligibility. Example: Spinning Axe is a gear with [Temporary]. While itâ€™s attached and its rules text is inactive, its [Temporary] ability doesnâ€™t trigger. However, a spell that reads â€œDestroy a gear with [Temporary]â€ could still choose and destroy Spinning Axe. ğŸ“
723.
Rules Text is never Inactive by default. ğŸ“
724.
Effect Text is Inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached. ğŸ“
725.
Inactive text can partially cease to be Inactive under speciï¬c circumstances and exceptions. ğŸ“
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches. ğŸ“
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches. ğŸ“
725.3.
If an Attached card has an Equip ability, the Weaponmaster keyword can reference that Equip ability and any abilities that passively modify that Equip ability. ğŸ“
726.
Keywords ğŸ“
727.
A Keyword is a speciï¬c term that appears on Cards that acts as a shorthand for a speciï¬c game effect, or ability of any variety. ğŸ“
727.1.
A Keyword can be an ability. ğŸ“
727.2.
Keywords can be identiï¬ed by having a colored highlight behind them. ğŸ“
727.2.a.
The color of the highlight has no effect on gameplay. ğŸ“
727.3.
Keywords can be referenced or speciï¬ed by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
727.3.a.
Other effects may grant Keywords. ğŸ“
727.3.a.1.
The deï¬nition and rules of the speciï¬c Keyword will determine the behavior if a Keyword is granted while it is already present. ğŸ“
727.3.a.2.
The effect that granted the Keyword will specify the duration for which it is granted. ğŸ“
727.3.a.3.
If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone. ğŸ“
727.3.b.
Other effects may remove Keywords. ğŸ“
727.3.b.1.
The effect that removed the Keyword will specify the duration it is removed. ğŸ“
727.3.b.2.
If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone. ğŸ“
728.
A card can have any number of Keywords. ğŸ“
729.
Similar to other rules text, execute any effects of Keywords in the order listed when reading the card from top to bottom of the rules text. ğŸ“
730.
Keyword Glossary ğŸ“
731.
Accelerate ğŸ“
731.1.
Accelerate is a Unit ability. ğŸ“
731.1.a.
Accelerate is functionally short for "As you play me, you may pay [1] and 1 Power as an additional cost. If you do, I enter ready." ğŸ“
731.1.a.1.
If the unit has a single domain, the Power portion of the Accelerate cost can be paid only with a Power that matches the domain of the unit. ğŸ“
731.1.a.2.
If the unit has no domain or more than one domain, the Power portion of the Accelerate cost can be paid with [A] (a Power of any domain). ğŸ“
731.2.
Accelerate is an Optional Additional Cost to be paid as a player plays the unit with the ability. ğŸ“
731.2.a.
Accelerate costs cannot be paid while the unit is on the board, only as part of the steps of playing a card. ğŸ“
731.3.
Accelerate has no function while on the board. ğŸ“
731.4.
Multiple instances of Accelerate are redundant. ğŸ“
731.5.
Accelerate, and whether or not a unit has Accelerate, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
731.6.
Accelerate inï¬‚uences the state of the unit entering the Board. It does not enter exhausted and then become ready. ğŸ“
731.6.a.
Accelerate will not interact with, or trigger, abilities that are affected by units becoming ready. ğŸ“
732.
Action ğŸ“
732.1.
Action is a Permissive keyword. ğŸ“
732.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities. ğŸ“
732.1.b.
Action grants the corresponding card or effect permission to be played or activated during Showdowns, even when it is not the Controlling player's turn. ğŸ“
732.1.c.
Action is functionally short for the following: ğŸ“
732.1.c.1.
On Spells and Units: "This can be played during showdowns on any player's turn." ğŸ“
732.1.c.2.
On Rune, Legend, or Permanent Abilities: "This can be activated during showdowns on any player's turn." ğŸ“
732.2.
The card or effect with this keyword is not restricted to showdowns. This permission is inclusive of all other timings and options available to the ability as written or by default. ğŸ“
732.3.
Action does not alter the function of any instruction of the corresponding card or effect it is on. It is only permission. Example: Playing a Unit with Action still has the inherent restrictions of playing Units without Action. It can only be played to the controlling player's base or a battleï¬eld they control. ğŸ“
732.4.
Action is a referenceable characteristic. ğŸ“
732.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Action is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
732.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Action is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
732.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Action is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
733.
Assault ğŸ“
733.1.
Assault is a Passive Ability keyword. ğŸ“
733.1.a.
It is present on Units. ğŸ“
733.1.b.
Assault is formatted as "Assault [X]". ğŸ“
733.1.b.1.
The X is referenced in the functional text of the ability. ğŸ“
733.1.b.2.
The X is referred to as the Assault Value. ğŸ“
733.1.b.3.
If X is omitted, it is presumed to be 1. ğŸ“
733.1.c.
It is functionally short for "While I am an attacker, I have +X [M]." ğŸ“
733.1.d.
Being an attacker means the Unit has gained the Attacker designation during Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
733.1.d.1.
Assault remains in effect as long as the Unit maintains the Attacker designation. ğŸ“
733.2.
If a Unit has Assault or has been granted Assault and is granted Assault by an additional source, the Assault Value of all granted Assault keywords is summed. Example: Petty Ofï¬cer has Assault. It is chosen as the target of Cleave, which says "Give a unit [Assault 3] this turn." After Cleave resolves, Petty Ofï¬cer has Assault 4 this turn. ğŸ“
733.3.
Assault, and whether or not a unit has Assault, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
734.
Deathknell ğŸ“
734.1.
Deathknell is a Triggered Ability keyword. ğŸ“
734.1.a.
It is present on Permanents. ğŸ“
734.1.b.
It is formatted as "Deathknell â€” [Effect]". ğŸ“
734.1.b.1.
[Effect] is the rules text for the speciï¬c instance of Deathknell. This is referred to as the Deathknell effect. ğŸ“
734.1.c.
It is functionally short for "When I die, [Effect]." ğŸ“
734.1.c.1.
[Effect] is the rules text of the Deathknell effect. ğŸ“
734.1.d.
The Trigger for this effect is the Permanent being Killed and sent to the Trash. ğŸ“
734.1.d.1.
If the Permanent with the effect is not sent to the Trash, for example because its "killed" event was replaced with a recall, the Deathknell will not occur. ğŸ“
734.1.d.2.
The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup. ğŸ“
734.1.d.3.
Before the card with Deathknell is moved to the Trash, note its location, its attributes, and any other details related to the effect of its Deathknell to process the trigger after it has been Finalized. ğŸ“
734.2.
Each instance of Deathknell a Permanent may have will trigger separately. ğŸ“
734.2.a.
The controller will choose the order to add these Triggers to the chain. ğŸ“
734.3.
Deathknell, and whether or not a permanent has Deathknell, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
735.
Deï¬‚ect ğŸ“
735.1.
Deï¬‚ect is a Passive Ability keyword. ğŸ“
735.1.a.
It is present on Permanents. ğŸ“
735.1.b.
It is formatted as "Deï¬‚ect [X]". ğŸ“
735.1.b.1.
The X is referenced in the functional text of the ability. ğŸ“
735.1.b.2.
The X is referred to as the Deï¬‚ect Value. ğŸ“
735.1.b.3.
If X is omitted, it is presumed to be 1. ğŸ“
735.1.c.
It is functionally short for "Spells and abilities an opponent controls that choose me cost an amount of Power equal to [Deï¬‚ect Value] more to play as an additional cost." ğŸ“
735.1.c.1.
The Power used to pay this cost may always be of any Domain. Example: A Fury spell targets an Order unit with Deï¬‚ect. The Power used to pay the Deï¬‚ect cost can be any Domain; it does not need to match the Domain of the spell or the target. ğŸ“
735.1.d.
It is an effect that imposes a Mandatory Additional Cost on Spells and Abilities that choose the permanent that has this ability. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
735.2.
If a Unit has Deï¬‚ect, or has been granted Deï¬‚ect, and is granted Deï¬‚ect by an additional source, the Deï¬‚ect Value of all granted Deï¬‚ect keywords is summed. ğŸ“
735.3.
Deï¬‚ect, and whether or not a permanent has Deï¬‚ect, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
736.
Ganking ğŸ“
736.1.
Ganking is a Passive Ability keyword. ğŸ“
736.1.a.
It is present on Units. ğŸ“
736.1.b.
It is functionally short for "I may move to a battleï¬eld from another battleï¬eld." ğŸ“
736.1.c.
It is a passive ability that adds permissions to the Unit's Standard Move. ğŸ“
736.1.c.1.
It does not restrict or remove options from the Unit's Standard Move. ğŸ“
736.1.c.2.
It does not have an activation cost. ğŸ“
736.1.c.3.
It does not give additional abilities or activations of Movement, only new options for the Standard Move. ğŸ“
736.2.
Multiple instances of Ganking are redundant. ğŸ“
736.3.
Ganking, and whether or not a unit has Ganking, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
737.
Hidden ğŸ“
737.1.
Hidden is a keyword that acts as a prerequisite to perform the Hide Discretionary Action. ğŸ“
737.1.a.
It is present on Spells, Units, and Gear. ğŸ“
737.1.b.
It is functionally short for "While this card is in your hand or in the Champion Zone on your turn during an Open State, you may pay [A] to hide this facedown at a battleï¬eld you control that doesn't already have a facedown card hidden there for as long as you control that battleï¬eld. Beginning on the next turn, this gains [Reaction] and you may play this, ignoring its base cost." ğŸ“
737.1.c.
It allows the player to take the Discretionary Action Hide. ğŸ“
737.1.c.1.
Hide is not a subset of Play. ğŸ“
737.1.c.2.
Hiding a card does not open a chain. ğŸ“
737.1.c.3.
Playing a card from facedown (or "from Hidden") does open a chain. ğŸ“
737.1.d.
Some choices made while playing a card from Hidden are restricted to the battleï¬eld where it was hidden. A card cannot be played from Hidden if it is a spell with no valid targets under these restrictions. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information. ğŸ“
737.1.d.1.
A hidden unit must be played to that battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
737.1.d.2.
If a hidden spell or a play effect of a hidden permanent chooses any targets, those targets must be chosen from among options at that battleï¬eld, unless the ability explicitly restricts targeting in a way that makes this impossible. Example: Blastcone Fae is a unit with Hidden and â€œWhen you play me, give a unit -2 [M] this turn, to a minimum of 1 [M].â€ Because this is a play effect, its target must be chosen from among units at the same battleï¬eld if Blastcone Fae was played from Hidden. Example: Tideturner is a unit with Hidden and â€œWhen you play me, you may choose a unit you control at another location. Move me to its location and it to my original location.â€ Because its play ability has a targeting restriction that can never be fulï¬lled by a unit at its battleï¬eld, its target may be chosen freely from among the available options. ğŸ“
737.1.d.3.
If a hidden spell or a play effect of a hidden permanent causes you to play a unit, you must choose to play that unit at that battleï¬eld. ğŸ“
737.2.
Abilities and instructions of hidden cards other than the choices listed above function as normal. Example: Stand United is a spell that has Hidden and says â€œBuff a friendly unit. Buffs give an additional +1 might to friendly units this turn.â€ If itâ€™s played from Hidden, the ï¬rst part of its ability must choose a friendly unit at the same battleï¬eld, but the second part of its ability affects all friendly units with buffs, no matter where they are. ğŸ“
737.3.
Instead of being hidden, a card with Hidden may be played for its cost as normal, at its normal timing with no restrictions on targeting. ğŸ“
737.4.
Multiple instances of Hidden are redundant. ğŸ“
737.5.
Hidden, and whether or not a card has Hidden, is a characteristic of the card and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
737.5.a.
This is independent of the state of being facedown. ğŸ“
737.6.
A card that is Hidden gains Reaction while facedown, and may be played any time a card with Reaction may be played as a result. ğŸ“
737.6.a.
The property is granted to the card in its facedown state, and is not publicly known. ğŸ“
738.
Legion ğŸ“
738.1.
Legion is a Conditional Keyword. ğŸ“
738.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities. ğŸ“
738.1.b.
It is formatted as "Legion â€” [Text]". ğŸ“
738.1.c.
Starting from the Keyword to the end of the clause, the entire statement is the Legion Ability. ğŸ“
738.1.c.1.
On spells and on play effects of permanents, it is functionally short for â€œIf you have played another Main Deck card before this one already this turn, apply [Text].â€ ğŸ“
738.1.c.2.
On other abilities and instructions, it is functionally short for â€œIf you have played a Main Deck card this turn, apply [Text].â€ ğŸ“
738.1.c.3.
This is called the Legion condition. ğŸ“
738.1.c.4.
Legion's conditional can apply to passive abilities, activated abilities, spell instructions, or even abilities active in zones outside of the board. ğŸ“
738.2.
All instances of Legion on cards a player controls are satisï¬ed by that player playing a single card. Example: One card has three different Legion Abilities. The Legion Text of all three abilities apply as long as one card has been played by the card's controller earlier in the same turn. ğŸ“
738.3.
Legion, and whether or not a card has Legion, is a characteristic of the card and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
739.
Reaction ğŸ“
739.1.
Reaction is a Permissive keyword. ğŸ“
739.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities. ğŸ“
739.1.b.
Reaction grants the corresponding card or effect all abilities and permissions of Action. ğŸ“
739.1.c.
Reaction, additionally, is functionally short for the following: ğŸ“
739.1.c.1.
On Spells: "This can be played during Closed States on any player's turn." ğŸ“
739.1.c.2.
On Units: "This can be played during Closed States on any player's turn." ğŸ“
739.1.c.3.
On Rune, Legend, or Permanent Abilities: "This can be activated during Closed States on any player's turn." ğŸ“
739.2.
The corresponding card or effect with this keyword is not restricted to Closed States or Showdowns. This permission is inclusive of all other timings and options available to the ability as written, Action's permissions, or by default. ğŸ“
739.3.
Reaction does not alter the function of any instruction of the Card, Rune, or Effect it is on. It is only Permission. ğŸ“
739.3.a.
Playing Units with Reaction still has the inherent restrictions of playing Units without Reaction. It can only be played to the controlling player's base or a battleï¬eld they control. ğŸ“
739.4.
Reaction is a referencable characteristic. ğŸ“
739.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Reaction is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
739.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Reaction is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
739.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Reaction is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
740.
Shield ğŸ“
740.1.
Shield is a Passive Ability keyword. ğŸ“
740.1.a.
It is present on Units. ğŸ“
740.1.b.
Shield is formatted as "Shield [X]". ğŸ“
740.1.b.1.
The X is referenced in the functional text of the ability. ğŸ“
740.1.b.2.
The X is referred to as the Shield Value. ğŸ“
740.1.b.3.
If X is omitted, it is presumed to be 1. ğŸ“
740.1.c.
It is functionally short for "While I am a defender, I have +X [M]." ğŸ“
740.1.d.
Being a defender means the Unit has gained the Defender designation during Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information. ğŸ“
740.1.d.1.
Shield remains in effect as long as the Unit maintains the Defender designation. ğŸ“
740.2.
If a Unit has Shield, or has been granted Shield, and is granted Shield by an additional source, the Shield Value of all granted Shield keywords is summed. Example: Stalwart Poro has Shield. It is chosen as the target of Block, which says "Give a unit [Shield 3] and [Tank] this turn." After Block resolves, Stalwart Poro has Shield 4 this turn. ğŸ“
740.3.
Shield, and whether or not a unit has Shield, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
741.
Tank ğŸ“
741.1.
Tank is a Passive Ability keyword. ğŸ“
741.1.a.
It is present on Units. ğŸ“
741.1.b.
It is functionally short for "I must be assigned lethal damage before any other unit with the same controller as me that does not have [Tank] during combat resolution." ğŸ“
741.1.c.
It alters how players can elect to assign combat damage during combat. ğŸ“
741.1.c.1.
Players must still assign lethal damage to a unit before moving to the next when assigning their damage. ğŸ“
741.1.c.2.
If more than one unit with Tank is present with the same controller in Combat, damage may be assigned to any of them. Units without Tank are invalid assignments until all units with Tank have lethal damage assigned to them. ğŸ“
741.2.
Multiple instances of Tank are redundant. ğŸ“
741.3.
Tank, and whether or not a unit has Tank, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
742.
Temporary ğŸ“
742.1.
Temporary is a Triggered Ability keyword. ğŸ“
742.1.a.
It is present on Permanents. ğŸ“
742.1.b.
It is functionally short for "At the start of this permanent's controller's Beginning Phase, before scoring, kill this." ğŸ“
742.1.c.
The Trigger Condition is the controller of the permanent's Beginning Phase occurring. ğŸ“
742.2.
Multiple instances of Temporary are redundant. ğŸ“
742.3.
Temporary, and whether or not a permanent has Temporary, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
743.
Vision ğŸ“
743.1.
Vision is a Triggered Ability keyword. ğŸ“
743.1.a.
It is present on Permanents. ğŸ“
743.1.b.
It is functionally short for "When this is played, look at the top card of your Main Deck. You may recycle it." ğŸ“
743.1.c.
The trigger is the permanent entering the Board. ğŸ“
743.2.
Multiple instances of Vision trigger separately. ğŸ“
743.2.a.
The player may choose to recycle or not recycle for each instance of Vision separately. ğŸ“
743.2.b.
If the player does not recycle the top card and nothing else happens in between the triggers resolving, each instance of Vision will see the same card. ğŸ“
743.3.
Vision, and whether or not a permanent has Vision, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
744.
Equip ğŸ“
744.1.
Equip is an Activated Ability keyword. ğŸ“
744.1.a.
Equip is normally present on Gear with the tag Equipment. ğŸ“
744.1.b.
Equip has a cost to activate and Attaches the card with Equip to a chosen Unit when the cost is paid. ğŸ“
744.1.b.1.
Equipâ€™s choice is a Target. ğŸ“
744.1.b.2.
The chosen Unit will become the Top-Most Card for the Attach action. ğŸ“
744.1.c.
Equip is formatted as â€œEquip [Cost]â€ ğŸ“
744.1.c.1.
If paying costs or making choices for this ability causes triggered abilities to trigger, they will be placed on the chain above this ability in a Pending state. See rule 369 Activated Abilities for more information. ğŸ“
744.1.c.2.
Equip is functionally short for â€œ[Cost]: Attach this gear to a unit you control.â€ ğŸ“
744.1.c.3.
Equip costs may include both resource costs and non-resource costs. ğŸ“
744.1.c.4.
Equip abilities may also include text that alters the Equip cost. Such text is taken into account when determining a cardâ€™s Equip cost for any reason.ğŸ“
744.1.c.5.
Equip abilities may include text that alters the timing or targeting of the Equip ability. ğŸ“
744.2.
When the Attach action completes from this keyword, the Unit that was chosen is considered to have been Equipped by the Gear with this ability. ğŸ“
744.2.a.
This is an event other Game Effects and Triggered Abilities can reference. ğŸ“
744.3.
Equipped is the state of a Top-Most Card being Attached by one or more cards that are Equipment. ğŸ“
744.3.a.
The state of being Equipped is synchronous with that of the Attached state of the Equipment. ğŸ“
744.3.b.
A Top-Most Card is Equipped as long as one or more of its Attached cards are Equipment. ğŸ“
744.3.c.
The state of being Equipped corresponds to a Top-Most card having a card with Equip that is Attached to it. ğŸ“
744.4.
Multiple instances of Equip are equivalent to multiple Activated Abilities and can each be activated separately by paying the corresponding costs. ğŸ“
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
745.
Quick-Draw ğŸ“
745.1.
Quick-Draw is a Triggered Ability keyword. It is also a Permissive keyword. ğŸ“
745.1.a.
Quick-Draw is present on Gear with Equip abilities. ğŸ“
745.1.b.
Cards with Quick-Draw have Reaction inherently. ğŸ“
745.1.c.
Quick-Draw allows cards to be played and Attached using Reaction timing. ğŸ“
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
745.2.
Multiple instances of Quick-Draw do not trigger separately and have no effect beyond the ï¬rst. ğŸ“
745.3.
Quick-Draw has no function while on the board. ğŸ“
745.4.
Quick-Draw, and whether or not a gear has Quick-Draw, is a characteristic of the Gear and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
746.
Repeat ğŸ“
746.1.
Repeat is an Optional Additional Cost keyword. ğŸ“
746.1.a.
Repeat is present on Spells. ğŸ“
746.1.b.
Repeat is an optional cost that player may pay to execute the effect of their spells a second time. ğŸ“
746.1.c.
Repeat is formatted as â€œRepeat [Cost]â€ ğŸ“
746.1.c.1.
The Cost is an Additional Cost to be paid during the steps of playing the spell. ğŸ“
746.1.c.2.
If a spell has more than one instance of Repeat, each Cost may be paid or not paid individually. ğŸ“
746.1.c.3.
Each Repeat Cost can be paid only a single time. ğŸ“
746.1.d.
Repeat is functionally short for â€œYou may pay [Cost] as an additional cost as you play this spell. If you do, execute the instructions of this spell one additional time.â€ ğŸ“
746.1.d.1.
When the additional cost is paid, the effect of the spell, upon resolution, will be performed an additional time. Example: Desertâ€™s Call is a spell with [Repeat] [2] and â€œPlay a 2 [S] Sand Soldier unit token.â€ If its controller pays its Repeat cost as they play it, the cardâ€™s instruction to play a Sand Soldier is executed twice, as though the card says â€œPlay a 2 [S] Sand Soldier unit token. Play a 2 [S] Sand Soldier unit token.â€ ğŸ“
746.2.
When a spellâ€™s effect is performed an additional time with Repeat, choices must be made at the usual time during the Make Relevant Choices step of Playing a Card. See rule 346 Playing Cards for more information. ğŸ“
746.2.a.
Choices made for the additional execution do not have to be the same as the choices made for the initial execution. Example: Rocket Barrage is a spell with [Repeat] [4][C] and â€œChoose one â€” Deal 4 to a unit in a base. [or] Kill a gear.â€ If Rocket Barrageâ€™s controller pays its Repeat cost as they play it, they may choose the same mode or a different one, and if they choose the same mode, may choose the same target or a different one. If they choose â€œKill a gearâ€ twice and choose two different gear, they must specify which gear is the ï¬rst target and which is the second. As the spell resolves, those two gear will be killed in the chosen order. ğŸ“
746.3.
Multiple instances of Repeat can be paid for separately. The spellâ€™s instructions will be executed an additional time for each instance of Repeat that is paid for. ğŸ“
746.3.a.
Regardless of the number of times a spell's instructions are executed with this keyword, the spell is only Played once. ğŸ“
746.4.
Repeat, and whether or not a spell has Repeat, is a characteristic of the Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“
747.
Weaponmaster ğŸ“
747.1.
Weaponmaster is a Triggered Ability keyword. ğŸ“
747.1.a.
Weaponmaster is present on Units. ğŸ“
747.1.b.
Weaponmaster is a Play Effect that chooses an Equipment you control and allows you to pay its Equip cost at a discount, regardless of the usual timing of the Equip ability, to Attach that Equipment to the unit with Weaponmaster. ğŸ“
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information. ğŸ“
747.1.c.1.
Weaponmaster can choose an Equipment whether it has an Equip ability or not. ğŸ“
747.1.c.2.
The cost of the Equip ability is determined as though that Equip ability was being activated choosing the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, as modulated by any abilities that alter Equip costs. ğŸ“
747.1.c.3.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost does not contain [A], it can still be paid, but will not be reduced. ğŸ“
747.1.c.4.
If the chosen card doesnâ€™t have an Equip cost, it canâ€™t be paid. ğŸ“
747.1.c.5.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost canâ€™t be paid, if it canâ€™t be detached from its current Top-Most card, or if it canâ€™t be attached to the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, it stays in its current location, Attached to anything it was already Attached to. ğŸ“
747.1.c.6.
The Equip ability is not activated this way, and the unit with the Weaponmaster ability is not chosen. ğŸ“
747.2.
Multiple instances of Weaponmaster trigger separately, and can choose different targets. ğŸ“
747.2.a.
If you choose the same target with multiple instances of Weaponmaster, each will resolve separately. ğŸ“
747.3.
Weaponmaster has no function while on the board. ğŸ“
747.4.
Weaponmaster, and whether or not a unit has Weaponmaster, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects. ğŸ“

References

A
A Main Deck Of At Least 40 Cards
103.2.
A Main Deck of at least 40 cards 1 Chosen Champion Unit Units Gear Spells
A Top-most Card
717.
Attaching is a limited action that causes cards to become linked to each other to combine their effects in some way. This causes one card to become Attached and the other to become A Top-Most Card. See rule 421 Attach for more information.
Abilities
134.2.a.
Abilities
134.2.a.1.
Abilities are discrete pieces of text that describe what a card may or must do. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
135.2
Effect Text can contain additional Abilities.
160.2.
A Basic Rune always has the following two Abilities:
162.2.
Players must ï¬rst add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs.
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information.
184.6.
Control of a Battleï¬eld determines Control of its Abilities.
184.6.a.
While a Battleï¬eld is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
185.4.
For Abilities, they are the Abilityâ€™s Controller.
185.4.a.
By default, the Controller of an Abilityâ€™s Source is the Controller of that Ability.
185.4.b.
Changes to Control of an Abilityâ€™s Source do not change Control of that Ability.
327.2.
Abilities are queued here as part of the process of resolving. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
344.2.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
357.
Abilities
358.
An Ability is the structured rules and capabilities of Game Objects or Spells.
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
359.
A card can have more than one Ability and more than one type of Ability.
370.2.a.
Declare activation of the Ability.
376.3.b.
If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain.
376.4.b.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action.
376.4.c.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action.
383.
Delayed Abilities are a type of Ability whose trigger Condition identiï¬es a speciï¬c time during a turn or a speciï¬c event that can occur during a speciï¬c timeframe.
383.1.
Delayed Abilities can be any other type of Ability, and contain all of the properties of that type in addition to the properties of Delayed Abilities.
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.
387.
Playing or activating Abilities follows the same steps of playing cards.
388.
Abilities when added to the Chain become Pending Items until they complete the steps of Playing.
388.1.
When an Ability ï¬nishes the steps of playing it becomes a Chain Item just like a Spell.
388.2.
When an Ability with the [Add] action is ï¬nalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item, like a Unit or Gear.
389.
1. Activate or trigger the Ability
389.1.
Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
390.3.a.
This is not an Ability being countered.
391.1.
Determine the base cost of the Ability.
392.2.a.
This is not an Ability being countered.
406.4.
Some Abilities trigger when cards are played or otherwise check whether cards have been played.
415.5.d.
Abilities originating from Game Objects that are responsible for Kill Actions are responsible in addition to the Game Object that created them. Example: Falling Star is a spell that says â€œDo this twice: Deal 3 to a unit.â€ Immortal Phoenix is a unit that says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ A player plays Falling Star while Immortal Phoenix is in their trash. The â€œdo thisâ€ phrasing on Falling Star means that it has a reï¬‚exive triggered ability, which places two triggered abilities on the chain. As each of those triggered abilities resolve, it deals damage to the unit chosen for that ability. If one of these abilities deals lethal damage to a unit, both Falling Star and its ability are considered sources of the damage, and so both Falling Star and its ability are responsible for killing the unit. This means that Falling Starâ€™s controller killed a unit with a spell, so Immortal Phoenixâ€™s ability will trigger.
427.
Spells, Abilities, or other effects may cause a Move to occur.
443.1.d.7.
If a Unit has one or more Abilities or effects applying to it that demand it be assigned damage in a speciï¬c way that is exclusionary, then the assigning player chooses only one of those abilities to apply when assigning damage. Example: Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last.") has been given the Tank ability ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."). A player is assigning damage to this Caitlyn with Tank and two units with no abilities. That player canâ€™t fulï¬ll both of Caitlynâ€™s damage requirements, so they may choose to assign damage to Caitlyn ï¬rst, fulï¬lling the Tank requirement, or last, fulï¬lling Caitlynâ€™s printed requirement. They canâ€™t choose to apply damage to Caitlyn in between the other two units, because that wouldnâ€™t fulï¬ll either requirement.
454.2.c.
Abilities of Effect Text of Attached cards are appended in this layer.
718.3.
While in this state, Abilities in the cardâ€™s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card.
Abilityâ€™s
393.1.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s targets are still legal.
393.2.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s effect would not create an illegal state. If it would, resolve in the same way you would resolve a Card that creates an illegal state. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
394.1.
This Ability is no longer Pending.
394.2.
This Ability becomes a Chain Item.
394.5.
Otherwise, execute the Ability just like a Spell, then clear the Chain Item from the Chain.
727.
A Keyword is a speciï¬c term that appears on Cards that acts as a shorthand for a speciï¬c game effect, or ability of any variety.
732.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Action is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Reaction is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
Abilityâ€™s Controller
185.4.
For Abilities, they are the Abilityâ€™s Controller.
Abilityâ€™s Source
185.4.a.
By default, the Controller of an Abilityâ€™s Source is the Controller of that Ability.
185.4.b.
Changes to Control of an Abilityâ€™s Source do not change Control of that Ability.
Accelerate
142.4.a.
This can be altered by Accelerate or similar game effects. See rule 731. Accelerate for more information.
731.
Accelerate
Action Phase
143.1.a.
This action can be done any time during a player's Action Phase.
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
155.2.a.
Action
155.2.b.1.
Grants all cases and rules of Action.
308.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Action or Reaction keywords can be played or activated in a Showdown State.
312.2.a.
When the turn is in a Neutral Open State during their Action Phase.
313.1.a.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed. Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords.
316.
Action Phase
316.1.
When all steps of the Start of Turn have been completed, the Action Phase begins.
316.2.
The Action Phase has no deï¬ned structure.
316.2.b.1.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction.
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
316.6.a.
This ends the Action Phase.
732.
Action
739.1.b.
Reaction grants the corresponding card or effect all abilities and permissions of Action.
Activate Abilities
334.1.b.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
344.2.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
Activated Abilities
144.
Units may have Activated Abilities.
144.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
148.
Gear may have Activated Abilities.
148.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
170.8.
Legends can have Activated Abilities. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
370.
Activated Abilities are repeatable effects with a cost. They follow a process of going onto the chain and resolving, similar to Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
370.1.
Activated Abilities are recognized by the presence of a ":" in the text of the card, preceded by a cost and succeeded by an effect. Example: "[2]: Draw 1" is an activated ability. The cost is 2 energy. The effect is to draw 1 card.
370.2.
Activated Abilities use the chain.
370.2.b.3.
If no further action is taken, execute the Activated Ability.
371.
The controlling player chooses when and whether to activate an Activated Ability.
374.
All Activated Abilities can only be activated on the Controlling Player's Turn and during an Open State.
376.3.
When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain.
390.2.
If legal options are not available for an Activated Ability, it is not legal to activate it.
391.1.a.
Activated Abilities will have a cost listed before the â€œ:â€ in their text.
744.1.
Equip is an Activated Ability keyword.
744.1.c.1.
If paying costs or making choices for this ability causes triggered abilities to trigger, they will be placed on the chain above this ability in a Pending state. See rule 369 Activated Abilities for more information.
744.4.
Multiple instances of Equip are equivalent to multiple Activated Abilities and can each be activated separately by paying the corresponding costs.
Active
415.1.a.
This can be Active or Passive.
415.1.a.1.
Active Kill is when the action is taken when instructed by a game effect or as a cost for a card or ability.
Active Player
332.1.
The player that created the chain becomes the ï¬rst Active Player.
332.2.
The Active Player is a designator similar to, but distinct from, Turn Player.
333.1.c.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute.
334.1.
The Active Player may do any the following:
334.1.a.5.
This can be an additional card to the item that Started the Chain in the case of the ï¬rst Active Player after creating the Chain.
334.1.c.1.
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass.
335.2.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute.
336.4.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute.
Add Reactions
416.3.
Activated abilities that Add resources and have the Reaction tag can be activated during the playing or resolution of other spells and abilities, any time that those spells or abilities require that resources be paid. Example: A player can add Energy and Power through any means before initiating the process of playing a spell. After initiating that process, in the Pay Costs step, they may activate Add Reactions to add Energy or Power to pay costs.
Added
134.2.e.5.b.
When Added to a playerâ€™s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain.
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information.
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
416.
Add
416.1.
Adding is the action of putting resources into a player's Rune Pool.
416.2.
Spells, triggered abilities, and activated abilities that Add resources ï¬nalize immediately.
416.2.a.
Priority and Focus will not pass from Add abilities being ï¬nalized, and will resolve before any other outstanding items on the chain are ï¬nalized.
416.3.
Activated abilities that Add resources and have the Reaction tag can be activated during the playing or resolution of other spells and abilities, any time that those spells or abilities require that resources be paid. Example: A player can add Energy and Power through any means before initiating the process of playing a spell. After initiating that process, in the Pay Costs step, they may activate Add Reactions to add Energy or Power to pay costs.
416.4.
Adding is a Limited Action.
416.4.a.
Players may only Add resources when Game Effects direct them to do so.
Additional Costs
353.2.a.1.
Some Additional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Mandatory, and must be paid to complete playing the card. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and don't include the word "may." Example: A unit has the passive ability "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." To play that unit, a player must kill a friendly unit. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
746.1.c.1.
The Cost is an Additional Cost to be paid during the steps of playing the spell.
All Effects Operating On Objects Have Been Applied Once
453.
The layers are applied repeatedly until all effects operating on objects have been applied once and no changes have been processed.
All Forms Of Closed State
155.2.b.2.
In addition to all prior cases, may also be played during all forms of Closed State.
Assault
733.
Assault
At Any Time
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
Attached
134.4.
A cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
135.2.b
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
135.2.c
The abilities in the Effect Text section of a card are appended to the Rules Text of the card to which the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
136.3
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
136.3.a
The Might Bonus is applied while Attached and stops applying as soon as the card with the Might Bonus is no longer Attached.
136.3.b
If the card to which a card with a Might Bonus is Attached has no Might value, the Might Bonus is ignored.
421.
Attach
421.1.
Attaching is the act of linking two cards on the board together to combine their effects in some way. This causes one or more cards to become Attached and at least one card to become a Top-Most Card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
421.1.a.
Attaching affects two cards at once.
421.1.a.1.
One card will be designated as the one being Attached, and thus become Attached. The other will become the Top-Most Card.
421.1.b.
This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached.
421.1.b.1.
In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card, they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects.
421.1.c.
The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text.
421.1.d.
The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it.
421.1.e.
Attaching one or more cards will cause those cardsâ€™ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
421.1.f.
Attaching a card will cause it to Detach from any card to which it is currently Attached.
421.2.
Attaching is a Limited Action.
421.2.a.
Players may only Attach cards when directed to by Game Effects.
421.3.
Attaching cards does not inherently choose or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Attach cards may do so.
422.1.
Detaching is the act of unlinking two cards that are currently linked through the act of Attaching. This causes one to cease being Attached, and potentially causes the other to cease being a Top-Most card.
422.1.a.
Detaching affects only cards that are currently Attached to another card.
422.1.a.1.
Game effects that instruct a player to Detach a card that is currently not Attached to anything will do nothing.
422.1.b.
When one or more cards become Detached, they cease to be in the Attached state.
422.1.b.2.
If the Top-Most Card no longer has any cards Attached to it after this, it is no longer a Top-Most Card.
422.4.b.
If the Attached card was Detached because the Top-Most Card changed zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, then the location that the Attached Card will Detach to is the last location the Top-Most Card was at before changing from a board zone to a non-board zone.
454.2.c.
Abilities of Effect Text of Attached cards are appended in this layer.
454.3.c.
Might Bonuses of Attached cards are applied in this layer.
717.
Attaching is a limited action that causes cards to become linked to each other to combine their effects in some way. This causes one card to become Attached and the other to become A Top-Most Card. See rule 421 Attach for more information.
718.
Attached is the state of a card being linked to another card in this way.
718.5.
Attached cards still have all properties of being a card on the board while in this state.
718.5.a.
Attached cards still have all Types and Tags while Attached.
718.5.b.
Attached cards still can be chosen or targeted by game effects while Attached.
718.6.
Attached cards cannot be moved separately from the Top-Most Card they are Attached to.
718.7.
A card may be Attached only to a single Top-Most card at a time.
718.8.
Attached cards may have different Controllers from their Top-Most card.
718.8.a.
Changes in Control of the Top-Most card do not impact Control of Attached cards and vice versa.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
719.
A Top-Most Card is a card that has one or more cards linked to it through the process of Attaching.
719.1.
The Effect Text of all cards Attached to this card are appended to the Rules Text of this card for as long as they remain Attached.
719.2.
This card ceases being a Top-Most Card when there are no longer any cards Attached to it.
719.3.
A Top-Most Card and all cards Attached to it are at the same location.
719.3.a.
When the Top-Most Card moves, all Attached cards move with it.
719.4.
The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa.
719.5.
When a Top-Most Card changes zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, all Attached cards Detach from it, remaining in their current zones.
724.
Effect Text is Inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.
725.3.
If an Attached card has an Equip ability, the Weaponmaster keyword can reference that Equip ability and any abilities that passively modify that Equip ability.
744.1.b.2.
The chosen Unit will become the Top-Most Card for the Attach action.
744.1.c.2.
Equip is functionally short for â€œ[Cost]: Attach this gear to a unit you control.â€
744.2.
When the Attach action completes from this keyword, the Unit that was chosen is considered to have been Equipped by the Gear with this ability.
744.3.
Equipped is the state of a Top-Most Card being Attached by one or more cards that are Equipment.
744.3.a.
The state of being Equipped is synchronous with that of the Attached state of the Equipment.
744.3.b.
A Top-Most Card is Equipped as long as one or more of its Attached cards are Equipment.
744.3.c.
The state of being Equipped corresponds to a Top-Most card having a card with Equip that is Attached to it.
745.1.c.
Quick-Draw allows cards to be played and Attached using Reaction timing.
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.b.
Weaponmaster is a Play Effect that chooses an Equipment you control and allows you to pay its Equip cost at a discount, regardless of the usual timing of the Equip ability, to Attach that Equipment to the unit with Weaponmaster.
747.1.c.5.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost canâ€™t be paid, if it canâ€™t be detached from its current Top-Most card, or if it canâ€™t be attached to the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, it stays in its current location, Attached to anything it was already Attached to.
Attaches
421.4.
When a card Attaches to a card, its location becomes the same as the new Top-Most Card.
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.
744.1.b.
Equip has a cost to activate and Attaches the card with Equip to a chosen Unit when the cost is paid.
Attachment
107.5.j.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Attachment.
134.4.
A cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
135.2.b
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
136.3
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
421.1.
Attaching is the act of linking two cards on the board together to combine their effects in some way. This causes one or more cards to become Attached and at least one card to become a Top-Most Card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
421.1.e.
Attaching one or more cards will cause those cardsâ€™ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
716.
Attachment
744.5.
