Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
Attack Triggers
376.4.d.
Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
Attacker
322.5.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
345.2.b.1.
The player who applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat.
376.4.d.
Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.d.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Attacker designation multiple times in the same combat.
442.1.a.
Establish who is Attacker and who is Defender.
442.1.a.1.
The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Attacker designation now.
442.1.a.3.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Attacker gain the Attacker designation now.
442.1.a.3.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
443.1.a.
The Combat Damage Step only occurs if both Attacking and Defending units remain at the location.
443.1.d.
Starting with the Attacker, each player assigns an amount of damage equal to their summed Might among the other's Units.
Attacker Designation
442.1.a.1.
The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Attacker designation now.
Attacking Units
443.1.a.1.
If neither Attacking Units nor Defending Units remain at this stage, the Combat Damage Step is skipped.
443.1.b.
Sum the Might of all Attacking Units.
B
Back Side
128.
Back Side
Banishing
414.1.
Banishing is the action of placing a card from any zone to Banishment. See rule 107.5. Banishment for more information.
414.2.
When a card is Banished it is placed directly into the Banishment zone from its origin.
414.4.
Banishing is a Limited Action.
414.4.a.
Players may only Banish cards or permanents when Game Effects direct them to do so.
652.1.
Banish all permanents and runes they currently control and all permanents and runes they own.
Banishment
107.5.
Banishment
107.5.f.
The cards in any player's Banishment are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
414.
Banish
414.1.
Banishing is the action of placing a card from any zone to Banishment. See rule 107.5. Banishment for more information.
414.2.
When a card is Banished it is placed directly into the Banishment zone from its origin.
Base
106.2.
The Base
106.2.d.
Other players cannot have Game Objects they control in another player's Base.
106.2.e.
The Base also houses each player's Runes that are on The Board.
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base.
143.4.a.
Units may move from their Base to a Battleï¬eld.
143.4.b.
Units may move from a Battleï¬eld to their Base.
146.1.a.1.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
147.2.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
147.3.
If a Gear is at a Battleï¬eld for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
352.2.a
By default, Valid locations include the controllerâ€™s Base or a Battleï¬eld the controller controls.
356.2.d.
If it is a Gear, it enters the Board Ready at the player's Base.
433.
A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move.
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.
440.2.b.
Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base, where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting.
Base Cost(s)
353.1.
If an ability or instruction allows you to "ignore" one or more of a card's costs, set the appropriate Base Cost(s) of the card to zero.
353.1.c.
Further additional costs and/or cost increases applied in subsequent steps may raise the card's Total Cost above zero. Example: Legion Rearguard is a Fury unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and has Accelerate. A player plays Legion Rearguard and is instructed to ignore its costs, but chooses to pay the Accelerate cost. They ignore Legion Rearguard's Base Cost of 2 Energy, but the optional additional cost of 1 Energy and 1 Fury Power is added to its Total Cost and must be paid.
Basic Runes
160.
Basic Runes
160.1.
There are six Basic Runes, each with a Domain corresponding to its name: Fury Rune Calm Rune Mind Rune Body Rune Chaos Rune Order Rune
160.2.
A Basic Rune always has the following two Abilities:
Battleï¬elds
103.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battleï¬elds determined by the Mode of Play.
103.4.
Battleï¬elds
103.4.c.
Cannot include more than one of a Battleï¬eld of the same name when there are more than one required for the deck.
106.3.
The Battleï¬eld Zone
106.3.a.
Multiple Battleï¬elds will be here, typically one per player, but occasionally less.
106.3.b.
The space where Battleï¬elds are located during gameplay.
106.3.c.
Each Battleï¬eld is individually a Location.
106.4.c.
Cards can only be placed in or occupy the Facedown Zone if the controller of the card also controls the associated Battleï¬eld.
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information.
113.
Each player sets aside their Battleï¬elds.
113.1.
Your Mode of Play will dictate how these are used and placed into the Battleï¬eld Zone. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
128.2.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battleï¬elds and Champion Legends.
132.6.a.
Battleï¬elds
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base.
143.4.a.
Units may move from their Base to a Battleï¬eld.
143.4.a.1.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present.
143.4.b.
Units may move from a Battleï¬eld to their Base.
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
147.3.
If a Gear is at a Battleï¬eld for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
165.
Battleï¬elds
166.
Battleï¬elds are Game Objects.
166.1.
Battleï¬elds are Owned by a player.
166.2.
Battleï¬elds are not shufï¬‚ed into Decks at the start of a game.
166.2.a.
Battleï¬elds are not played during the course of regular play.
166.2.b.
Battleï¬elds are established at the start of a game and remain in place for the duration of regular play.
166.3.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
166.4.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Moved.
166.5.
Battleï¬elds are Locations.
166.5.a.
Battleï¬elds can be Origins of moves.
166.5.b.
Battleï¬elds can be Destinations of moves.
166.6.
Any number of Units can be present at a Battleï¬eld.
166.7.
Battleï¬elds can be targeted by spells or game effects.
166.8.
Battleï¬elds can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
166.9.
Battleï¬elds can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
167.
Battleï¬elds are not Permanents.
168.
The number of Battleï¬elds on the Board is determined by the Mode of Play.
184.
Battleï¬elds
184.1.
Control is established over Battleï¬elds through the course of play.
184.2.
Control is a binary state for Battleï¬elds and an Identiï¬er for players.
184.2.a.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled or Uncontrolled.
184.2.b.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled by a speciï¬c player or Controlled by no one.
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
184.3.b.
A Battleï¬eld remains Contested until Control is established or re-established.
184.3.c.
While a Battleï¬eld remains Contested, Control of a Battleï¬eld cannot change.
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
184.4.
Control is established by having Units at a Battleï¬eld at the end of a Showdown or Combat after applying the contested status.
184.4.a.
If a player controls Units at a Battleï¬eld, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battleï¬eld for as long as they have Units at that Battleï¬eld.
184.4.b.
A player maintains control of a Battleï¬eld while it is being Contested by an opponent.
184.4.c.
If a player has no Units at a Battleï¬eld, they lose Control of that Battleï¬eld immediately, unless it is Contested.
184.6.
Control of a Battleï¬eld determines Control of its Abilities.
184.6.a.
While a Battleï¬eld is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
316.4.a.
A Combat phase occurs as a result of Units controlled by opposing players being present at the same Battleï¬eld.
316.5.b.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battleï¬eld when the Contested status is applied to a Battleï¬eld with no current controller.
316.5.b.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of a player moving to an empty Battleï¬eld are a stand-alone Phase and do not create a Combat.
322.5.a.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now
322.5.b.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but have the opposite designation of their controller, they lose that designation, and gain the same designation as their controller now
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
322.6.
4. Battleï¬elds with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled.
322.7.
5. Recall all Gear at Battleï¬elds. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battleï¬elds that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash.
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
322.8.a
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battleï¬eld that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested
322.9
6a. If Units of an opposing player are present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Showdown staged before it can be Opened, the Showdown will cease being Staged
322.10.
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players.
322.10.a.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battleï¬eld as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there.
322.11
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there.
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there.
340.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State.
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested.
341.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battleï¬eld gains Focus.
345.2.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Contested being applied to a Battleï¬eld without a controller, do one of the following:
345.2.a.
If only one playerâ€™s Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, and if that player does not already Control the Battleï¬eld, that player establishes Control over the Battleï¬eld. See rule 179. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
345.2.a.1.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn.
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
345.2.b.1.
The player who applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat.
352.2.a
By default, Valid locations include the controllerâ€™s Base or a Battleï¬eld the controller controls.
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
398.1.b.3.
As long as it does not result in any forbidden action being taken or game state being created. Example: A player can't use the Standard Move discretionary action to move a unit to a Battleï¬eld that's already occupied by Units controlled by two other players.
408.1.
Hiding a card is the act of placing a card facedown at a Battleï¬eld you control.
408.3.
Cards that are facedown at Battleï¬elds have their gameplay properties and permissions deï¬ned by the effect that put them there. Example: Cards that players Hide with the Hidden keyword can be Played for [0] on any subsequent turn as a property of the Hidden keyword.
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
427.2.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present by any means.
428.
The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleï¬eld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved.
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
439.
Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleï¬eld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated.
439.1.
If more than one Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ï¬rst.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.
442.1.a.1.
The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Attacker designation now.
442.1.a.2.
The Defender is the player who did not apply the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Defender designation now.
442.1.a.3.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
442.1.a.4.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
444.1.a.2.
Insert â€œ2d. Recall Attackers present at the Battleï¬eld if Defenders are still present.â€ See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
444.2.b.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn. See rule 182. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
444.2.c.
This does not have to be the player that applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld.
444.2.d.
If there are no Units remaining here controlled by any player, the Battleï¬eld becomes Uncontrolled.
446.1.
Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleï¬eld they did not yet Score this turn.
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
446.1.b.
A player will gain control of a Battleï¬eld after establishing Control by applying Contested ï¬rst.
446.2.
Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleï¬eld during their Beginning Phase.
447.
A player may only Score, from either method, once per Battleï¬eld per turn.
448.1.b.2.
If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleï¬eld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point. If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleï¬eld this turn, that player draws a card.
448.2.
Trigger Score abilities at the Battleï¬eld that Scored.
448.2.a.
Conquer abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Conquered.
448.2.b.
Hold abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Held.
448.2.c.
These will only trigger when the Battleï¬eld is Scored; I.E. These cannot be triggered more than once per turn for a player.
460.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: Determines how many Battleï¬elds are in play, contributed by players, during play.
460.4.b.
This may involve utilizing less Battleï¬elds than there are players.
462.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 2
462.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup.
462.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone.
463.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 2
463.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building. Only 1 will be used, chosen during setup.
463.5.
Setup: Each player selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are set aside and will not be used for this round of play. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone. After this game, the Battleï¬elds that were used are to be removed and not selected again for this Match. One of the remaining Battleï¬elds that were set aside must be chosen instead.
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
464.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3
464.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are discarded and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the three Players before play and will be used for this game.
465.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3
465.4.a.
Each player provides three (3) Battleï¬elds, included in their deck during deck building.
465.4.b.
The player who is taking the ï¬rst turn removes their Battleï¬elds. They will not be used.
465.5.
Setup: Each player who is not going ï¬rst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game.
466.4.
Battleï¬eld Count: 3
466.4.a.
Each player provides one (1) Battleï¬eld, included in their deck during deck building.
466.4.b.
The player who is taking the ï¬rst turn removes their Battleï¬elds. They will not be used.
466.5.a.
Each player who is not going ï¬rst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game.
466.8.b.
Battleï¬elds controlled during the Beginning Phase of a player's turn by that player's teammate are disqualiï¬ed from being scored by that Team, that turn. Example: A player may not induce their partner to retreat, and then conquer a Battleï¬eld their teammate was controlling.
466.8.c.1.
Players may not Hide cards at Battleï¬elds controlled by their Teammate.
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase.
466.8.h.
Teammates may not utilize the same Battleï¬elds.
652.2.
Remove the Battleï¬eld they contributed to the game if it is in use.
Becoming Invalid
356.3.e.9.
The process for a card's choice becoming Invalid or Unavailable is referred to as mistargeting. Example: A spell has the instruction "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld." Before that instruction can execute, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The instruction will not be executed, because it speciï¬es that the unit it chooses must be at a Battleï¬eld, and by the time it attempted to execute, the unit was no longer valid as a choice.
Beginning Phase
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
398.2.b.
These actions can only be taken when a player is instructed to do so as the execution of an effect or during their speciï¬ed occasion during the turn. Example: A player may Draw during the Draw Step of the Beginning Phase of their turn or when instructed to do so by a spell or ability. They can't choose to Draw at any other time.
400.2.a.
Each player draws 1 during the Draw Step of their Beginning Phase.
402.3.a.
A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn.
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
446.2.
Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleï¬eld during their Beginning Phase.
466.8.b.
Battleï¬elds controlled during the Beginning Phase of a player's turn by that player's teammate are disqualiï¬ed from being scored by that Team, that turn. Example: A player may not induce their partner to retreat, and then conquer a Battleï¬eld their teammate was controlling.
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase.
Board
106.
The Play Area includes a space for Game Objects referred to as The Board.
106.1.
The Board is divided into several Zones.
106.2.e.
The Base also houses each player's Runes that are on The Board.
133.2.d.
Body is associated with the color orange and represented by a blocky diamond-shaped symbol. Its shorthand is [O].
140.1.a.
While on the Board:
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base.
140.1.a.2.
Units and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
140.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being a Unit, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that target Units on the Board.
146.1.a.
While on the Board.
146.1.a.2.
Gear and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
146.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being Gear, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that affect Gear on the Board.
157.1.a.
This means, despite remaining on the Board until Recycled or otherwise removed from the board, it is not a Permanent.
168.
The number of Battleï¬elds on the Board is determined by the Mode of Play.
356.2.d.
If it is a Gear, it enters the Board Ready at the player's Base.
362.1.
Passive Abilities of Permanents are typically only active while on the Board.
363.1.
Passive Abilities of cards in zones that are outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The passive ability "Play me only during an opponent's turn." applies in any zone from which that card can be played.
373.
Can primarily be activated while on the Board.
377.1.
Typically active while on the Board.
377.2.
Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board.
378.1.
Triggered Abilities on cards outside of the Board rely on the Information Level of the zone they are in.
378.2.
Triggered Abilities outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The triggered ability "When you conquer, you may discard 1 to return this from your trash to your hand." triggers while the card it's on is in the trash, and not anywhere else.
407.1.
Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board.
410.1.
Stunning is the act of selecting one or more Units on the Board and rendering them Stunned.
424.1.
A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move, unless it is caused by a corrective Recall. See rule 407. Move for more information.
727.3.a.3.
If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
727.3.b.2.
If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
Board Exhausted
142.4.
Units enter the Board exhausted.
356.2.c.
If it is a Unit, it enters the Board exhausted at the Location that was chosen.
Bonus Damage
404.4.
Dealing can have the intrinsic property of Bonus Damage.
404.5.
Bonus Damage is a property granted to the action of Dealing and alters the amount of Damage distributed by this action. See rule 712. Bonus Damage for more information.
712.
Bonus Damage
713.
Bonus Damage is an intrinsic property that can be granted to Deal actions that inï¬‚uence the amount of Damage that the action is distributing.
714.
If more than one instance of Bonus Damage is applied or granted to a Deal action, all instances are summed and applied once.
714.2.
If, for any reason, Bonus Damage would be a negative number, then no Bonus Damage is applied to the action.
715.1.
If the Deal action has a single target, the amount of Damage to that target will be increased by the Bonus Damage granted to it.
715.2.
If the Deal action has multiple targets, the amount of Damage dealt to each target is increased by Bonus Damage individually and separately. Example: Singularity is a spell that says â€œDeal 6 to each of up to two units.â€ A player plays Singularity while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Singularity deals 1 Bonus Damage to both of its targets, dealing 7 to each.
715.3.
If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split. This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen. Example: Volibear, Furious is a unit that says in part â€œWhen I attack, deal 5 damage split among any number of enemy units here.â€ A player attacks with Volibear, Furious while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Volibear, Furious now deals 6 damage split among any number of enemy units at its location, and can choose to split that damage among up to 6 units rather than the usual 5.
Buff Counter
413.1.b.
To Buff a unit, place a Buff Counter on it if it does not have one already
413.1.b.1.
If the unit already has a Buff Counter on it, it does not get another one.
413.1.c.
Units with Buff Counters can still be chosen for actions that Buff units, but will not be Buffed as part of the execution. Example: A spell reads "Buff a unit. Then, if it was buffed this way, draw a card." It will place a buff counter on a unit that has no buff counter, and then its controller will draw a card. However, if the player chooses a unit with a buff counter on it already, then the card will not be drawn.
Buffed
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
413.
Buff
413.1.
Bufï¬ng is the action of placing a Buff counter on a Unit. See rule 701. Buffs for more information.
413.1.a.
A Buff is also an object.
413.1.b.
To Buff a unit, place a Buff Counter on it if it does not have one already
413.1.c.
Units with Buff Counters can still be chosen for actions that Buff units, but will not be Buffed as part of the execution. Example: A spell reads "Buff a unit. Then, if it was buffed this way, draw a card." It will place a buff counter on a unit that has no buff counter, and then its controller will draw a card. However, if the player chooses a unit with a buff counter on it already, then the card will not be drawn.
413.2.a.
Players may only Buff units when Game Effects direct them to do so.
413.3.
This action is formatted as "Buff [one or more units]." e.g., "Buff a unit." e.g., "Buff a friendly unit." e.g., "Buff two friendly units at the same battleï¬eld."
701.
Buffs
702.
Buffs are objects placed on Units.
702.1.
Buffs can be tracked with a buff reminder card from a Riftbound booster pack or with any spare object in your surroundings.
702.2.
Buffs can be added or spent.
702.2.a.
To Buff a Unit, a player chooses a Unit and then places a buff on it. That Unit is Buffed for as long as the buff remains on it.
702.2.b.
Spending a Buff removes a single Buff counter from a Unit.
702.3.
There can only be one Buff on a Unit at a time.
702.3.a.
If a Buff is added, or instructed to be added, on a Unit that already has a Buff, it is not placed instead.
703.
Each Buff individually contributes +1 Might to a Unit.
704.
Buffs are Game Objects and may be referenced, counted, or targeted by other effects as speciï¬ed.
705.
If a Unit leaves play, remove all Buffs from it.
705.1.
Champions do not retain Buffs in the Champion Zone, even if they return there somehow.
Bufï¬ng
413.1.
Bufï¬ng is the action of placing a Buff counter on a Unit. See rule 701. Buffs for more information.
413.2.
Bufï¬ng is a Limited Action.
Burn Out
315.4.b.1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
315.4.b.2.
After completing the Burn Out the Turn Player still Draws 1.
400.4.b.
Perform a Burn Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
418.
Burn Out
418.1.c.
If an instruction directs a player to look at or reveal cards in excess to the number of cards in a playerâ€™s Main Deck, that player looks at or Reveals as many as possible, but does not Burn Out, then proceeds with the rest of the instruction.
418.1.c.1.
If there are insufï¬cient cards among the looked at or revealed cards to perform subsequent actions to the revealed or looked at cards, any further instructions are ignored. This does not cause a Burn Out, even if those instructions would cause those cards to change zones. Reminder: Cards are considered in the zone of origin while being looked at or revealed, in this case the Main Deck.
418.2.
To Burn Out, a player does the following in sequence:
418.3.
A player's Main Deck may remain empty as they Burn Out, usually because their trash is also empty. When they attempt to perform the original action again, it will cause another Burn Out.
Burned Out
315.4.b.1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
Burning Out
418.1.
Burning Out is an action a player must perform if they attempt to move one or more cards from their Main Deck to any other zone in excess of the number of cards remaining in their Main Deck:
418.4.
Burning Out is a Limited Action.
418.5.
Burning Out is a Replacement Effect. See rule 364. Replacement Effects for more information.
C
Calm
133.2.b.
Calm is associated with the color green and represented by a symbol resembling a leaf. Its shorthand is [G].
Card
052.
Card, when written in card effects, is shorthand for "Main Deck card." Runes, legends, and battleï¬elds are not considered cards when executing the abilities and effects of game objects. They are considered cards for the purposes of these rules.
124.
Cards
140.1.b.1.
Units are treated as Cards, similar to when in the Hand.
146.1.b.1.
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand.
157.
Rune is a Card Type.
185.1.
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.
334.1.a.
Play a Card that is legally timed.
334.1.a.1.
Cards, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
334.1.a.2.
A Legally Timed Card would be a Card with Reaction.
334.1.a.6.
Whether a Card is legally timed is evaluated during the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
393.2.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s effect would not create an illegal state. If it would, resolve in the same way you would resolve a Card that creates an illegal state. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
727.
A Keyword is a speciï¬c term that appears on Cards that acts as a shorthand for a speciï¬c game effect, or ability of any variety.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
Card Outside Of The Board
363.
Presence on Card outside of the Board
Cards Outside Of The Board
378.
Presence on Cards outside of the Board
Category
132.
Category
132.1.
A card can have one or more Categories and Sub-Categories based on the properties of its front and back sides.
132.2.
These Categories and Sub-Categories dictate the behaviors of the card during play.
132.7.
Supertypes are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed before a cardâ€™s type.
132.8.
Tags are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed after a cardâ€™s type.
Chain
184.6.a.
While a Battleï¬eld is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
305.
When there are no items on the Chain and the Turn Player cannot or chooses not to perform any Discretionary Actions, the current phase or step of the turn ends and the next phase, step, or turn begins.
309.1.
If a Chain exists, the turn is in a Closed State.
309.2.
If no Chain exists, the turn is in an Open State.
310.1.
Neutral Open: There is no Showdown in progress and no Chain exists.
310.2.
Neutral Closed: There is no Showdown in progress and a Chain exists.
310.3.
Showdown Open: A Showdown is in progress and no Chain exists.
310.4.
Showdown Closed: A Showdown is in progress and a Chain exists.
312.2.c.
When the turn is in a Closed State and they control the next item on the Chain.
319.3.
After a Pending Item becomes a Legal Item on the Chain
319.4.
After a Chain Item is removed from the Chain for any reason
320.
While a Cleanup is occurring, Chain Items cannot be Resolved.
322.12.
8. Finalize any Pending Items on the Chain
325.1.
During a Chain
327.
The Chain is a Non-Board Zone that temporarily exists whenever a card is played or an ability is activated.
328.
Cards and abilities added to the chain are added as Pending Chain Items that become Finalized Chain Items.
328.2.
Chain Items are Pending until the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
328.3.
When a Pending Chain Item is no longer Pending it is ï¬nalized and becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
329.
The Chain exists as long as a Chain Item is on it.
329.1.
Only one Chain can exist at a time.
329.2.
If a card would begin to be played while a Chain already exists, it is placed on the existing Chain.
330.
The State of the Turn is partially determined by whether or not the Chain currently exists.
330.1.
The turn is said to be in a Closed State if a Chain exists.
330.2.
The turn is said to be in an Open State if no Chain exists.
332.
Whenever a card or token is played or an ability is activated or triggered, a Chain is created.
333.1.
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain.
333.1.b.
Each Item is Finalized in the order it was appended to the Chain.
333.1.c.1.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
333.1.c.2.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, repeat Step 1.
333.1.c.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute.
334.1.a.5.
This can be an additional card to the item that Started the Chain in the case of the ï¬rst Active Player after creating the Chain.
335.1.
If all players have passed Priority without adding any items to the Chain, proceed to Step 4: Resolve.
336.1.
The newest item on the Chain resolves. Execute its game effects in their entirety. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information on resolving spells. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information on resolving abilities.
336.2.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
336.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, return to Step 1: Finalize.
336.4.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute.
338.1.
Each spell played this way creates a Chain as normal.
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
344.1.a.
The spell will start a Chain as normal.
351.
1. Remove the card from the zone you are playing it from and put it onto the Chain.
356.2.
A Permanent leaves the Chain and becomes a Game Object.
356.3.
A Spell lingers on the Chain.
356.3.a.
This card becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
356.3.b.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, then the controller of those Pending Items completes Steps 2 through 5 of Playing Cards for those items before continuing. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
356.3.c.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
370.2.b.
Proceed with executing the Chain.
376.3.
When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain.
376.3.a.
Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn.
376.3.b.
If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain.
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.
376.4.a.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ï¬nalized and enters the board.
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
380.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers are a type of Triggered Ability that create one or more Chain Items when their condition is met.
388.1.
When an Ability ï¬nishes the steps of playing it becomes a Chain Item just like a Spell.
388.2.
When an Ability with the [Add] action is ï¬nalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item, like a Unit or Gear.
390.3.
If there are not enough options to make legal choices for a Triggered Ability that has been put on the chain, remove it from the Chain now. It ceases to be a Pending Item but never becomes a Chain Item.
392.2.
At this stage, players may decline to pay for Triggered Abilities that have incurred a cost. If they do, the ability will cease being a Pending Item and be removed from the Chain. It never becomes a Chain Item.
394.2.
This Ability becomes a Chain Item.
394.4.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
394.5.
Otherwise, execute the Ability just like a Spell, then clear the Chain Item from the Chain.
424.3.c.
Moving does not use the Chain, nor is it able to be Reacted to.
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
442.1.d.
Players proceed with any play on the Chain as normal.
652.5.c.1.
If the removed player had Priority during a Chain, the next Player in order receives Priority.
652.5.c.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have passed Priority, then the most recent spell or ability on the Chain will resolve with Priority being re-established as appropriate for the state after the resolution of that spell or ability.
Chains And Showdowns
324.
Chains and Showdowns
Champion Legend
103.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battleï¬elds determined by the Mode of Play.
103.1.
1 Champion Legend
103.1.b.2.
Your deckâ€™s Domain Identity is dictated by the domains of your Champion Legend. In the default card frame, these domains appear as symbols in the legendâ€™s upper left corner.
103.2.a.2.
Must be a champion unit with a champion tag that matches the tag on your Champion Legend. Example: Loose Cannon has the tag Jinx. Therefore, a player could choose Jinx, Rebel or Jinx, Demolitionist as their Chosen Champion, because they also have the tag Jinx. Example: Tibbers has the tag Annie, but it is a signature unit, not a champion unit. It cannot be your Chosen Champion, even if your Champion Legend has the tag Annie.
103.2.d.
Your deck may only contain 3 total Signature cards that have the same Champion tag as your Champion Legend.
103.2.d.2.
All of the Signature cards must have the Champion tag that corresponds to the Champion Legend of the deck.
103.3.a.1.
Cards in this deck must be of the Domain Identity of your Champion Legend.
106.5.a.
The space for each player's Champion Legend.
106.5.c.
The Champion Legend here is a Game Object. See rule 119. Game Objects for more information.
106.5.d.
The Champion Legend cannot be removed, moved, or displaced from this zone.
111.
Each player separates their Champion Legend and places it in the Legend Zone.
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
128.2.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battleï¬elds and Champion Legends.
466.8.g.
Teammates may not utilize the same Champion Legend.
Champion Tags
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
Champion Unit
103.2.a.3.
A playerâ€™s Chosen Champion is both the speciï¬c card chosen for this slot during Deck Building and also any Champion Unit with the same name as the speciï¬c card selected for this speciï¬c slot during the course of play. Example: A player chose Jinx, Rebel as their Chosen Champion. One copy of Jinx, Rebel starts the game in their Chosen Champion zone. Any additional copies of Jinx, Rebel in their Main Deck, their hand, their trash, or on the board also count as their Chosen Champion for any game rules and effects that care about Chosen Champion status during the game.
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
705.1.
Champions do not retain Buffs in the Champion Zone, even if they return there somehow.
Champion Zone
103.2.a.1.
This will be placed in the Champion Zone at the start of the game.
103.2.d.3.
Signature cards are not Champion units and cannot be placed in the Champion Zone.
107.2.
The Champion Zone
112.
Each player separates their Chosen Champion and places it in the Champion Zone.
132.4.
Main Deck Cards begin the game in the Main Deck or (in the case of a Chosen Champion) the Champion Zone.
132.7.a.
Champion is a supertype that applies exclusively to units. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding. See rule 103.2.a. Chosen Champion for more information.
Channel Phase
462.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
463.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
464.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
465.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
466.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
Channeled
132.5.a.1.
A sub-category encompassing cards with the rune type. These are channeled rather than played. They remain on the board after being channeled, but they are not permanents, as they are not Main Deck cards.
315.3.b.
The Turn Player channels 2 runes from their Rune Deck. See rule 417. Channel for more information.
417.
Channel
417.1.
Channeling is the action of taking one or more Runes from the top of a player's Rune Deck and putting them on the board.
417.3.
Channeling is a Limited Action.
Chaos
133.2.e.
Chaos is associated with the color purple and represented by a hexagonal symbol with swirls emanating from its center. Its shorthand is [P].
Choice
352.4.a.
This does not include cards that affect one or more Game Objects based on criteria. Example: "Stun a unit at a battleï¬eld" is a Choice. Example: "Kill all gear" is not a Choice.
Choosing
107.5.i.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Choosing.
352.6.
When a card Chooses one or more speciï¬c Game Objects to affect, it is Targeted.
Chosen
352.14.d.
Each Target is valid, and contributes to Chosen triggers individually.
Chosen Champion
103.2.a.
Chosen Champion
103.2.a.2.
Must be a champion unit with a champion tag that matches the tag on your Champion Legend. Example: Loose Cannon has the tag Jinx. Therefore, a player could choose Jinx, Rebel or Jinx, Demolitionist as their Chosen Champion, because they also have the tag Jinx. Example: Tibbers has the tag Annie, but it is a signature unit, not a champion unit. It cannot be your Chosen Champion, even if your Champion Legend has the tag Annie.
103.2.a.3.
A playerâ€™s Chosen Champion is both the speciï¬c card chosen for this slot during Deck Building and also any Champion Unit with the same name as the speciï¬c card selected for this speciï¬c slot during the course of play. Example: A player chose Jinx, Rebel as their Chosen Champion. One copy of Jinx, Rebel starts the game in their Chosen Champion zone. Any additional copies of Jinx, Rebel in their Main Deck, their hand, their trash, or on the board also count as their Chosen Champion for any game rules and effects that care about Chosen Champion status during the game.
103.2.b.1.
This includes your Chosen Champion. Example: A deck could include Volibear, Furious as its Chosen Champion and still include 2 more copies of Volibear, Furious.
107.2.a.
The space each player puts their Chosen Champion at the start of the game.
107.2.b.
The Chosen Champion here cannot be returned to this zone by normal means.
107.2.b.1.
If a Chosen Champion is instructed to be returned to this zone, it can only do so if there is not a card already in this zone.
107.2.c.
The Chosen Champion can be played from here as normal, following the rules of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
112.
Each player separates their Chosen Champion and places it in the Champion Zone.
132.4.
Main Deck Cards begin the game in the Main Deck or (in the case of a Chosen Champion) the Champion Zone.
132.7.a.
Champion is a supertype that applies exclusively to units. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding. See rule 103.2.a. Chosen Champion for more information.
Cleanup
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information.
317.2.a.
Invoke an End of Turn Special Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information.
318.
Cleanups
319.
A Cleanup occurs at the following times:
320.
While a Cleanup is occurring, Chain Items cannot be Resolved.
321.
If an event occurs during a Cleanup that qualiï¬es for a Cleanup, another Cleanup will occur immediately after the ï¬rst completes, repeating until a Cleanup occurs with no new change in the gameâ€™s state.
322.
When a Cleanup occurs, the following steps occur in order:
323.
Special Cleanups are Cleanup steps invoked at speciï¬c times that have additional steps not present in a normal Cleanup.
323.1.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and deï¬ned by the sub-section that invokes it. Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section deï¬nes what steps are added to the Cleanup.
323.2.
If events during a Special Cleanup require another Cleanup, a normal Cleanup is invoked, not another iteration of the Special Cleanup.
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested.
344.3.a.1.
Perform a Cleanup.
415.4.
Killing can also be the result of resolving a Cleanup.
415.5.c.
When one or more Units is killed due to a Cleanup, the spell or ability that resolved immediately prior to that Cleanup that applied damage to the Unit or Units is responsible for that Kill action.
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.
431.
When a Move action is complete, perform a Cleanup.
435.1.
When an un-attached Gear is created or played at a battleï¬eld, or is at a battleï¬eld for any other reason, it is Recalled to its controller's base during the next Cleanup. Example: An Equipment is attached to a unit at a battleï¬eld, so the Equipment is present at that battleï¬eld. If the unit dies, the Equipment will be recalled during the next cleanup.
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
442.1.a.3.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
442.1.a.4.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
734.1.d.2.
The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup.
Closed State
143.1.b.
This action cannot be performed during a Closed State.
309.
At any given time, the turn is in either an Open State or a Closed State.
309.1.
If a Chain exists, the turn is in a Closed State.
309.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Reaction keyword can be played or activated in a Closed State.
312.2.c.
When the turn is in a Closed State and they control the next item on the Chain.
312.2.d.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes.
319.1.
After the game transitions to or from an Open or Closed state
330.1.
The turn is said to be in a Closed State if a Chain exists.
330.1.a.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
330.1.b.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
334.1.a.1.
Cards, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
370.2.a.1.
The ability goes on the chain but has no card to represent it, so players need to take note that it is now a Closed State.
376.3.a.
Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn.
389.1.
Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
739.1.c.1.
On Spells: "This can be played during Closed States on any player's turn."
739.1.c.2.
On Units: "This can be played during Closed States on any player's turn."
739.1.c.3.
On Rune, Legend, or Permanent Abilities: "This can be activated during Closed States on any player's turn."
739.2.
The corresponding card or effect with this keyword is not restricted to Closed States or Showdowns. This permission is inclusive of all other timings and options available to the ability as written, Action's permissions, or by default.
Closes The State
351.1.
This Closes the State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
Colored Highlight
727.2.
Keywords can be identiï¬ed by having a colored highlight behind them.
Combat
142.2.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects.
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
184.4.a.
If a player controls Units at a Battleï¬eld, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battleï¬eld for as long as they have Units at that Battleï¬eld.
316.4.
Combat
316.4.a.
A Combat phase occurs as a result of Units controlled by opposing players being present at the same Battleï¬eld.
316.4.c.
The source effect does not change the structure or ï¬‚ow of Combat once initiated.
316.4.d.
A Combat can only occur between two players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
316.5.a.
A Showdown occurs when a Combat occurs.
316.5.a.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of Combat are a Sub-Phase of Combat.
316.5.b.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of a player moving to an empty Battleï¬eld are a stand-alone Phase and do not create a Combat.
322.5.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress
322.5.a.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now
322.5.b.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but have the opposite designation of their controller, they lose that designation, and gain the same designation as their controller now
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
322.10.
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players.
322.10.a.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battleï¬eld as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there.
322.11
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there.
323.1.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and deï¬ned by the sub-section that invokes it. Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section deï¬nes what steps are added to the Cleanup.
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
342.1.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities.
342.1.b.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed.
345.1.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Combat, proceed with the remaining steps of Combat to resolve the phase. See rule 441. The Steps of Combat for more information.
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
345.2.b.1.
The player who applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
404.3.a.
Assigning Damage causes Damage to be dealt outside of being directed to Deal Damage. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
404.6.c.
Damage Dealt as a result of being assigned during Combat has the Units as its source.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
429.
Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move.
430.
Units may cause Combat when they Move.
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
437.
Combat
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
439.
Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleï¬eld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated.
439.1.
If more than one Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ï¬rst.
440.
Combat can only occur between Units controlled by exactly two players.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
440.3.
All choices that would result in a Combat occurring between more than two players simultaneously are invalid and ineligible to be completed.
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
733.1.d.
Being an attacker means the Unit has gained the Attacker designation during Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
740.1.d.
Being a defender means the Unit has gained the Defender designation during Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
Combat Cleanup
142.3.b.2.
During a Combat Cleanup. See rule 444.1.for more information about Combat Cleanups.
323.1.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and deï¬ned by the sub-section that invokes it. Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section deï¬nes what steps are added to the Cleanup.
444.1.
1. Perform a Combat Cleanup.
Combat Damage
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
443.1.a.
The Combat Damage Step only occurs if both Attacking and Defending units remain at the location.
443.1.a.1.
If neither Attacking Units nor Defending Units remain at this stage, the Combat Damage Step is skipped.
Combat In Progress
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.
Combat Special Cleanup
444.1.a.
Invoke a Combat Special Cleanup.
Combat Staged
322.11
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged
Combats In Progress
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
Concedes
466.6.a.1.
If one player Concedes, then the entire team loses.
649.
Conceding
Condition
376.
Triggered Abilities are repeatable effects that happen when a Condition is met.
376.2.
Triggered Abilities have a Condition and an Effect.
376.2.a.
The Condition follows the When.
376.2.b.
The Effect is the Instruction that follows the comma after the Condition.
376.2.c.
The Condition of a Trigger is evaluated after a potentially inciting event has been processed.
376.3.
When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain.
376.4.
Some Conditions are commonly used and structured in a way that explicitly deï¬nes their use and other properties of the Effect that is associated with it.
376.4.a.
Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board.
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.
377.2.
Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board.
380.3.
If present, the Condition of a Reï¬‚exive Trigger will follow the same format as a Triggered Ability.
Conditional Keyword
738.1.
Legion is a Conditional Keyword.
Conditional Passive Abilities
361.3.a.
Conditional Passive Abilities can be recognized by the occurrence of "if" or "while" as part of the statement of the ability. Example: "While I'm attacking or defending alone, I have +2 [M]." Example: "If an opponent controls a battleï¬eld, I enter ready."
Conquer Abilities
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.
448.2.a.
Conquer abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Conquered.
Conquer Effects
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Conquering is negated or replaced in any way, the Conquer Effect will still trigger.
Conquering
345.2.a.
If only one playerâ€™s Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, and if that player does not already Control the Battleï¬eld, that player establishes Control over the Battleï¬eld. See rule 179. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action.
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.b.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Conquering is negated or replaced in any way, the Conquer Effect will still trigger.
444.2.b.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn. See rule 182. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
446.1.
Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleï¬eld they did not yet Score this turn.
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
448.1.a.1.
Notably, points earned from sources that are not Conquer or Hold are not beholden to these restrictions.
448.1.b.2.
If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleï¬eld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point. If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleï¬eld this turn, that player draws a card.
448.2.a.
Conquer abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Conquered.
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase.
Contested
184.3.
Control can be Contested through the course of play.
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
184.3.b.
A Battleï¬eld remains Contested until Control is established or re-established.
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
184.4.b.
A player maintains control of a Battleï¬eld while it is being Contested by an opponent.
184.4.c.
If a player has no Units at a Battleï¬eld, they lose Control of that Battleï¬eld immediately, unless it is Contested.
316.5.b.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battleï¬eld when the Contested status is applied to a Battleï¬eld with no current controller.
322.6.
4. Battleï¬elds with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled.
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
322.8.a
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battleï¬eld that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested
322.10.
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players.
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested.
341.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battleï¬eld gains Focus.
345.2.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Contested being applied to a Battleï¬eld without a controller, do one of the following:
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
345.2.b.1.
The player who applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat.
428.
The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleï¬eld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved.
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
442.1.a.1.
The Attacker is the player whose unit(s) applied the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Attacker designation now.
442.1.a.2.
The Defender is the player who did not apply the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Defender designation now.
444.2.c.
This does not have to be the player that applied Contested to the Battleï¬eld.
446.1.b.
