A player will gain control of a Battleï¬eld after establishing Control by applying Contested ï¬rst.
Contested And The Turn Is In A Neutral Open State
340.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State.
Contested Battleï¬eld
442.1.a.3.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Attacker gain the Attacker designation now.
442.1.a.4.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Defender gain the Defender designation now.
Contested Status
444.2.a.
Clear the Contested Status.
Contested, Control
184.3.c.
While a Battleï¬eld remains Contested, Control of a Battleï¬eld cannot change.
Control
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information.
176.
A token's controller is the controller of the spell or ability that created it, unless the token's type innately determines control or that spell or ability speciï¬es that a different player is the token's controller.
182.
Control
183.
Control is the concept of a player having inï¬‚uence of a Game Object and applies differently to different card types.
184.1.
Control is established over Battleï¬elds through the course of play.
184.2.
Control is a binary state for Battleï¬elds and an Identiï¬er for players.
184.2.a.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled or Uncontrolled.
184.3.
Control can be Contested through the course of play.
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
184.3.b.
A Battleï¬eld remains Contested until Control is established or re-established.
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
184.4.
Control is established by having Units at a Battleï¬eld at the end of a Showdown or Combat after applying the contested status.
184.4.a.
If a player controls Units at a Battleï¬eld, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battleï¬eld for as long as they have Units at that Battleï¬eld.
184.4.c.
If a player has no Units at a Battleï¬eld, they lose Control of that Battleï¬eld immediately, unless it is Contested.
184.5.
Control is a constant state.
184.6.
Control of a Battleï¬eld determines Control of its Abilities.
184.6.a.
While a Battleï¬eld is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
184.6.c.
â€œYouâ€ in a battleï¬eldâ€™s abilities refers to the battleï¬eldâ€™s Controller, as does the implied â€œyouâ€ in instructions like â€œdraw 1.â€ If the battleï¬eld has no Controller, â€œyouâ€ refers to no one, and all such instructions are ignored.
185.1.
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.
185.2.
For Spells, they are the Spell's Controller.
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
185.4.a.
By default, the Controller of an Abilityâ€™s Source is the Controller of that Ability.
185.4.b.
Changes to Control of an Abilityâ€™s Source do not change Control of that Ability.
186.
When a game effect or rules text refers to the Controller of a speciï¬c object, it can be referring to either context interchangeably.
186.1.
The method of assignment of control is different, but the status of Control is the same across all Game Objects.
322.5.a.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now
340.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State.
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested.
345.2.a.
If only one playerâ€™s Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, and if that player does not already Control the Battleï¬eld, that player establishes Control over the Battleï¬eld. See rule 179. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
402.3.a.
A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn.
444.2.b.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battleï¬eld this turn. See rule 182. Control for more information on Control. See rule 446.1.for more information on Conquering.
446.1.
Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleï¬eld they did not yet Score this turn.
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
446.1.b.
A player will gain control of a Battleï¬eld after establishing Control by applying Contested ï¬rst.
446.2.
Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleï¬eld during their Beginning Phase.
466.8.c.
Control is not shared.
718.8.
Attached cards may have different Controllers from their Top-Most card.
718.8.a.
Changes in Control of the Top-Most card do not impact Control of Attached cards and vice versa.
Controlled By A Speciï¬c Player
184.2.b.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled by a speciï¬c player or Controlled by no one.
Controlled By No One
184.2.b.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled by a speciï¬c player or Controlled by no one.
Cost
130.
Cost
130.1.
Main Deck cards have a Cost, listed in the upper left corner of the front face of the card. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
130.2.a.
The numeral listed in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card.
130.3.a.
The symbols, listed vertically, in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card.
143.2.
Exhausting the Unit is the Cost for this action.
143.3.c.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously.
144.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
148.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
162.
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs.
179.2.a.
Tokens do not have costs.
353.6.
Costs may be Energy costs, Power costs, or non-standard costs. Example: A card reads "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." Killing a friendly unit is an additional cost to play that card.
354.2.
In addition, pay any non-standard Cost summed in rule 353.2in any order.
370.1.
Activated Abilities are recognized by the presence of a ":" in the text of the card, preceded by a cost and succeeded by an effect. Example: "[2]: Draw 1" is an activated ability. The cost is 2 energy. The effect is to draw 1 card.
401.4.
When Exhausting is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A spell says "As an additional cost to play this, you may exhaust a friendly unit." An exhausted friendly unit may not be exhausted again as the additional cost for the spell, and the additional cost has not been paid.
403.3.
When Recycling is listed as a Cost, the action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: Vi, Destructive has the ability "Recycle 1 from your trash: Give me +1 [M] this turn." Each time a player activates the ability, they must recycle 1 card from their trash to pay its cost. If they have no cards in their trash, they can't activate the ability, because they can't pay its cost.
407.3.a.
The Cost is Exhausting one or more Units.
409.3.
When Discarding is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A card has the ability "Discard 2: Deal 2 damage to a unit at a battleï¬eld." To activate the ability, the card's controller must have at least 2 cards in hand and must be able to discard them.
746.1.d.
Repeat is functionally short for â€œYou may pay [Cost] as an additional cost as you play this spell. If you do, execute the instructions of this spell one additional time.â€
Countered
406.4.b.
If a game effect prevents the resolution of the cardâ€”for example, because the card was counteredâ€”the card wasn't played and no abilities that trigger on playing cards trigger. See rule 412. Counter for more information.
412.
Counter
412.1.
Countering is the act of negating the execution, activation, or otherwise playing of a card by a player.
412.1.a.
A card that is Countered does nothing and is then placed in the Trash.
412.1.b.
A card that is Countered is not considered to have been played.
412.1.c.
Countering does not refund any costs paid to play a card.
412.2.a.
Players may only Counter cards when directed to by Game Effects.
412.3.
This action is formatted as "Counter [a card or ability on the chain]."
652.4.
Counter all spells and abilities of all types controlled by the player that has conceded.
Current Turn Player
368.2.
If the affected object is an Uncontrolled Battleï¬eld then the Current Turn Player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply.
D
Damage
141.
Damage is a marked value that is applied to Units.
141.1.
Damage is not a Game Object.
141.2.
Damage is a value tracked per-Unit.
141.3.
Damage tracks how close a Unit is to being Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
141.4.
Damage can be Healed. See rule 405. Heal for more information.
142.3.b.
Damage is Healed from Units at two speciï¬c times:
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
322.4.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash.
404.1.a.
Assigning Damage during Combat Resolution is not Dealing Damage, but will cause Damage to be Dealt when assignment is complete.
404.1.b.
To Deal Damage to Units, mark the speciï¬ed amount of Damage on the Unit.
404.1.c.
Damage is marked on each unit separately.
404.1.d.
Damage can be Dealt to more than one Unit at the same time.
404.2.
Only Damage can be Dealt.
404.3.a.
Assigning Damage causes Damage to be dealt outside of being directed to Deal Damage. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
404.5.
Bonus Damage is a property granted to the action of Dealing and alters the amount of Damage distributed by this action. See rule 712. Bonus Damage for more information.
404.6.b.
If a game effect does specify a source, then that source is what is considered the origin of the Damage for this Deal action.
404.6.b.1.
Units and Spells can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.
404.6.b.2.
Abilities can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.
404.6.b.2.a.
When an Ability is the source of Damage for a Deal action, it is in addition to the Spell or Unit that created that Ability. Example: Iron Ballista is a gear that says â€œ[E]: Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld.â€ This damage is dealt both by a gear and by an ability.
404.6.b.3.
When a spell or ability speciï¬es a Unit as the source of the Damage for the Deal action, it is not in addition to the spell or ability that speciï¬ed it. Example: Challenge is a spell that reads â€œChoose a friendly unit and an enemy unit. They deal damage equal to their Mights to each other.â€ The damage that Challenge causes to be dealt is dealt by the chosen units, not by Challenge.
404.6.c.
Damage Dealt as a result of being assigned during Combat has the Units as its source.
404.6.c.1.
The Damage assigned, and subsequently Dealt, to attackers has the defenders as the source and vice versa.
404.7.
Deal actions can distribute Damage as part of combat actions or non-combat actions.
405.1.
Damage being cleared from Units is Healing.
405.1.a.
If Damage is cleared for any reason it is considered Healing.
443.1.d.1.
Assigning Damage is not Dealing Damage.
443.1.d.1.a.
When all Damage is assigned, it will be Dealt simultaneously. These actions are not synonymous.
443.1.e.
Deal Damage to each unit equal to the amount assigned to it.
713.
Bonus Damage is an intrinsic property that can be granted to Deal actions that inï¬‚uence the amount of Damage that the action is distributing.
714.1.
Bonus Damage can only be a positive value, and can only increase the amount of Damage being distributed.
715.1.
If the Deal action has a single target, the amount of Damage to that target will be increased by the Bonus Damage granted to it.
715.2.
If the Deal action has multiple targets, the amount of Damage dealt to each target is increased by Bonus Damage individually and separately. Example: Singularity is a spell that says â€œDeal 6 to each of up to two units.â€ A player plays Singularity while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Singularity deals 1 Bonus Damage to both of its targets, dealing 7 to each.
715.3.
If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split. This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen. Example: Volibear, Furious is a unit that says in part â€œWhen I attack, deal 5 damage split among any number of enemy units here.â€ A player attacks with Volibear, Furious while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Volibear, Furious now deals 6 damage split among any number of enemy units at its location, and can choose to split that damage among up to 6 units rather than the usual 5.
Deal Damage
404.1.
Spells, Units, Abilities, and other game effects may Deal Damage to units.
404.1.b.
To Deal Damage to Units, mark the speciï¬ed amount of Damage on the Unit.
404.3.a.
Assigning Damage causes Damage to be dealt outside of being directed to Deal Damage. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
Dealing Damage
404.1.a.
Assigning Damage during Combat Resolution is not Dealing Damage, but will cause Damage to be Dealt when assignment is complete.
404.3.
Dealing Damage is a Limited Action.
443.1.d.1.
Assigning Damage is not Dealing Damage.
Dealt
404.1.a.
Assigning Damage during Combat Resolution is not Dealing Damage, but will cause Damage to be Dealt when assignment is complete.
404.1.d.
Damage can be Dealt to more than one Unit at the same time.
404.2.
Only Damage can be Dealt.
404.4.
Dealing can have the intrinsic property of Bonus Damage.
404.5.
Bonus Damage is a property granted to the action of Dealing and alters the amount of Damage distributed by this action. See rule 712. Bonus Damage for more information.
404.6.
Deal actions can originate from one or more sources.
404.6.a.
If a game effect does not specify a source, the game effect describing the Deal action is the source. Example: Void Seeker is a spell that reads â€œDeal 4 to a unit at a battleï¬eld. Draw 1.â€ The damage that Void Seeker instructs you to deal is dealt by Void Seeker.
404.6.b.
If a game effect does specify a source, then that source is what is considered the origin of the Damage for this Deal action.
404.6.b.1.
Units and Spells can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.
404.6.b.2.
Abilities can be the source of Damage for Deal actions.
404.6.b.2.a.
When an Ability is the source of Damage for a Deal action, it is in addition to the Spell or Unit that created that Ability. Example: Iron Ballista is a gear that says â€œ[E]: Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld.â€ This damage is dealt both by a gear and by an ability.
404.6.b.3.
When a spell or ability speciï¬es a Unit as the source of the Damage for the Deal action, it is not in addition to the spell or ability that speciï¬ed it. Example: Challenge is a spell that reads â€œChoose a friendly unit and an enemy unit. They deal damage equal to their Mights to each other.â€ The damage that Challenge causes to be dealt is dealt by the chosen units, not by Challenge.
404.6.c.1.
The Damage assigned, and subsequently Dealt, to attackers has the defenders as the source and vice versa.
404.7.
Deal actions can distribute Damage as part of combat actions or non-combat actions.
443.1.d.1.a.
When all Damage is assigned, it will be Dealt simultaneously. These actions are not synonymous.
713.
Bonus Damage is an intrinsic property that can be granted to Deal actions that inï¬‚uence the amount of Damage that the action is distributing.
714.
If more than one instance of Bonus Damage is applied or granted to a Deal action, all instances are summed and applied once.
715.
Bonus Damage applies to the total damage Dealt by one instance of the action.
715.1.
If the Deal action has a single target, the amount of Damage to that target will be increased by the Bonus Damage granted to it.
715.2.
If the Deal action has multiple targets, the amount of Damage dealt to each target is increased by Bonus Damage individually and separately. Example: Singularity is a spell that says â€œDeal 6 to each of up to two units.â€ A player plays Singularity while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Singularity deals 1 Bonus Damage to both of its targets, dealing 7 to each.
715.3.
If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split. This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen. Example: Volibear, Furious is a unit that says in part â€œWhen I attack, deal 5 damage split among any number of enemy units here.â€ A player attacks with Volibear, Furious while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Volibear, Furious now deals 6 damage split among any number of enemy units at its location, and can choose to split that damage among up to 6 units rather than the usual 5.
Deathknell
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
415.1.a.1.b.
When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction, it ï¬rst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unitâ€™s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ï¬nalized before completing this Kill Instruction.
734.
Deathknell
734.1.d.2.
The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup.
734.1.d.3.
Before the card with Deathknell is moved to the Trash, note its location, its attributes, and any other details related to the effect of its Deathknell to process the trigger after it has been Finalized.
Deck Construction
101.
Deck Construction
172.1.
The Legend determines the Domain Identity of cards its owner can include. See rule 101. Deck Construction for more information.
Decks
103.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battleï¬elds determined by the Mode of Play.
103.1.b.1.
Cards included in your Deck must abide by your Domain Identity.
404.
Deal
Decreases
420.1.a.
Swapping creates two different effects that apply to each attribute. One that Increases one value and one that Decreases the other.
420.1.b.
To accomplish this, determine the difference between these values and then apply an Increase for that amount to the lower value of the two attributes, and a Decrease of that amount to the higher value of the two attributes.
Defend Triggers
376.4.e.
Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
Defender
322.5.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
376.4.e.
Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
376.4.e.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Defender designation multiple times in the same combat.
442.1.a.
Establish who is Attacker and who is Defender.
442.1.a.2.
The Defender is the player who did not apply the Contested status to the Battleï¬eld. They gain the Defender designation now.
442.1.a.4.
Units at the Contested Battleï¬eld controlled by the Defender gain the Defender designation now.
442.1.a.4.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
443.1.a.
The Combat Damage Step only occurs if both Attacking and Defending units remain at the location.
444.1.a.2.
Insert â€œ2d. Recall Attackers present at the Battleï¬eld if Defenders are still present.â€ See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
Defending Player
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
Defending Units
443.1.a.1.
If neither Attacking Units nor Defending Units remain at this stage, the Combat Damage Step is skipped.
443.1.c.
Sum the Might of all Defending Units.
Delayed Abilities
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
383.
Delayed Abilities are a type of Ability whose trigger Condition identiï¬es a speciï¬c time during a turn or a speciï¬c event that can occur during a speciï¬c timeframe.
383.1.
Delayed Abilities can be any other type of Ability, and contain all of the properties of that type in addition to the properties of Delayed Abilities.
384.
Delayed Abilities will resolve or be active just like the ability they augment, but only during the speciï¬ed time in the effect that created the Delayed Ability. Example: Ravenborn Tome reads â€œThe next spell you play this turn deals 1 Bonus Damageâ€ is a Delayed Passive Ability that passively adds 1 damage to just the next spell played. The next spell is a speciï¬c time, and the 1 Bonus Damage is a passive ability. Example: Noxian Guillotine reads â€œChoose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn.â€ When the chosen unit takes damage is the speciï¬ed time, and killing it is the condition for a Delayed Triggered Ability.
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.
Delayed Passive Abilities
383.4.
Delayed Passive Abilities are Passive Abilities that are applicable only during a speciï¬ed window of time. The time that the Delayed Passive Ability applies will be recognized in the effect that initiates it.
384.
Delayed Abilities will resolve or be active just like the ability they augment, but only during the speciï¬ed time in the effect that created the Delayed Ability. Example: Ravenborn Tome reads â€œThe next spell you play this turn deals 1 Bonus Damageâ€ is a Delayed Passive Ability that passively adds 1 damage to just the next spell played. The next spell is a speciï¬c time, and the 1 Bonus Damage is a passive ability. Example: Noxian Guillotine reads â€œChoose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn.â€ When the chosen unit takes damage is the speciï¬ed time, and killing it is the condition for a Delayed Triggered Ability.
Delayed Replacements
383.3.
Delayed Replacements are Replacement Effects that can be recognized by specifying the effect they are replacing at a speciï¬c time, or â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ in the description of the effect as it resolves.
Delayed Triggered Ability
384.
Delayed Abilities will resolve or be active just like the ability they augment, but only during the speciï¬ed time in the effect that created the Delayed Ability. Example: Ravenborn Tome reads â€œThe next spell you play this turn deals 1 Bonus Damageâ€ is a Delayed Passive Ability that passively adds 1 damage to just the next spell played. The next spell is a speciï¬c time, and the 1 Bonus Damage is a passive ability. Example: Noxian Guillotine reads â€œChoose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn.â€ When the chosen unit takes damage is the speciï¬ed time, and killing it is the condition for a Delayed Triggered Ability.
Delayed Triggers
383.2.
Delayed Triggers are Triggered Abilities that can be recognized by describing a speciï¬c time of the turn, or by structuring a Triggered Ability with a speciï¬c frame of time as a restriction.
Depend On
456.
To determine which effect Depends on another, determine which of the prior criteria applies, and then also which effectâ€™s evaluation is altered by the sequence of applications. That effect is said to Depend on the other.
Dependency
455.
If more than one effect applies to the same Game Object in the Same Layer, or to each other in the same layer, then both effects will apply but their order may be determined by Dependency.
455.1.
A Dependency is established if:
Depends On
456.
To determine which effect Depends on another, determine which of the prior criteria applies, and then also which effectâ€™s evaluation is altered by the sequence of applications. That effect is said to Depend on the other.
456.1.
To resolve a dependency, the effects within the same layer that created the dependency must be applied such that: 1. Identify which effect Depends on the other within the Layer. 2. Apply the effect that is depended on ï¬rst. 3. Immediately apply the effect that Depends on the ï¬rst effect next.
Destination
143.3.a.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the units' Destination must be the same.
166.5.b.
Battleï¬elds can be Destinations of moves.
424.3.b.
Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving.
425.
Moving is deï¬ned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations.
425.2.
The Destination is where the Permanent is going to.
427.1.
The source of the Move will provide details on any restrictions on legality for Destination.
428.
The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleï¬eld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved.
Detach
421.1.f.
Attaching a card will cause it to Detach from any card to which it is currently Attached.
422.
Detach
422.1.
Detaching is the act of unlinking two cards that are currently linked through the act of Attaching. This causes one to cease being Attached, and potentially causes the other to cease being a Top-Most card.
422.1.a.
Detaching affects only cards that are currently Attached to another card.
422.1.a.1.
Game effects that instruct a player to Detach a card that is currently not Attached to anything will do nothing.
422.1.b.
When one or more cards become Detached, they cease to be in the Attached state.
422.1.c.
The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive.
422.1.d.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text.
422.1.e.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached.
422.2.
Detaching is a Limited Action.
422.2.a.
Players may only Detach cards when directed to by Game Effects.
422.3.
Detaching cards does not inherently choose, or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Detach cards may.
422.4.
When a card Detaches from a Top-Most Card, its location is the same as the Top-Most Card from which it Detached.
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.
422.4.b.
If the Attached card was Detached because the Top-Most Card changed zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, then the location that the Attached Card will Detach to is the last location the Top-Most Card was at before changing from a board zone to a non-board zone.
718.1.
A card remains in this state until Detached.
719.5.
When a Top-Most Card changes zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, all Attached cards Detach from it, remaining in their current zones.
719.5.a.
The player that controls the Top-Most Card that changed zones decides the order these cards Detach in, and thus the order of any relevant effects that occur due to the Detach occurring.
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.
Deï¬‚ect
353.2.a.2.
The cost imposed by the Deï¬‚ect keyword is a Mandatory Additional Cost. See rule 735. Deï¬‚ect for more information.
735.
Deï¬‚ect
Discard
409.
Discard
409.1.
Discarding a card is moving it from a player's hand directly into their trash without activating or executing its normal rules text.
409.2.
Discarding is a Limited Action.
409.2.a.
A player must Discard cards when instructed to do so by game effects or costs.
409.3.
When Discarding is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A card has the ability "Discard 2: Deal 2 damage to a unit at a battleï¬eld." To activate the ability, the card's controller must have at least 2 cards in hand and must be able to discard them.
409.4.
When Discarding is part of an effect, then a player must Discard as many cards as possible from their hand. If instructed to discard more cards than they have in their hand, further discard instructions are ignored. Example: Undercover Agent has the ability "[Deathknell] â€” Discard 2, then draw 2. (When I die, get the effect.)" If Undercover Agent's controller has 2 or more cards in hand, they must discard 2. If they have 1 card in hand, they discard 1, and the rest of the discard instruction is ignored. If they have no cards in hand, the entire discard instruction is ignored. Regardless of how many cards they discard, they then draw 2.
414.2.b.
Banish is not a subset of Discard.
Discretionary Actions
305.
When there are no items on the Chain and the Turn Player cannot or chooses not to perform any Discretionary Actions, the current phase or step of the turn ends and the next phase, step, or turn begins.
312.1.
Priority is the singular exclusive right to take Discretionary Actions. See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information.
312.1.a.
The player with Priority can take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions.
312.1.b.
If no player has Priority, no player can take Discretionary Actions.
313.1.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
313.1.a.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed. Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords.
316.2.a.
A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions they are able to perform during this phase. See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information.
316.3.
As a result of a player taking Discretionary Actions, one or more structured phases may occur.
316.6.
When a player has no more Discretionary Actions they wish to execute, they must indicate they are ending their turn.
398.1.
Discretionary Actions
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
398.1.b.
A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions available to them during their turn.
401.3.a.
Most Exhaust actions will be costs for Activated Abilities or Discretionary Actions. Example: A unit's Standard Move exhausts the unit as a cost.
406.2.
This is a Discretionary Action.
407.3.
The Standard Move inherent to Units is a Discretionary Action.
408.2.
Hiding is a Discretionary Action.
Disqualiï¬ed
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
Disqualiï¬ed From Being Scored
466.8.b.
Battleï¬elds controlled during the Beginning Phase of a player's turn by that player's teammate are disqualiï¬ed from being scored by that Team, that turn. Example: A player may not induce their partner to retreat, and then conquer a Battleï¬eld their teammate was controlling.
Domain
103.1.b.3.
If a card has a single Domain, then that card is permitted in the Domain Identity that corresponds to the same Domain.
103.1.b.4.
If a card has more than one Domain, then that card is permitted only in a Domain Identity that contains all of the indicated Domains on that card.
133.
Domain
133.1.
Most cards belong to one or more of six Domains, identiï¬ed by one or more symbols in the lower right corner.
134.2.e.4.
Power of a speciï¬c Domain is represented by its domain symbol and the corresponding shorthand. See rule 133. Domain for more information.
134.2.e.5.
Power of any Domain is represented by a swirling rainbow symbol. Its shorthand is [A].
134.2.e.5.a.
When required as a cost, [A] can be paid by Power of any Domain.
134.2.e.5.b.
When Added to a playerâ€™s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain.
134.2.e.6.
Power of a domain corresponding to a cardâ€™s own Domain is not represented by a symbol, but appears in these rules similarly to other symbols. Its shorthand is [C].
134.2.e.6.a.
When a [C] shorthand is printed on a card as reminder text, it assumes that cardâ€™s usual Domain, but it still means â€œone Power of this cardâ€™s Domain.â€
134.2.e.6.b.
A [C] shorthand on a card with no Domain or with multiple Domains is processed as [A] instead.
160.2.b.1.
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled.
172.
Legends may have one or more Domains.
179.2.b.
Tokens do not have domains.
Domain Identity
103.1.b.
This will dictate the Domain Identity of the Main Deck.
103.1.b.1.
Cards included in your Deck must abide by your Domain Identity.
103.1.b.2.
Your deckâ€™s Domain Identity is dictated by the domains of your Champion Legend. In the default card frame, these domains appear as symbols in the legendâ€™s upper left corner.
103.1.b.3.
If a card has a single Domain, then that card is permitted in the Domain Identity that corresponds to the same Domain.
103.1.b.4.
If a card has more than one Domain, then that card is permitted only in a Domain Identity that contains all of the indicated Domains on that card.
103.2.c.
Subject to Domain Identity.
103.3.a.1.
Cards in this deck must be of the Domain Identity of your Champion Legend.
103.4.b.
Subject to Domain Identity if applicable.
172.1.
The Legend determines the Domain Identity of cards its owner can include. See rule 101. Deck Construction for more information.
Double
419.
Double
419.1.
Doubling is the act of increasing a numeric attribute by an amount equal to that attributeâ€™s current value.
419.2
Doubling is a Limited Action.
Drawn
107.6.b.
This is the location cards go when Drawn.
315.4.b.2.
After completing the Burn Out the Turn Player still Draws 1.
315.4.d.
As the Draw Phase ends, each player's Rune Pool empties. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
398.2.b.
These actions can only be taken when a player is instructed to do so as the execution of an effect or during their speciï¬ed occasion during the turn. Example: A player may Draw during the Draw Step of the Beginning Phase of their turn or when instructed to do so by a spell or ability. They can't choose to Draw at any other time.
400.
Draw
400.1.
Drawing a card takes a single card from the top of the Main Deck and adds it to the player's Hand.
400.2.a.
Each player draws 1 during the Draw Step of their Beginning Phase.
400.4.c.
Draw the remaining cards needed to complete the Draw action.
418.1.a.
If a player must Draw cards in excess to the number of cards in their deck, they will Draw as many as possible, perform this action, then Draw the remaining amount instructed.
464.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
465.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
466.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
During A Neutral Open State
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
E
Effect Text
135.
Effect Text
135.1
Some cards have a separate section of text below the Rules Text. This is referred to as the Effect Text.
135.2
Effect Text can contain additional Abilities.
135.2.a
Effect Text can be blank.
135.2.b
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
135.2.c
The abilities in the Effect Text section of a card are appended to the Rules Text of the card to which the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
370.1.
Activated Abilities are recognized by the presence of a ":" in the text of the card, preceded by a cost and succeeded by an effect. Example: "[2]: Draw 1" is an activated ability. The cost is 2 energy. The effect is to draw 1 card.
376.2.
Triggered Abilities have a Condition and an Effect.
376.2.b.
The Effect is the Instruction that follows the comma after the Condition.
376.4.
Some Conditions are commonly used and structured in a way that explicitly deï¬nes their use and other properties of the Effect that is associated with it.
407.3.b.
The Effect is Moving those Unit.
421.1.b.
This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached.
421.1.b.1.
In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card, they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects.
421.1.c.
The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text.
422.1.c.
The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive.
422.1.d.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text.
454.2.c.
Abilities of Effect Text of Attached cards are appended in this layer.
718.3.
While in this state, Abilities in the cardâ€™s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
719.1.
The Effect Text of all cards Attached to this card are appended to the Rules Text of this card for as long as they remain Attached.
724.
Effect Text is Inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
End Of Turn
316.6.b.
Play proceeds to the End of Turn.
Ending Step
410.1.a.2.
Stunned Units lose the Stunned status at the beginning of the next Ending Step.
Energy
130.2.
Energy Cost
159.
Runes produce Energy and Power.
159.1.
Energy is used to pay numeric Energy costs.
159.1.a.
Energy has no Domain.
159.1.b.
Energy has no type.
162.
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs.
162.1.
When a card adds Energy or Power, it is added to the controlling player's Rune Pool.
162.2.
Players must ï¬rst add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs.
162.3.
Energy and Power do not have a physical marker or tracker, although players may wish to use a physical tracker if they are retaining unspent Energy and Power over the course of their turn.
163.1.
Any unspent Energy or Power are lost.
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information.
306.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn.
317.3.b.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost.
353.1.a.
If a card allows a player to play a card "ignoring its cost," its base Energy cost and base Power cost are set to zero.
354.1.
In total, pay the combined Energy cost (if any) and Power cost (if any).
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
Enter The Board
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
Equip
725.3.
If an Attached card has an Equip ability, the Weaponmaster keyword can reference that Equip ability and any abilities that passively modify that Equip ability.
744.
Equip
744.1.
Equip is an Activated Ability keyword.
744.1.a.
Equip is normally present on Gear with the tag Equipment.
744.1.b.
Equip has a cost to activate and Attaches the card with Equip to a chosen Unit when the cost is paid.
744.1.b.1.
Equipâ€™s choice is a Target.
744.1.c.
Equip is formatted as â€œEquip [Cost]â€
744.1.c.2.
Equip is functionally short for â€œ[Cost]: Attach this gear to a unit you control.â€
744.1.c.3.
Equip costs may include both resource costs and non-resource costs.
744.1.c.4.
Equip abilities may also include text that alters the Equip cost. Such text is taken into account when determining a cardâ€™s Equip cost for any reason.
744.1.c.5.
Equip abilities may include text that alters the timing or targeting of the Equip ability.
744.2.
When the Attach action completes from this keyword, the Unit that was chosen is considered to have been Equipped by the Gear with this ability.
744.3.
Equipped is the state of a Top-Most Card being Attached by one or more cards that are Equipment.
744.3.a.
The state of being Equipped is synchronous with that of the Attached state of the Equipment.
744.3.b.
A Top-Most Card is Equipped as long as one or more of its Attached cards are Equipment.
744.3.c.
The state of being Equipped corresponds to a Top-Most card having a card with Equip that is Attached to it.
744.4.
Multiple instances of Equip are equivalent to multiple Activated Abilities and can each be activated separately by paying the corresponding costs.
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
745.1.a.
Quick-Draw is present on Gear with Equip abilities.
747.1.b.
Weaponmaster is a Play Effect that chooses an Equipment you control and allows you to pay its Equip cost at a discount, regardless of the usual timing of the Equip ability, to Attach that Equipment to the unit with Weaponmaster.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.c.1.
Weaponmaster can choose an Equipment whether it has an Equip ability or not.
747.1.c.2.
The cost of the Equip ability is determined as though that Equip ability was being activated choosing the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, as modulated by any abilities that alter Equip costs.
747.1.c.3.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost does not contain [A], it can still be paid, but will not be reduced.
747.1.c.4.
If the chosen card doesnâ€™t have an Equip cost, it canâ€™t be paid.
747.1.c.5.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost canâ€™t be paid, if it canâ€™t be detached from its current Top-Most card, or if it canâ€™t be attached to the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, it stays in its current location, Attached to anything it was already Attached to.
747.1.c.6.
The Equip ability is not activated this way, and the unit with the Weaponmaster ability is not chosen.
Establishes Control
444.2.
2. If no Showdown or Combat is staged at this location, the player with Units remaining here Establishes Control.
Everything Else
185.
Everything Else
Exhaust Symbol
401.5.
In abilities, the Exhaust symbol represents the cost "Exhaust this" or "Exhaust me." It resembles a card turning sideways.
Exhausted
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
134.2.e.2.
The cost of Exhausting a Permanent is represented by the â€œexhaust symbol,â€ which resembles a card turning sideways. Its shorthand is [E]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [T].)
143.2.
Exhausting the Unit is the Cost for this action.
143.3.c.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously.
401.
Exhaust
401.1.
Exhausting is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as "spent."
401.1.b.
A Unit that is already Exhausted cannot be Exhausted again.
401.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Exhausted while it is already Exhausted, nothing additional happens.
401.2.
"Exhausted" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.
401.3.a.
Most Exhaust actions will be costs for Activated Abilities or Discretionary Actions. Example: A unit's Standard Move exhausts the unit as a cost.
401.4.
When Exhausting is listed as a Cost, then the Action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: A spell says "As an additional cost to play this, you may exhaust a friendly unit." An exhausted friendly unit may not be exhausted again as the additional cost for the spell, and the additional cost has not been paid.
402.1.a.
To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Exhausting, so that it is vertically oriented in front of you.
407.3.a.
The Cost is Exhausting one or more Units.
719.4.
The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa.
Expiration Step
317.3.b.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost.
F
Face Up
129.5.
The term face up is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's front face presented
Facedown Zones
106.4.
The Facedown Zones
106.4.a.
Each Battleï¬eld is associated with a sub-zone called a Facedown Zone, a single logical space that a card can be put facedown in through various Game Effects.
106.4.b.
Each Facedown Zone has a maximum occupancy of one card.
106.4.c.
Cards can only be placed in or occupy the Facedown Zone if the controller of the card also controls the associated Battleï¬eld.
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information.
128.4.
The term facedown is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's back side presented on the Board. A facedown cardâ€™s front side is considered Private Information.
Final Point
448.1.a.
The Final Point has additional restrictions.
448.1.b.1.
If the player has Scored through Hold, that player scores the Final Point.
448.1.b.2.
If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleï¬eld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point. If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleï¬eld this turn, that player draws a card.
466.8.f.
The Final Point has an adjustment to the criteria when scoring.
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase.
466.8.f.2.
No other changes to Final Point restrictions.
Finalize
322.12.
8. Finalize any Pending Items on the Chain
333.1.b.
Each Item is Finalized in the order it was appended to the Chain.
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
734.1.d.3.
Before the card with Deathknell is moved to the Trash, note its location, its attributes, and any other details related to the effect of its Deathknell to process the trigger after it has been Finalized.
Finalized Chain Items
349.2.
Near the end of the process cards will cease being Pending and become Finalized Chain Items.
Finalized Items
333.1.
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain.
First Player
115.1.a.
The Mode of Play will specify how to determine a First Player.
115.1.b.
If not otherwise speciï¬ed, Seating then determines the sequence, play proceeding clockwise from the First Player.
115.1.b.1.
The First Player is the player who becomes the Turn Player ï¬rst.
118.
Begin play with the First Player taking their turn.
First Turn Process
460.7.
First Turn Process: Adjustments to each player's ï¬rst turn.
462.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
463.7.
First Turn Process: The player going second channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
464.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
465.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
466.7.
First Turn Process: The player going ï¬rst does not draw a card during their ï¬rst Draw Phase of the game. The player going last channels an extra Rune from their Rune Deck during their ï¬rst Channel Phase of the game.
Flavor Text
137.
Flavor Text
Focus
312.2.b.
When the turn is in a Showdown State and they gain Focus.
313.
At any given time, up to one player has Focus.
313.1.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
313.1.a.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed. Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords.
313.2.
A player who gains Focus also gains Priority.
313.3.
A player who passes Priority retains Focus.
313.4
A player may not make discretionary actions with Focus unless they also possess Priority.
313.5.
If the turn is in a Neutral State, no player has Focus.
320.1.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded.
341.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battleï¬eld gains Focus.
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
343.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority.
344.
During a Showdown, the player with Focus may do one of the following:
344.4.
Otherwise, Focus passes to the next Player in Turn Order.
345.
If all players pass Focus without playing a spell or activating an ability, then the Showdown Closes.
416.2.a.
Priority and Focus will not pass from Add abilities being ï¬nalized, and will resolve before any other outstanding items on the chain are ï¬nalized.
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
652.5.b.1.
If the removed player had Focus in a Showdown, the next Player in order receives Focus.
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
Format
460.6.
Format: Conditions to win or additional rules added over play.
462.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
464.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
465.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
466.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
Formation Of Players
460.2.
Formation of Players: How the players are organized while playing.
Friendly
466.8.d.
Friendly describes controlled Game Objects by a player or their Teammate. Example: "When I am played, ready a friendly unit" could target a player's own Units or their teammate's Units.
Front Face
129.2.
This is also referred to as a front face.
Front Side
129.
Front Side
Fury
133.2.a.
Fury is associated with the color red and represented by a circular symbol with three projecting points. Its shorthand is [R].
G
Game Actions
120.
A Game Object is any game piece that can produce one or more Game Effects or grant prerequisites for players to take Game Actions.
121.
A Game Object does not include nor preclude any inherent properties beyond the ability to produce, or act as the prerequisite for, Game Effects and Game Actions.
303.1.
Game Actions of any nature are performed one at a time and are executed completely.
303.2.
Game Actions cannot be performed simultaneously for any reason.
395.
Game Actions
396.
Game Actions are actions players may perform at any given time during the game.
398.
There are two types of Game Actions:
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
Game Effects
106.4.a.
Each Battleï¬eld is associated with a sub-zone called a Facedown Zone, a single logical space that a card can be put facedown in through various Game Effects.
120.
A Game Object is any game piece that can produce one or more Game Effects or grant prerequisites for players to take Game Actions.
121.
A Game Object does not include nor preclude any inherent properties beyond the ability to produce, or act as the prerequisite for, Game Effects and Game Actions.
144.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
148.1.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
184.3.e.
At this time Game Effects cannot reference this status.
316.4.b.
This could be the result of a Standard Move Standard Action, a Spell, or other Game Effect.
317.1.a.
At the end of the turn Game Effects take place.
352.2.b
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit..
410.2.a.
Players may only Stun Units when directed to by Game Effects.
411.2.a.
Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects.
411.4.
Game Effects can manipulate or modify the cards Revealed while they are Revealed
412.2.a.
Players may only Counter cards when directed to by Game Effects.
413.2.a.
Players may only Buff units when Game Effects direct them to do so.
414.4.a.
Players may only Banish cards or permanents when Game Effects direct them to do so.
415.3.a.
Players may only Kill units when Game Effects direct them to do so.
416.4.a.
Players may only Add resources when Game Effects direct them to do so.
417.2.
The Game Effect that instructs a player to channel 1 or more runes may specify the conditions or circumstances under which those runes enter the board. Example: A spell reads "Channel 1 rune exhausted." As that spell resolves, its controller puts the top rune of their rune deck onto the board and that rune enters the board exhausted rather than ready.
417.3.a.
Players may only channel runes when Game Effects direct them to do so.
418.4.a.
Players may only burn out when Game Effects direct them to do so.
419.1.a.
This creates an effect that modulates that attribute by that speciï¬c amount for the duration speciï¬ed by the Game Effect that instructed the player to perform this action. Example: A unit with 3 base Might and Shield 2 is in combat as a Defender. Since Shield applies, its current Might is 5. A player chooses it as the target for Last Stand, a spell that reads in part â€œDouble a friendly unit's Might this turn.â€ Its current Might is 5, so it gets +5 Might this turn, for a current Might of 10. After combat, Shield no longer applies, but the +5 Might from Last Stand does, so the unitâ€™s Might is 8.
419.2.a.
Players may only Double when Game Effects direct them to do so.
420.2.a
Players may only swap when Game Effects direct them to do so.
421.2.a.
Players may only Attach cards when directed to by Game Effects.
421.3.
Attaching cards does not inherently choose or specify a target. However, Game Effects that Attach cards may do so.
422.2.a.
Players may only Detach cards when directed to by Game Effects.
434.3.
A Recall cannot be prevented by actions and Game Effects that restrict or block Movement.
451.
Layers are the mechanism in which Game Effects alter the Traits, Intrinsic Abilities, or other properties of Game Objects.
452.1.
Layers only serve to structure the application and order that Game Effects apply to Game Objects to maintain consistency.
454.1.b.1.
All Traits, including the Rules Text, replace or are added to those of the original Game Object as speciï¬ed by the Game Effect directing the Copy. This is applied in this layer.
727.3.
Keywords can be referenced or speciï¬ed by other Game Effects.
731.5.
Accelerate, and whether or not a unit has Accelerate, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
732.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Action is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
732.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Action is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
732.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Action is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
733.3.
Assault, and whether or not a unit has Assault, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
734.3.
Deathknell, and whether or not a permanent has Deathknell, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
735.3.
Deï¬‚ect, and whether or not a permanent has Deï¬‚ect, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
736.3.
Ganking, and whether or not a unit has Ganking, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
737.5.
Hidden, and whether or not a card has Hidden, is a characteristic of the card and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
738.3.
Legion, and whether or not a card has Legion, is a characteristic of the card and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Reaction is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Reaction is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.c.
Whether or not an Ability has Reaction is a characteristic of that Ability and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
740.3.
Shield, and whether or not a unit has Shield, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
741.3.
Tank, and whether or not a unit has Tank, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
742.3.
Temporary, and whether or not a permanent has Temporary, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
743.3.
Vision, and whether or not a permanent has Vision, is a characteristic of the permanent and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
744.2.a.
This is an event other Game Effects and Triggered Abilities can reference.
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
745.4.
Quick-Draw, and whether or not a gear has Quick-Draw, is a characteristic of the Gear and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
746.4.
Repeat, and whether or not a spell has Repeat, is a characteristic of the Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
747.4.
Weaponmaster, and whether or not a unit has Weaponmaster, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
Game Objects
106.
The Play Area includes a space for Game Objects referred to as The Board.
106.2.d.
Other players cannot have Game Objects they control in another player's Base.
106.5.c.
The Champion Legend here is a Game Object. See rule 119. Game Objects for more information.
108.
All Game Objects in the collective Play Areas are Public Information.
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
119.
Game Objects
120.
A Game Object is any game piece that can produce one or more Game Effects or grant prerequisites for players to take Game Actions.
121.
A Game Object does not include nor preclude any inherent properties beyond the ability to produce, or act as the prerequisite for, Game Effects and Game Actions.
122.
A Game Object can be a literal object or a logical object.
123.
Game Objects include, but are not limited to, the following: Main Deck cards in any zone Runes in any zone Legends Battleï¬elds Tokens Abilities of any type on the chain Buffs and other status markers
140.1.
A Game Object
141.1.
Damage is not a Game Object.
146.1.
A Game Object
146.1.b.1.
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand.
166.
Battleï¬elds are Game Objects.
170.
Legends are Game Objects.
174.
Tokens are Game Objects created by spells and abilities during play.
183.
Control is the concept of a player having inï¬‚uence of a Game Object and applies differently to different card types.
185.1.
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
185.3.a.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Inherent Abilities.
185.3.b.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Unique Abilities.
186.1.
The method of assignment of control is different, but the status of Control is the same across all Game Objects.
315.1.a.
The Turn Player readies all Game Objects they control that are able to be readied. See rule 402. Ready for more information.
319.5.
After any number of Game Objects enter or leave the Board
319.6.
After the status of any number of Game Objects changes for any reason
334.1.b.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
344.2.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
348.1.
Permanents become Game Objects when Played.
352.4.
If a card requires you to speciï¬cally choose one or more Game Objects, that choice is made now.
352.4.a.
This does not include cards that affect one or more Game Objects based on criteria. Example: "Stun a unit at a battleï¬eld" is a Choice. Example: "Kill all gear" is not a Choice.
352.6.
When a card Chooses one or more speciï¬c Game Objects to affect, it is Targeted.
352.12.
If a card speciï¬es that a player may choose some number of Game Objects to be affected by a card, then all choices are considered targeted and chosen independently.
352.13.
If a card speciï¬es that a player chooses â€œany numberâ€ or â€œup toâ€ some number of Game Objects to be affected, they may choose any number of available targets, including zero. If they choose zero, the spell or ability can be played without any targets.
352.14.i.
Any costs that were paid, or effects that were triggered as a result of those Game Objects being chosen as Targets remain in effect, paid, or otherwise triggered.
356.2.
A Permanent leaves the Chain and becomes a Game Object.
358.
An Ability is the structured rules and capabilities of Game Objects or Spells.
372.
Activated abilities are present on Game Objects and some Spells.
376.2.c.1.
If a Game Object with a Triggered Ability that is active in a speciï¬c zone, it is evaluated and subsequently triggered if it enters that zone at the same time that its Triggerâ€™s condition is met. Example: Immortal Phoenix says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ This ability triggers if Immortal Phoenix is in your trash immediately after you kill a unit with a spell, even if the unit you killed with a spell was that Immortal Phoenix.
376.2.c.2.
A Game Object will not be able to successfully be able to evaluate its Trigger Condition, however, if it leaves the zone that its Trigger is active from at the same time that its Trigger is satisï¬ed. Example: Viktor, Leader says â€œWhen another non-Recruit unit you control dies, play a 1 [M] Recruit unit token into your base.â€ This ability triggers if Viktor is on the board immediately after another non-Recruit unit you control dies. It does not trigger if Viktor and another non-Recruit unit you control die during the same game action (for instance, if they are both killed in the same Cleanup due to the damage dealt by Unchecked Power).
401.1.
Exhausting is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as "spent."
401.2.
"Exhausted" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.
402.1.
Readying is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as available for action.
402.2.
"Ready" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.
402.3.a.
A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn.
402.3.b.
The player may also Ready their Game Objects when effects or spells instruct them to do so.
407.1.
Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board.
407.2.a.
Players may only move Game Objects when instructed to do so by Game Effects or costs.
415.5.
Killing can be attributed to one or more Game Objects.
415.5.a.
The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object.
415.5.d.
Abilities originating from Game Objects that are responsible for Kill Actions are responsible in addition to the Game Object that created them. Example: Falling Star is a spell that says â€œDo this twice: Deal 3 to a unit.â€ Immortal Phoenix is a unit that says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ A player plays Falling Star while Immortal Phoenix is in their trash. The â€œdo thisâ€ phrasing on Falling Star means that it has a reï¬‚exive triggered ability, which places two triggered abilities on the chain. As each of those triggered abilities resolve, it deals damage to the unit chosen for that ability. If one of these abilities deals lethal damage to a unit, both Falling Star and its ability are considered sources of the damage, and so both Falling Star and its ability are responsible for killing the unit. This means that Falling Starâ€™s controller killed a unit with a spell, so Immortal Phoenixâ€™s ability will trigger.
420.1.
Swapping is the act of increasing one numeric value and decreasing another numeric value on some number of Game Objects such that their values are reversed.
451.
Layers are the mechanism in which Game Effects alter the Traits, Intrinsic Abilities, or other properties of Game Objects.
452.1.
Layers only serve to structure the application and order that Game Effects apply to Game Objects to maintain consistency.
454.1.a.
This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace inherent traits of Game Objects. Name Super Type Type Tags Controller Cost Domain
454.1.b.
One Game Object becoming a copy of another.
454.1.b.1.
All Traits, including the Rules Text, replace or are added to those of the original Game Object as speciï¬ed by the Game Effect directing the Copy. This is applied in this layer.
454.2.a.
This layer deals with effects that grant, remove, or replace the abilities or rules text of Game Objects. Keywords Passive Abilities Appending rules text Removing rules text Duplicating Rules Text from one Game Object to another
454.3.a.
This layer deals with the mathematics of increasing and decreasing the numeric values of the traits of Game Objects. Might Energy Cost Power Cost
455.
If more than one effect applies to the same Game Object in the Same Layer, or to each other in the same layer, then both effects will apply but their order may be determined by Dependency.
466.8.d.
Friendly describes controlled Game Objects by a player or their Teammate. Example: "When I am played, ready a friendly unit" could target a player's own Units or their teammate's Units.
704.
Buffs are Game Objects and may be referenced, counted, or targeted by other effects as speciï¬ed.
727.3.a.3.
If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
727.3.b.2.
If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
732.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Action is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.a.
Whether or not a Game Object has Reaction is a characteristic of that Game Object and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
Ganking
143.4.c.
Ganking is a unique ability that affects a Unit's Standard Move
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
736.
Ganking
Gear
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
132.4.a.2.
Unit and Gear are permanent types.
145.
Gear
146.
Gear are:
146.1.a.1.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
146.1.a.2.
Gear and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
146.1.a.3.
Gear can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, effects, or game actions that specify Gear.
146.1.a.4.
Gear can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
146.1.b.1.
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand.
146.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being Gear, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that affect Gear on the Board.
146.1.b.3.
Gear can be affected by spells and game effects that affect Gear in the Trash.
147.
Gear have several Intrinsic Properties unique to them.
147.1.
Gear enters play Ready.
147.2.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
147.3.
If a Gear is at a Battleï¬eld for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
148.
Gear may have Activated Abilities.
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
322.7.
5. Recall all Gear at Battleï¬elds. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battleï¬elds that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash.
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
356.2.d.
If it is a Gear, it enters the Board Ready at the player's Base.
376.4.a.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen you play meâ€¦â€ for Units and â€œWhen you play thisâ€¦â€ for Gear.
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.
388.2.
When an Ability with the [Add] action is ï¬nalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item, like a Unit or Gear.
415.5.a.
The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object.
415.5.b.
A spell or ability that contains a Kill instruction is responsible for Killing the Unit or Gear.
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.
435.1.
When an un-attached Gear is created or played at a battleï¬eld, or is at a battleï¬eld for any other reason, it is Recalled to its controller's base during the next Cleanup. Example: An Equipment is attached to a unit at a battleï¬eld, so the Equipment is present at that battleï¬eld. If the unit dies, the Equipment will be recalled during the next cleanup.
744.1.a.
Equip is normally present on Gear with the tag Equipment.
744.2.
When the Attach action completes from this keyword, the Unit that was chosen is considered to have been Equipped by the Gear with this ability.
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
745.1.a.
Quick-Draw is present on Gear with Equip abilities.
Golden Rule
001.
Golden Rule
H
Hand
107.6.
The Hand
140.1.b.1.
Units are treated as Cards, similar to when in the Hand.
146.1.b.1.
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand.
400.1.
Drawing a card takes a single card from the top of the Main Deck and adds it to the player's Hand.
Healed
141.4.
Damage can be Healed. See rule 405. Heal for more information.
142.3.b.
Damage is Healed from Units at two speciï¬c times:
317.2.b.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€
405.
Heal
405.1.
Damage being cleared from Units is Healing.
405.1.a.
If Damage is cleared for any reason it is considered Healing.
405.2.
More than one Unit can be Healed at the same time.
405.3.
Healing is a Limited Action.
405.3.a.
Players may only Heal units when game effects instruct them to, or at speciï¬c points in the turn.
444.1.a.1.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€
Held
448.2.b.
Hold abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Held.
Hidden
106.4.d.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battleï¬eld, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information. See rule 408. Hide for more information.
322.7.
