5. Recall all Gear at Battleï¬elds. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battleï¬elds that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash.
408.
Hide
408.2.a.
The Hidden keyword allows a player to pay a cost to Hide a card any time they have a Hidden card in their hand or Champion Zone and meet the prerequisites. See rule 737. Hidden for more information.
408.3.
Cards that are facedown at Battleï¬elds have their gameplay properties and permissions deï¬ned by the effect that put them there. Example: Cards that players Hide with the Hidden keyword can be Played for [0] on any subsequent turn as a property of the Hidden keyword.
466.8.c.1.
Players may not Hide cards at Battleï¬elds controlled by their Teammate.
737.
Hidden
737.1.
Hidden is a keyword that acts as a prerequisite to perform the Hide Discretionary Action.
737.1.c.
It allows the player to take the Discretionary Action Hide.
737.6.
A card that is Hidden gains Reaction while facedown, and may be played any time a card with Reaction may be played as a result.
Hiding
408.1.
Hiding a card is the act of placing a card facedown at a Battleï¬eld you control.
408.2.
Hiding is a Discretionary Action.
Hold Abilities
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.
448.2.b.
Hold abilities trigger at a Battleï¬eld that was Held.
Hold Effects
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Holding is negated or replaced in any way, the Hold Effect will still trigger.
Holding
315.2.b.1.
Holding occurs at this time. See rule 445. Scoring for more information.
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.c.2.c.
If the act of gaining one point from Holding is negated or replaced in any way, the Hold Effect will still trigger.
446.2.
Hold: A player maintains Control of a Battleï¬eld during their Beginning Phase.
448.1.a.1.
Notably, points earned from sources that are not Conquer or Hold are not beholden to these restrictions.
448.1.b.1.
If the player has Scored through Hold, that player scores the Final Point.
I
Identiï¬er
184.2.
Control is a binary state for Battleï¬elds and an Identiï¬er for players.
Illustration
138.
Illustration
Inactive
134.4.
A cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
134.4.a.
The presence of text, rules, Keywords, and other effects can still be referenced and detected by other game effects, even while Rules Text is Inactive.
135.2.b
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
421.1.e.
Attaching one or more cards will cause those cardsâ€™ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
422.1.c.
The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive.
457.2.
When Rules Text becomes Inactive for any reason, it loses its Timestamp. When it ceases to be Inactive, a new Timestamp is established.
718.2.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
720.
Inactive
721.1.
Card text can occasionally be assigned to be ignored, disregarded, or otherwise rendered as not applicable during the course of play. This state is referred to as Inactive.
721.1.b.
Inactive Abilities do not trigger, do not apply, and cannot be activated. Inactive instructions are not processed.
722.
Inactive text is still present on cards.
722.1.
Cards with Inactive text still have keywords for the sake of Game Effects that want to reference or see if a card has a keyword.
722.2.
Game Effects that parse or interpret text to determine target eligibility may still parse Inactive text for the sake of eligibility. Example: Spinning Axe is a gear with [Temporary]. While itâ€™s attached and its rules text is inactive, its [Temporary] ability doesnâ€™t trigger. However, a spell that reads â€œDestroy a gear with [Temporary]â€ could still choose and destroy Spinning Axe.
723.
Rules Text is never Inactive by default.
724.
Effect Text is Inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
725.
Inactive text can partially cease to be Inactive under speciï¬c circumstances and exceptions.
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
Increasing
419.1.
Doubling is the act of increasing a numeric attribute by an amount equal to that attributeâ€™s current value.
420.1.a.
Swapping creates two different effects that apply to each attribute. One that Increases one value and one that Decreases the other.
420.1.b.
To accomplish this, determine the difference between these values and then apply an Increase for that amount to the lower value of the two attributes, and a Decrease of that amount to the higher value of the two attributes.
Information
107.1.f.
The cards in any player's Trash are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
107.5.f.
The cards in any player's Banishment are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
378.1.
Triggered Abilities on cards outside of the Board rely on the Information Level of the zone they are in.
Inherent Ability
143.
Units have the Inherent Ability to perform a Standard Move.
185.3.a.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Inherent Abilities.
Initial Chain
342.
When a Showdown begins, it may or may not begin with an Initial Chain.
342.1.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities.
342.1.b.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed.
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.
442.1.c.
The State Closes if an Initial Chain was created.
Instructions
134.2.b.
Instructions
376.2.b.
The Effect is the Instruction that follows the comma after the Condition.
Intrinsic Properties
142.
Units have multiple Intrinsic Properties unique to them:
147.
Gear have several Intrinsic Properties unique to them.
Invalid
356.3.e.7.
If all of an instruction's Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, that instruction will not execute.
356.3.e.8.
If an instruction has more than one Target and fewer than all of the Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, the instruction will execute, with only the Targets available and valid being operated on.
356.3.e.10.
It is possible for none of a spell's instructions to be executed as it resolves, due to all of them requiring targets to act on and all of those targets becoming Invalid or Unavailable. In this case, the spell has no effect but is still considered played. Example: A player plays a spell that reads "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld" with no other instructions, and chooses an enemy unit at a battleï¬eld. They also control a unit with the ability "When you play a spell, give me +1 [M] this turn." Before the spell resolves, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The spell resolves and its only instruction cannot be executed, but the unit's ability still triggers as the spell resolves and gives it +1 [M].
361.3.a.
Conditional Passive Abilities can be recognized by the occurrence of "if" or "while" as part of the statement of the ability. Example: "While I'm attacking or defending alone, I have +2 [M]." Example: "If an opponent controls a battleï¬eld, I enter ready."
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
Invalid Destinations
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
K
Keywords
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
134.2.c.
Keywords
134.2.c.1.
Keywords are short words or phrases that represent longer abilities or instructions. See rule 726. Keywords for more information.
134.4.a.
The presence of text, rules, Keywords, and other effects can still be referenced and detected by other game effects, even while Rules Text is Inactive.
155.
Certain Keywords on spells are not executable rules text, but instead intrinsic properties of the spell.
726.
Keywords
727.
A Keyword is a speciï¬c term that appears on Cards that acts as a shorthand for a speciï¬c game effect, or ability of any variety.
727.1.
A Keyword can be an ability.
727.2.
Keywords can be identiï¬ed by having a colored highlight behind them.
727.3.
Keywords can be referenced or speciï¬ed by other Game Effects.
727.3.a.
Other effects may grant Keywords.
727.3.a.1.
The deï¬nition and rules of the speciï¬c Keyword will determine the behavior if a Keyword is granted while it is already present.
727.3.a.2.
The effect that granted the Keyword will specify the duration for which it is granted.
727.3.a.3.
If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
727.3.b.
Other effects may remove Keywords.
727.3.b.1.
The effect that removed the Keyword will specify the duration it is removed.
727.3.b.2.
If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
728.
A card can have any number of Keywords.
729.
Similar to other rules text, execute any effects of Keywords in the order listed when reading the card from top to bottom of the rules text.
Kill Actions
415.5.d.
Abilities originating from Game Objects that are responsible for Kill Actions are responsible in addition to the Game Object that created them. Example: Falling Star is a spell that says â€œDo this twice: Deal 3 to a unit.â€ Immortal Phoenix is a unit that says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ A player plays Falling Star while Immortal Phoenix is in their trash. The â€œdo thisâ€ phrasing on Falling Star means that it has a reï¬‚exive triggered ability, which places two triggered abilities on the chain. As each of those triggered abilities resolve, it deals damage to the unit chosen for that ability. If one of these abilities deals lethal damage to a unit, both Falling Star and its ability are considered sources of the damage, and so both Falling Star and its ability are responsible for killing the unit. This means that Falling Starâ€™s controller killed a unit with a spell, so Immortal Phoenixâ€™s ability will trigger.
Kill Instruction
415.1.a.1.a.
This is referred to as a Kill Instruction.
415.1.a.1.b.
When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction, it ï¬rst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unitâ€™s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ï¬nalized before completing this Kill Instruction.
Killed
140.1.a.4.
Units can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
141.3.
Damage tracks how close a Unit is to being Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
142.2.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects.
142.2.a.
If a Unit ever has nonzero damage marked on it equalling or exceeding its Might, it is Killed.
146.1.a.4.
Gear can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
166.3.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
170.3.
Legends cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
414.2.a.
Banish is not a subset of Kill.
415.
Kill
415.1.
Killing is the action of a Permanent going to the trash from the board.
415.2.
When a permanent is killed it is placed directly in the trash from its place of origin.
415.2.a.
It is only considered Killed if its origin was any zone on the board.
415.3.
Killing is a Limited Action.
415.3.a.
Players may only Kill units when Game Effects direct them to do so.
415.4.
Killing can also be the result of resolving a Cleanup.
415.5.
Killing can be attributed to one or more Game Objects.
415.5.a.
The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object.
415.5.b.
A spell or ability that contains a Kill instruction is responsible for Killing the Unit or Gear.
415.5.c.
When one or more Units is killed due to a Cleanup, the spell or ability that resolved immediately prior to that Cleanup that applied damage to the Unit or Units is responsible for that Kill action.
734.1.d.
The Trigger for this effect is the Permanent being Killed and sent to the Trash.
734.1.d.2.
The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup.
L
Layers
450.
Layers
Legal Item
319.3.
After a Pending Item becomes a Legal Item on the Chain
320.1.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded.
Legally Timed
334.1.a.
Play a Card that is legally timed.
334.1.a.2.
A Legally Timed Card would be a Card with Reaction.
334.1.b.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
334.1.b.1.
All rules for legally timed cards apply to legally timed abilities.
344.1.
Play a spell that is legally timed.
344.2.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
Legend Zone
103.1.a.
This is placed in the Legend Zone at the start of the game.
106.5.
The Legend Zone
111.
Each player separates their Champion Legend and places it in the Legend Zone.
132.6.b.
Legends
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
169.
Legends
170.
Legends are Game Objects.
170.1.
Legends are Owned by a player.
170.2.
Legends are not shufï¬‚ed into Decks at the start of a game.
170.2.a.
Legends are not played during the course of regular play.
170.2.b.
Legends are established at the start of a game, and remain in place for the duration of regular play.
170.3.
Legends cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
170.4.
Legends cannot be Moved.
170.5.
Legends can be targeted by spells or game effects.
170.6.
Legends can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
170.7.
Legends can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
170.8.
Legends can have Activated Abilities. See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
171.
Legends are not Permanents.
172.
Legends may have one or more Domains.
172.1.
The Legend determines the Domain Identity of cards its owner can include. See rule 101. Deck Construction for more information.
Legion
738.
Legion
Lethal Damage
415.1.a.2.
Passive Kill is when the action is taken as a result of Lethal Damage or as a consequence for any other state.
Limited Actions
312.1.b.1.
Players can always take and make choices for Limited Actions when instructed, regardless of Priority.
398.2.
Limited Actions
398.2.a.
A Limited Action is a game action that a spell, ability, or circumstance of the turn's progression causes the player to perform. A player cannot perform these actions at-will.
400.2.
This is a Limited Action.
401.3.
This is a Limited Action.
402.3.
This is a Limited Action.
403.2.
This is a Limited Action.
404.3.
Dealing Damage is a Limited Action.
405.3.
Healing is a Limited Action.
406.3.a.
This treats Play as a Limited Action.
407.2.
Moving is a Limited Action.
409.2.
Discarding is a Limited Action.
410.2.
Stunning is a Limited Action.
411.2.
Revealing is a Limited Action.
412.2.
Countering is a Limited Action.
413.2.
Bufï¬ng is a Limited Action.
414.4.
Banishing is a Limited Action.
415.3.
Killing is a Limited Action.
416.4.
Adding is a Limited Action.
417.3.
Channeling is a Limited Action.
418.4.
Burning Out is a Limited Action.
419.2
Doubling is a Limited Action.
420.2.
Swapping is a Limited Action.
422.2.
Detaching is a Limited Action.
424.
Moving is a Limited Action.
Limited Play Effect
406.3.b.
Treat all steps of Play as normal, except as noted by the game effect creating this Limited Play Effect.
Location
106.2.c.
Each Base is a Location.
106.3.c.
Each Battleï¬eld is individually a Location.
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base.
166.5.
Battleï¬elds are Locations.
352.2.
For Units, choose a valid Location where that Unit will be placed upon being Played.
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
356.2.c.
If it is a Unit, it enters the Board exhausted at the Location that was chosen.
407.1.
Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
Loses
466.6.a.2.
If one player Loses, then the entire team loses.
M
Main Deck
052.
Card, when written in card effects, is shorthand for "Main Deck card." Runes, legends, and battleï¬elds are not considered cards when executing the abilities and effects of game objects. They are considered cards for the purposes of these rules.
103.1.b.
This will dictate the Domain Identity of the Main Deck.
103.2.b.
Your Main Deck can include up to 3 copies of the same named card.
103.2.e.
During Gameplay, the Main Deck is Secret Information.
103.3.b.
Must be shufï¬‚ed and kept separate from the Main Deck.
107.3.
The Main Deck Zone
107.3.a.
The space for the player's Main Deck.
114.1.
The Main Deck is placed in the Main Deck Zone.
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
128.2.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battleï¬elds and Champion Legends.
128.3.
The back side of a card is presented to conceal information for Private and Secret information cards. For example, cards in the Main Deck and cards in hand have their back side presented.
130.1.
Main Deck cards have a Cost, listed in the upper left corner of the front face of the card. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
132.4.
Main Deck Cards begin the game in the Main Deck or (in the case of a Chosen Champion) the Champion Zone.
132.4.a.1.
An umbrella sub-category encompassing Main Deck Game Objects that remain on the board after being played.
132.5.a.1.
A sub-category encompassing cards with the rune type. These are channeled rather than played. They remain on the board after being channeled, but they are not permanents, as they are not Main Deck cards.
157.1.
A Rune is not a Main Deck card.
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
315.4.b.1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
400.1.
Drawing a card takes a single card from the top of the Main Deck and adds it to the player's Hand.
400.4.
If a player attempts to draw more cards than are available in their Main Deck, they do the following:
403.1.a.
Main Deck cards are Recycled to the Main Deck.
403.1.c.
Each player Recycles cards to their own Main Deck and Rune Deck, regardless of which player is instructed to perform the Recycle action.
403.5.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Main Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in a random order. Example: Garbage Grabber has the ability "Recycle 3 from your trash, [1], [E]: Draw " To pay the cost of activating this ability, its controller chooses 3 cards from their trash and places them on the bottom of their Main Deck in a random order.
411.1.a.2.
Cards remain in the zone they are being Revealed from. Example: If a card is being Revealed from the top of a player's Main Deck, it is still the top card of that player's Main Deck.
411.4.a.
While cards are Revealed, those cards can be further manipulated, or accessed. They can even have their destination modiï¬ed for when the Reveal ends. Example: "Reveal 2 cards from the top of your Main Deck. Put one into your hand and Recycle the other" would be executed by taking the top two cards from your Main Deck to the table, and once every player present has had a chance to understand them you would make the selection of one of them to add to your hand. The one you did not select would then be Recycled to the bottom of the Main Deck.
418.1.
Burning Out is an action a player must perform if they attempt to move one or more cards from their Main Deck to any other zone in excess of the number of cards remaining in their Main Deck:
418.1.b.
If a player must put one or more cards from their Main Deck in any other zone, such as the Trash, in excess of the number of cards in their deck they will do so as much as possible, perform this action, and then complete the remaining number required by the instruction.
418.1.c.
If an instruction directs a player to look at or reveal cards in excess to the number of cards in a playerâ€™s Main Deck, that player looks at or Reveals as many as possible, but does not Burn Out, then proceeds with the rest of the instruction.
418.1.c.1.
If there are insufï¬cient cards among the looked at or revealed cards to perform subsequent actions to the revealed or looked at cards, any further instructions are ignored. This does not cause a Burn Out, even if those instructions would cause those cards to change zones. Reminder: Cards are considered in the zone of origin while being looked at or revealed, in this case the Main Deck.
418.2.b.
Recycles their trash into their Main Deck. Reminder: When multiple cards are Recycled to the Main Deck at the same time, those cards must be randomized
Make Relevant Choices
746.2.
When a spellâ€™s effect is performed an additional time with Repeat, choices must be made at the usual time during the Make Relevant Choices step of Playing a Card. See rule 346 Playing Cards for more information.
Mandatory
353.2.a.1.
Some Additional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Mandatory, and must be paid to complete playing the card. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and don't include the word "may." Example: A unit has the passive ability "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." To play that unit, a player must kill a friendly unit. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Mandatory Additional Costs
353.2.a.
Mandatory Additional Costs
353.2.a.2.
The cost imposed by the Deï¬‚ect keyword is a Mandatory Additional Cost. See rule 735. Deï¬‚ect for more information.
Match
462.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
463.5.
Setup: Each player selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are set aside and will not be used for this round of play. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone. After this game, the Battleï¬elds that were used are to be removed and not selected again for this Match. One of the remaining Battleï¬elds that were set aside must be chosen instead.
464.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
465.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
466.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
Might
134.2.e.3.
Might is represented by the â€œMight symbol,â€ which resembles a sword and shield. Its shorthand is [M]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [S].)
136.3
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
136.3.b
If the card to which a card with a Might Bonus is Attached has no Might value, the Might Bonus is ignored.
142.2.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects.
142.2.a.
If a Unit ever has nonzero damage marked on it equalling or exceeding its Might, it is Killed.
179.1.b.
Token units have a Might.
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
322.4.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash.
421.1.d.
The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it.
422.1.e.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached.
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
443.1.b.
Sum the Might of all Attacking Units.
443.1.c.
Sum the Might of all Defending Units.
443.1.d.
Starting with the Attacker, each player assigns an amount of damage equal to their summed Might among the other's Units.
703.
Each Buff individually contributes +1 Might to a Unit.
706.
Mighty
707.
Mighty is a description that applies to some units. Other game effects can check whether a unit is Mighty.
709.
A Unit "becomes Mighty" at the moment its Might changes from being less than 5 to being 5 or greater. Example: A Unit with Might 4 that gets +1 [M] becomes Mighty. Example: A Unit with Might 5 that gets +1 [M] does not become Mighty, because it was already Mighty.
710.
Units on the board are evaluated according to their current Might. Example: A unit with a base Might of 3 is targeted by a spell that reads "A unit gets +3 [M] this turn." As that spell resolves, its Might changes from 3 to 6, and it becomes Mighty. When that effect expires at the end of the turn, it will no longer be Mighty.
711.
Units in Non-Board Zones are evaluated according to their inherent Might. Example: A unit in the trash is Mighty if its printed Might is 5 or greater. It doesn't matter if there were effects raising or lowering its might while it was on the board.
718.4.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by the value listed.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
Might Bonus
136.
Might Bonus
136.1
Some cards have a Might Bonus in their lower right corner, expressed as an operator plus an integer.
136.2
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus can be +0.
136.3
A cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
136.3.a
The Might Bonus is applied while Attached and stops applying as soon as the card with the Might Bonus is no longer Attached.
136.3.b
If the card to which a card with a Might Bonus is Attached has no Might value, the Might Bonus is ignored.
421.1.b.
This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached.
421.1.b.1.
In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card, they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects.
421.1.d.
The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it.
422.1.e.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached.
454.3.c.
Might Bonuses of Attached cards are applied in this layer.
718.4.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by the value listed.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
Mind
133.2.c.
Mind is associated with the color blue and represented by a symbol resembling a sun and moon. Its shorthand is [B].
Mistargeting
356.3.e.9.
The process for a card's choice becoming Invalid or Unavailable is referred to as mistargeting. Example: A spell has the instruction "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld." Before that instruction can execute, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The instruction will not be executed, because it speciï¬es that the unit it chooses must be at a Battleï¬eld, and by the time it attempted to execute, the unit was no longer valid as a choice.
440.2.b.
Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base, where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting.
Mode Of Play
103.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battleï¬elds determined by the Mode of Play.
103.4.a.
The number will be dictated by your Mode of Play.
113.1.
Your Mode of Play will dictate how these are used and placed into the Battleï¬eld Zone. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
115.1.a.
The Mode of Play will specify how to determine a First Player.
115.2.
See the selected Mode of Play for any adjustments to each player's ï¬rst turn. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
168.
The number of Battleï¬elds on the Board is determined by the Mode of Play.
448.1.b.
When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score, and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play, the following occurs:
449.
When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play, they Win the Game immediately.
460.
A Mode of Play must deï¬ne several variables for the game.
651.4.
If the player has Teammates due to the Mode of Play, that playerâ€™s Teammates also lose and are removed from the game.
Modes Of Play
113.1.
Your Mode of Play will dictate how these are used and placed into the Battleï¬eld Zone. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
115.2.
See the selected Mode of Play for any adjustments to each player's ï¬rst turn. See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
316.2.b.1.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction.
316.2.c.
In Modes of Play with Teammates, spells may be played by Teammates of the Turn Player during this time, but the actions of the Turn Player take precedence.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
458.
Modes of Play
Move
143.3.a.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the units' Destination must be the same.
143.3.b.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the Origins do not need to be the same.
143.4.
The Destinations where Units can Move to with their Standard Move are restricted:
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
166.4.
Battleï¬elds cannot be Moved.
170.4.
Legends cannot be Moved.
319.7.
After a Move is completed
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
407.
Move
407.1.
Moving is the act of a Game Object moving between two Locations on The Board.
407.2.
Moving is a Limited Action.
407.2.b.
The Standard Move inherent to Units may also cause Movement. See rule 142for more information on the Standard Move.
407.3.b.
The Effect is Moving those Unit.
415.2.b.
This is not a subset of Move.
421.4.a.
This is not a Move.
423.
Movement
424.
Moving is a Limited Action.
424.1.
A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move, unless it is caused by a corrective Recall. See rule 407. Move for more information.
424.2.
A card changing game zones does not in itself constitute a Move.
424.3.
Moving is instantaneous.
424.3.b.
Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving.
424.3.c.
Moving does not use the Chain, nor is it able to be Reacted to.
425.
Moving is deï¬ned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
425.3.
Units are the only Permanents that can Move.
427.
Spells, Abilities, or other effects may cause a Move to occur.
427.1.
The source of the Move will provide details on any restrictions on legality for Destination.
429.
Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move.
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.
430.
Units may cause Combat when they Move.
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
431.
When a Move action is complete, perform a Cleanup.
433.
A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move.
434.
Recalls are not Moves.
434.1.
They do not cause Triggered Abilities to trigger that are triggered by Move actions.
434.3.
A Recall cannot be prevented by actions and Game Effects that restrict or block Movement.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
Move Destination
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
Mulligan
117.
In turn order, players perform their Mulligan.
N
Name
131.
Name
131.3.
Cards that are printed in different languages but represent the same card are considered to have the same name for the purposes of deckbuilding and gameplay. Example: Chemtech Enforcer in English and its counterpart in Chinese are considered the same card, despite the Name element on the card reading differently.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
Neutral Closed
310.2.
Neutral Closed: There is no Showdown in progress and a Chain exists.
Neutral Open
310.1.
Neutral Open: There is no Showdown in progress and no Chain exists.
310.1.a.
By default, cards can be played and abilities activated only when a player has priority on their turn in a Neutral Open state.
312.2.a.
When the turn is in a Neutral Open State during their Action Phase.
316.2.b.
This is denoted as a Neutral Open State, and only the Turn Player has the ability to play spells or activate abilities. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there.
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there.
Neutral State
308.
At any given time, the turn is in either a Neutral State or a Showdown State.
308.2.
If no Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Neutral State.
313.5.
If the turn is in a Neutral State, no player has Focus.
339.2.
The turn is said to be in a Neutral State if no Showdown is in progress.
No Changes Have Been Processed
453.
The layers are applied repeatedly until all effects operating on objects have been applied once and no changes have been processed.
Non-board Zones
107.
The Play Area also includes Non-Board Zones.
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
180.1.
If a token is put into any Non-Board Zone, it ceases to exist immediately after moving to its new zone.
327.
The Chain is a Non-Board Zone that temporarily exists whenever a card is played or an ability is activated.
356.3.e.2.
A target is illegal as the spell resolves if it no longer meets the targeting requirements of the spell, or if it has changed Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone.
356.3.e.4.
If a target changes Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone and then returns to its original zone, it is no longer a legal target, because it's not treated as the same object. Examples: An enemy unit at a battleï¬eld is no longer a legal target if it is no longer an enemy, no longer a unit, or no longer at a battleï¬eld. A unit with 3 or less Might is no longer a legal target if it is no longer a unit or if its Might is greater than 3. Something that's exhausted is no longer a legal target if it is no longer exhausted. (It can't stop being "something.") A spell that's played from hidden can normally only target its own battleï¬eld or something at that battleï¬eld. A target for such a spell may cease to be a legal target if it moves from the battleï¬eld where that spell was played, even if the spell has no location targeting requirement otherwise.
711.
Units in Non-Board Zones are evaluated according to their inherent Might. Example: A unit in the trash is Mighty if its printed Might is 5 or greater. It doesn't matter if there were effects raising or lowering its might while it was on the board.
727.3.a.3.
If an effect that grants a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
727.3.b.2.
If an effect that removes a Keyword does not specify a duration, the duration is as long as that Game Object remains on the Board or in its current Non-Board Zone.
Non-deck Cards
132.6.
Non-Deck Cards are not part of any deck and begin the game in a zone determined by their type.
Non-mandatory
353.2.b.1.
Some Optional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Non-Mandatory, and must be paid only if the player made the choice to pay them in rule 352.They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and the word "may." Example: A unit has the ability "As you play me, you may discard 1 as an additional cost. If you do, reduce my cost by [2]." While playing the unit, its controller declares their intention to pay the additional cost in rule 352, applies that additional cost in rule 353.2, applies the discount granted by paying that cost in rule 353.4, and discards a card to pay that additional cost in rule 354.2.See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Number Of Players
460.1.
Number of Players: How many people are playing the game.
O
One Set Point
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
Open State
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
155.2.a.1.
This indicates that, in addition to being able to be played during an Open State, this spell may also be played during Open States during Showdowns.
309.
At any given time, the turn is in either an Open State or a Closed State.
309.2.
If no Chain exists, the turn is in an Open State.
319.1.
After the game transitions to or from an Open or Closed state
330.2.
The turn is said to be in an Open State if no Chain exists.
333.1.c.1.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
336.2.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
374.
All Activated Abilities can only be activated on the Controlling Player's Turn and during an Open State.
376.3.a.
Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn.
Open State Outside Of Showdowns
151.
A spell can be played during an Open State Outside of Showdowns on its controller's turn.
Optional Additional Costs
353.2.b.
Optional Additional Costs
731.2.
Accelerate is an Optional Additional Cost to be paid as a player plays the unit with the ability.
746.1.
Repeat is an Optional Additional Cost keyword.
Optional Costs
353.2.b.1.
Some Optional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Non-Mandatory, and must be paid only if the player made the choice to pay them in rule 352.They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and the word "may." Example: A unit has the ability "As you play me, you may discard 1 as an additional cost. If you do, reduce my cost by [2]." While playing the unit, its controller declares their intention to pay the additional cost in rule 352, applies that additional cost in rule 353.2, applies the discount granted by paying that cost in rule 353.4, and discards a card to pay that additional cost in rule 354.2.See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Order
133.2.f.
Order is associated with the color yellow and represented by an angular winged symbol. Its shorthand is [Y].
Origins
143.3.b.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the Origins do not need to be the same.
166.5.a.
Battleï¬elds can be Origins of moves.
424.3.b.
Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving.
425.
Moving is deï¬ned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations.
425.1.
The Origin is where the Permanent is starting from.
Ownership
126.
Ownership
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
166.1.
Battleï¬elds are Owned by a player.
170.1.
Legends are Owned by a player.
177.
A token's owner is the player who controlled the effect that created it.
P
Pass Priority
334.1.c.
Pass Priority
Passive
415.1.a.
This can be Active or Passive.
415.1.a.2.
Passive Kill is when the action is taken as a result of Lethal Damage or as a consequence for any other state.
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.
Passive Abilities
166.8.
Battleï¬elds can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
170.6.
Legends can have Passive Abilities. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
353.2.a.1.
Some Additional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Mandatory, and must be paid to complete playing the card. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and don't include the word "may." Example: A unit has the passive ability "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." To play that unit, a player must kill a friendly unit. See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
353.2.b.1.
Some Optional Costs speciï¬ed by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Non-Mandatory, and must be paid only if the player made the choice to pay them in rule 352.They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and the word "may." Example: A unit has the ability "As you play me, you may discard 1 as an additional cost. If you do, reduce my cost by [2]." While playing the unit, its controller declares their intention to pay the additional cost in rule 352, applies that additional cost in rule 353.2, applies the discount granted by paying that cost in rule 353.4, and discards a card to pay that additional cost in rule 354.2.See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
361.3.
Passive Abilities can be conditional.
363.1.
Passive Abilities of cards in zones that are outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The passive ability "Play me only during an opponent's turn." applies in any zone from which that card can be played.
363.2.
Passive Abilities can alter the costs of cards as they are played.
365.1.
Passive Abilities can be Replacement Effects.
383.4.
Delayed Passive Abilities are Passive Abilities that are applicable only during a speciï¬ed window of time. The time that the Delayed Passive Ability applies will be recognized in the effect that initiates it.
733.1.
Assault is a Passive Ability keyword.
735.1.
Deï¬‚ect is a Passive Ability keyword.
736.1.
Ganking is a Passive Ability keyword.
740.1.
Shield is a Passive Ability keyword.
741.1.
Tank is a Passive Ability keyword.
Pending Chain Items
328.
Cards and abilities added to the chain are added as Pending Chain Items that become Finalized Chain Items.
328.3.
When a Pending Chain Item is no longer Pending it is ï¬nalized and becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
349.1.
When initially being played cards are Pending, as Pending Chain Items.
370.2.b.1.
Follow the steps of â€œPlaying or Activating Abilitiesâ€ in rule 386. This ability will become a Pending Chain Item.
Pending Item
319.3.
After a Pending Item becomes a Legal Item on the Chain
320.1.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded.
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
322.12.
8. Finalize any Pending Items on the Chain
328.1.
Pending Items are on the Chain.
328.2.
Chain Items are Pending until the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
328.3.
When a Pending Chain Item is no longer Pending it is ï¬nalized and becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
333.1.
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain.
333.1.c.2.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, repeat Step 1.
333.1.c.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute.
334.1.a.4.
The card will be added to the chain as a Pending Item, following the steps of playing a card.
334.1.a.7.
Playing a card will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize.
334.1.b.2.
Activating abilities will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize.
336.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, return to Step 1: Finalize.
336.4.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute.
349.1.
When initially being played cards are Pending, as Pending Chain Items.
349.2.
Near the end of the process cards will cease being Pending and become Finalized Chain Items.
351.2.
This item becomes Pending.
356.1.
This card is no longer Pending.
356.3.b.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, then the controller of those Pending Items completes Steps 2 through 5 of Playing Cards for those items before continuing. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
376.4.a.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ï¬nalized and enters the board.
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.b.2.b.
The Conquer Abilities of anything that references the player Conquering is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Conquer and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
376.4.c.2.b.
The Hold Abilities of anything that references the player Holding is put on the Chain as a Pending Item when the Condition that the player that controls the triggering source has performed a Hold and gained 1 Victory Point.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
381.1.
A new ability is created and added to the chain as a Pending Item. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
381.2.
If a Reï¬‚exive Trigger creates more than one Pending Item it creates them all in order, but does not go beyond the ï¬rst step of adding them to the Chain. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
388.
Abilities when added to the Chain become Pending Items until they complete the steps of Playing.
389.1.
Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
390.3.
If there are not enough options to make legal choices for a Triggered Ability that has been put on the chain, remove it from the Chain now. It ceases to be a Pending Item but never becomes a Chain Item.
392.2.
At this stage, players may decline to pay for Triggered Abilities that have incurred a cost. If they do, the ability will cease being a Pending Item and be removed from the Chain. It never becomes a Chain Item.
394.1.
This Ability is no longer Pending.
394.3.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, their controllers perform the remaining steps of playing now.
415.1.a.1.b.
When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction, it ï¬rst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unitâ€™s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ï¬nalized before completing this Kill Instruction.
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.
734.1.d.2.
The trigger will be added to the chain as a Pending Item before the card with Deathknell is moved to the trash due to a Kill instruction or a Cleanup.
744.1.c.1.
If paying costs or making choices for this ability causes triggered abilities to trigger, they will be placed on the chain above this ability in a Pending state. See rule 369 Activated Abilities for more information.
Permanent Abilities
732.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities.
738.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities.
739.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities.
Permanents
132.4.a.
Permanents
134.2.e.2.
The cost of Exhausting a Permanent is represented by the â€œexhaust symbol,â€ which resembles a card turning sideways. Its shorthand is [E]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [T].)
157.1.a.
This means, despite remaining on the Board until Recycled or otherwise removed from the board, it is not a Permanent.
167.
Battleï¬elds are not Permanents.
171.
Legends are not Permanents.
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
185.3.d.
That player may make decisions about any game effects created from "When you play me" effects of Permanents.
348.1.
Permanents become Game Objects when Played.
356.2.
A Permanent leaves the Chain and becomes a Game Object.
362.
Presence on Permanents
362.1.
Passive Abilities of Permanents are typically only active while on the Board.
376.4.a.
Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board.
376.4.a.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ï¬nalized and enters the board.
377.
Presence on Permanents
377.2.
Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board.
415.1.
Killing is the action of a Permanent going to the trash from the board.
415.2.
When a permanent is killed it is placed directly in the trash from its place of origin.
424.1.
A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move, unless it is caused by a corrective Recall. See rule 407. Move for more information.
424.3.a.
There is no state for Permanents between locations.
424.3.b.
Permanents are either at their Origin before Moving or their Destination after Moving.
425.
Moving is deï¬ned by the Origin and Destination of the Permanent that is changing locations.
425.1.
The Origin is where the Permanent is starting from.
425.2.
The Destination is where the Permanent is going to.
425.3.
Units are the only Permanents that can Move.
433.
A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move.
434.2.
A Recall causes a Permanent to change locations.
436.
Recalls do not affect the state of the Permanent being recalled.
734.1.a.
It is present on Permanents.
Permissive
732.1.
Action is a Permissive keyword.
739.1.
Reaction is a Permissive keyword.
745.1.
Quick-Draw is a Triggered Ability keyword. It is also a Permissive keyword.
Phases
306.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn.
316.5.b.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of a player moving to an empty Battleï¬eld are a stand-alone Phase and do not create a Combat.
319.2.
After the game transitions between Phases
Play
107.6.a.
Each player has a collection of cards they may Play cards from.
185.1.
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.
334.1.a.
Play a Card that is legally timed.
344.1.
Play a spell that is legally timed.
356.
6. Finalize this card and proceed with the card's category of Play.
406.
Play
406.1.
A player Plays cards by paying costs associated with that card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
406.2.a.
As long as a player has the resources to pay the costs associated with the card, they may play cards.
406.3.a.
This treats Play as a Limited Action.
406.3.b.
Treat all steps of Play as normal, except as noted by the game effect creating this Limited Play Effect.
406.3.c.
If there are no eligible cards to Play when instructed to Play in this manner like this, then nothing happens and resolution continues.
737.1.c.1.
Hide is not a subset of Play.
Play Area
106.
The Play Area includes a space for Game Objects referred to as The Board.
107.
The Play Area also includes Non-Board Zones.
108.
All Game Objects in the collective Play Areas are Public Information.
108.1.
Any player may view, or be provided with the details of the face-up information printed on the cards in the Play Area.
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
Play Cost
129.3.
This can be identiï¬ed in situations where the back is not easily discernible by the presence of the Play Cost in the upper left corner of the card.
Play Effect
376.4.a.
Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board.
747.1.b.
Weaponmaster is a Play Effect that chooses an Equipment you control and allows you to pay its Equip cost at a discount, regardless of the usual timing of the Equip ability, to Attach that Equipment to the unit with Weaponmaster.
Played
179.1.a.
Tokens are played by their owner if their card type is played, following all the applicable steps for playing a card plus any restrictions or modiï¬cations from the effect that created the token. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
347.1.
A card is Played when it has ï¬nished this process in its entirety.
347.2.
Tokens are not cards, but can still be Played. See rule 173. Tokens for more information.
348.1.
Permanents become Game Objects when Played.
348.2.
Spells create game effects that are executed, then the card is placed in the trash when Played.
352.2.
For Units, choose a valid Location where that Unit will be placed upon being Played.
406.3.
Game effects may result in cards being played as part of their resolution.
408.3.
Cards that are facedown at Battleï¬elds have their gameplay properties and permissions deï¬ned by the effect that put them there. Example: Cards that players Hide with the Hidden keyword can be Played for [0] on any subsequent turn as a property of the Hidden keyword.
746.3.a.
Regardless of the number of times a spell's instructions are executed with this keyword, the spell is only Played once.
Player
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
312.2.d.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes.
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
334.1.c.1.
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass.
335.2.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute.
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
343.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority.
344.3.a.
If all Players have passed once in sequence, the Showdown ends.
344.4.
Otherwise, Focus passes to the next Player in Turn Order.
422.2.a.
Players may only Detach cards when directed to by Game Effects.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
444.1.a.3.
Insert â€œ2e. Remove Attacker and Defender Designation from all Units and Players.â€
652.5.b.1.
If the removed player had Focus in a Showdown, the next Player in order receives Focus.
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
652.5.c.1.
If the removed player had Priority during a Chain, the next Player in order receives Priority.
652.5.c.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have passed Priority, then the most recent spell or ability on the Chain will resolve with Priority being re-established as appropriate for the state after the resolution of that spell or ability.
Playing
333.1.
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain.
352.2.b
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit..
388.
Abilities when added to the Chain become Pending Items until they complete the steps of Playing.
Playing A Card
107.2.c.
The Chosen Champion can be played from here as normal, following the rules of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
334.1.a.6.
Whether a Card is legally timed is evaluated during the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
370.
Activated Abilities are repeatable effects with a cost. They follow a process of going onto the chain and resolving, similar to Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
746.2.
When a spellâ€™s effect is performed an additional time with Repeat, choices must be made at the usual time during the Make Relevant Choices step of Playing a Card. See rule 346 Playing Cards for more information.
Playing Cards
107.2.c.
The Chosen Champion can be played from here as normal, following the rules of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
144.2.a.
This follows the same process as playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
148.2.a.
This follows the same process as playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
179.1.a.
Tokens are played by their owner if their card type is played, following all the applicable steps for playing a card plus any restrictions or modiï¬cations from the effect that created the token. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
328.2.
Chain Items are Pending until the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of playing a card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
334.1.a.6.
Whether a Card is legally timed is evaluated during the â€œCheck Legalityâ€ step of Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
336.1.
The newest item on the Chain resolves. Execute its game effects in their entirety. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information on resolving spells. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information on resolving abilities.
346.
Playing Cards
370.
Activated Abilities are repeatable effects with a cost. They follow a process of going onto the chain and resolving, similar to Playing a Card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
389.1.
Add a Pending Item to the chain representing the Ability that is either being Activated or Triggered. Notably, although this Chain Item will not have a card representing it, this will create a Closed State. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
390.1.
Make all choices required for this ability, such as targets, options, or other relevant decisions. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information
391.2.
Apply cost increases and decreases as a result of choices made in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
391.3.
Apply any other cost increases or decreases as necessary. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
392.1.
Pay costs as determined in the prior step. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
393.2.
Ensure that the Abilityâ€™s effect would not create an illegal state. If it would, resolve in the same way you would resolve a Card that creates an illegal state. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
406.1.
A player Plays cards by paying costs associated with that card. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
735.1.d.
It is an effect that imposes a Mandatory Additional Cost on Spells and Abilities that choose the permanent that has this ability. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
746.2.
When a spellâ€™s effect is performed an additional time with Repeat, choices must be made at the usual time during the Make Relevant Choices step of Playing a Card. See rule 346 Playing Cards for more information.
Playing Or Activating Abilities
334.1.b.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
336.1.
The newest item on the Chain resolves. Execute its game effects in their entirety. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information on resolving spells. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information on resolving abilities.
381.1.
A new ability is created and added to the chain as a Pending Item. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
381.2.
If a Reï¬‚exive Trigger creates more than one Pending Item it creates them all in order, but does not go beyond the ï¬rst step of adding them to the Chain. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
Point
448.1.
The player earns up to one Point, depending on their current score.
448.1.b.
When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score, and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play, the following occurs:
449.
When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play, they Win the Game immediately.
462.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
464.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
465.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
466.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
Power
130.3.
Power cost
134.2.e.4.
Power of a speciï¬c Domain is represented by its domain symbol and the corresponding shorthand. See rule 133. Domain for more information.
134.2.e.5.a.
When required as a cost, [A] can be paid by Power of any Domain.
134.2.e.5.b.
When Added to a playerâ€™s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain.
159.
Runes produce Energy and Power.
159.2.
Power is used to pay Domain-associated Power Costs.
159.2.a.
Power has a Domain.
159.2.a.1.
Power's Domain usually corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that produced it.
159.2.b.
Some Power is Universal and can be used to pay for costs of any Domain.
160.2.b.1.
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled.
162.
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs.
162.1.
When a card adds Energy or Power, it is added to the controlling player's Rune Pool.
162.2.
Players must ï¬rst add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs.
162.3.
Energy and Power do not have a physical marker or tracker, although players may wish to use a physical tracker if they are retaining unspent Energy and Power over the course of their turn.
163.1.
Any unspent Energy or Power are lost.
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information.
317.3.b.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost.
353.1.a.
If a card allows a player to play a card "ignoring its cost," its base Energy cost and base Power cost are set to zero.
354.1.
In total, pay the combined Energy cost (if any) and Power cost (if any).
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
Priority
312.
At any given time, up to one player has Priority.
312.1.
Priority is the singular exclusive right to take Discretionary Actions. See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information.
312.1.a.
The player with Priority can take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions.
312.1.b.
If no player has Priority, no player can take Discretionary Actions.
312.1.b.1.
Players can always take and make choices for Limited Actions when instructed, regardless of Priority.
312.2.
A player receives Priority at the following times:
312.2.d.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes.
312.3
When a player is granted Priority, it is either created if no player has it or taken from the player with Priority.
313.2.
A player who gains Focus also gains Priority.
313.3.
A player who passes Priority retains Focus.
313.4
A player may not make discretionary actions with Focus unless they also possess Priority.
320.1.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded.
333.1.a.
This process does not pass Priority.
333.1.c.3.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute.
334.1.c.1.
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass.
335.1.
If all players have passed Priority without adding any items to the Chain, proceed to Step 4: Resolve.
335.2.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute.
336.4.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute.
343.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority.
416.2.a.
Priority and Focus will not pass from Add abilities being ï¬nalized, and will resolve before any other outstanding items on the chain are ï¬nalized.
652.5.c.1.
If the removed player had Priority during a Chain, the next Player in order receives Priority.
652.5.c.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have passed Priority, then the most recent spell or ability on the Chain will resolve with Priority being re-established as appropriate for the state after the resolution of that spell or ability.
Privacy
107.1.f.
The cards in any player's Trash are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
107.3.c.
The order of cards in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
107.4.c.
The order of runes in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
107.5.f.
The cards in any player's Banishment are Public Information. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
127.
Privacy
127.2.
A card will have a different level of Privacy based on where it resides at a given time
408.4.
If a facedown card would be put into a zone whose Privacy is Private or Secret, or if the game ends, its owner reveals it to all players. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
Private
127.4.
Private: This level of Privacy indicates that only the controller of a card on the board or the owner of a card in any other zone may read or look at the face of the card. Example: Cards in a player's hand are owned by that player. Only that player may read or look at their faces. Example: If a player controls a facedown card at a battleï¬eld, that player and only that player may read or look at that card's face, regardless of who owns that card.
128.3.
The back side of a card is presented to conceal information for Private and Secret information cards. For example, cards in the Main Deck and cards in hand have their back side presented.
408.4.
If a facedown card would be put into a zone whose Privacy is Private or Secret, or if the game ends, its owner reveals it to all players. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
411.2.a.
Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects.
411.2.b.
During the course of a game of Riftbound, a player may choose to show Private information to one or more other players. This does not count as revealing and does not trigger any effects that trigger when cards are revealed.
Private Information
107.6.c.
The cards in a player's hand are Private Information.
128.4.
The term facedown is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's back side presented on the Board. A facedown cardâ€™s front side is considered Private Information.
409.1.a.
