The player who is performing the action chooses which cards to send to their Trash, and may use Private Information to do so.
466.8.e.
Hands are still Private Information.
Process Of Play
350.
The Process of Play
Public
127.5.
Public: This level of Privacy indicates that any player may read or look at the face of the card.
Public Information
107.6.d.
The number of cards in a player's hand is Public Information.
108.
All Game Objects in the collective Play Areas are Public Information.
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
129.6.
Cards are considered to be Public Information while in this state, even if obscured by other cards in a pile. Example: The Trash is Public Information because all cards there have their front face presented even while stacked.
Q
Quick-draw
745.
Quick-Draw
745.1.
Quick-Draw is a Triggered Ability keyword. It is also a Permissive keyword.
745.1.a.
Quick-Draw is present on Gear with Equip abilities.
745.1.b.
Cards with Quick-Draw have Reaction inherently.
745.1.c.
Quick-Draw allows cards to be played and Attached using Reaction timing.
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
745.2.
Multiple instances of Quick-Draw do not trigger separately and have no effect beyond the ï¬rst.
745.3.
Quick-Draw has no function while on the board.
745.4.
Quick-Draw, and whether or not a gear has Quick-Draw, is a characteristic of the Gear and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
R
Reaction
155.2.b.
Reaction
308.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Action or Reaction keywords can be played or activated in a Showdown State.
309.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Reaction keyword can be played or activated in a Closed State.
313.1.a.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed. Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords.
316.2.b.1.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction.
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
334.1.a.2.
A Legally Timed Card would be a Card with Reaction.
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
356.3.c.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
394.4.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells. See rule 326. Chains for more information.
416.3.
Activated abilities that Add resources and have the Reaction tag can be activated during the playing or resolution of other spells and abilities, any time that those spells or abilities require that resources be paid. Example: A player can add Energy and Power through any means before initiating the process of playing a spell. After initiating that process, in the Pay Costs step, they may activate Add Reactions to add Energy or Power to pay costs.
424.3.c.
Moving does not use the Chain, nor is it able to be Reacted to.
737.6.
A card that is Hidden gains Reaction while facedown, and may be played any time a card with Reaction may be played as a result.
739.
Reaction
739.1.b.
Reaction grants the corresponding card or effect all abilities and permissions of Action.
739.1.c.
Reaction, additionally, is functionally short for the following:
745.1.b.
Cards with Quick-Draw have Reaction inherently.
745.1.c.
Quick-Draw allows cards to be played and Attached using Reaction timing.
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
Ready
147.1.
Gear enters play Ready.
315.1.a.
The Turn Player readies all Game Objects they control that are able to be readied. See rule 402. Ready for more information.
401.1.a.
To mark it, rotate the card 90 degrees opposite of Readying, so that the orientation of the card is lengthwise in front of you.
402.
Ready
402.1.
Readying is an action that marks a non-spell Game Object as available for action.
402.1.b.
A Unit that is already Ready cannot be Readied again.
402.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Readied while it is already Ready, nothing additional happens.
402.2.
"Ready" is a state for Game Objects that other game effects and rules can reference.
402.3.a.
A player Readies all non-spell Game Objects they Control during the Ready Step of the Beginning Phase on their turn.
402.3.b.
The player may also Ready their Game Objects when effects or spells instruct them to do so.
719.4.
The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa.
Recalls
147.3.
If a Gear is at a Battleï¬eld for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
422.4.a.
If the Detached card was a Gear and this causes it to become present at a Battleï¬eld, it will be Recalled during the next Cleanup.
424.1.
A Permanent changing its position from any space on the Board to another space on the Board is a Move, unless it is caused by a corrective Recall. See rule 407. Move for more information.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
433.
A Recall is when a Permanent is relocated from anywhere to its Base without it being a Move.
434.
Recalls are not Moves.
434.2.
A Recall causes a Permanent to change locations.
434.3.
A Recall cannot be prevented by actions and Game Effects that restrict or block Movement.
435.
Gear can be Recalled.
435.1.
When an un-attached Gear is created or played at a battleï¬eld, or is at a battleï¬eld for any other reason, it is Recalled to its controller's base during the next Cleanup. Example: An Equipment is attached to a unit at a battleï¬eld, so the Equipment is present at that battleï¬eld. If the unit dies, the Equipment will be recalled during the next cleanup.
436.1.
Unless otherwise stated by the source of the Recall, Damage, Exhausted Status, Buffed Status, and applied Layer alterations will all remain unaffected by a Recall.
444.1.a.2.
Insert â€œ2d. Recall Attackers present at the Battleï¬eld if Defenders are still present.â€ See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
Recruit Token
181.1.
A 1[M] Recruit token is a domainless unit token with 1 Might and the Recruit tag.
Recycled
157.1.a.
This means, despite remaining on the Board until Recycled or otherwise removed from the board, it is not a Permanent.
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
160.2.b.1.
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled.
403.1.a.
Main Deck cards are Recycled to the Main Deck.
403.1.b.
Runes are Recycled to the Rune Deck.
403.5.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Main Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in a random order. Example: Garbage Grabber has the ability "Recycle 3 from your trash, [1], [E]: Draw " To pay the cost of activating this ability, its controller chooses 3 cards from their trash and places them on the bottom of their Main Deck in a random order.
403.5.a.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Rune Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in the order of their owner's choosing.
411.4.a.
While cards are Revealed, those cards can be further manipulated, or accessed. They can even have their destination modiï¬ed for when the Reveal ends. Example: "Reveal 2 cards from the top of your Main Deck. Put one into your hand and Recycle the other" would be executed by taking the top two cards from your Main Deck to the table, and once every player present has had a chance to understand them you would make the selection of one of them to add to your hand. The one you did not select would then be Recycled to the bottom of the Main Deck.
418.2.b.
Recycles their trash into their Main Deck. Reminder: When multiple cards are Recycled to the Main Deck at the same time, those cards must be randomized
Recycles
117.3.
Finally, that player Recycles the cards that were set aside. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
403.
Recycle
403.1.
Recycling cards is the action in which a player takes one or more cards from a speciï¬c zone and then puts it on the bottom of the corresponding deck.
403.1.c.
Each player Recycles cards to their own Main Deck and Rune Deck, regardless of which player is instructed to perform the Recycle action.
403.2.a.
The player must Recycle cards from the speciï¬ed zones when instructed to do so by game effects or costs.
403.3.
When Recycling is listed as a Cost, the action must be able to be completed for the cost to be paid. Example: Vi, Destructive has the ability "Recycle 1 from your trash: Give me +1 [M] this turn." Each time a player activates the ability, they must recycle 1 card from their trash to pay its cost. If they have no cards in their trash, they can't activate the ability, because they can't pay its cost.
403.4.
When Recycling is part of an effect, a player must Recycle as many cards as possible from the speciï¬ed zone or zones.
403.6.
This action, when instructed, is sometimes formatted as "Recycle X from [Zone]." That means to take X cards of the instructed player's choice from the relevant zone and recycle them. Example: Dr. Mundo, Expert has the ability "At the start of your Beginning Phase, recycle 3 from your trash." As that ability resolves, its controller recycles 3 cards from their trash. If there are fewer than 3 cards in that player's trash, they recycle as many as they can.
Reminder Text
134.2.d.
Reminder Text
Reminder: Lethal Damage Is Non-zero Damage Equaling Or Exceeding The Might Of A Unit
443.1.d.2.
Abilities or effects may inï¬‚uence the order in which damage is assigned. Reminder: Lethal Damage is non-zero damage equaling or exceeding the Might of a Unit.
Removal Of A Player
651.2.
If more than one player remains after a concession, follow the steps for the Removal of a Player.
652.
If the game continues, follow these steps for Removal of a Player.
Repeat
746.
Repeat
746.1.
Repeat is an Optional Additional Cost keyword.
746.1.a.
Repeat is present on Spells.
746.1.b.
Repeat is an optional cost that player may pay to execute the effect of their spells a second time.
746.1.c.
Repeat is formatted as â€œRepeat [Cost]â€
746.1.c.2.
If a spell has more than one instance of Repeat, each Cost may be paid or not paid individually.
746.1.c.3.
Each Repeat Cost can be paid only a single time.
746.1.d.
Repeat is functionally short for â€œYou may pay [Cost] as an additional cost as you play this spell. If you do, execute the instructions of this spell one additional time.â€
746.2.
When a spellâ€™s effect is performed an additional time with Repeat, choices must be made at the usual time during the Make Relevant Choices step of Playing a Card. See rule 346 Playing Cards for more information.
746.3.
Multiple instances of Repeat can be paid for separately. The spellâ€™s instructions will be executed an additional time for each instance of Repeat that is paid for.
746.4.
Repeat, and whether or not a spell has Repeat, is a characteristic of the Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
Repeatedly
453.
The layers are applied repeatedly until all effects operating on objects have been applied once and no changes have been processed.
Replacement
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.
Replacement Effect
154.2.
If a later part of a spell applies a Replacement Effect that alters earlier parts of the spell, apply those replacement effects as appropriate. Example: A spell says "Choose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn." and "[Legion] â€” Kill it now instead. (Get the effect if you've played another card this turn.)" If the Legion condition is satisï¬ed, the unit is killed immediately and the instruction to kill it the next time it takes damage is ignored, even if the unit remains on the board somehow.
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
365.1.
Passive Abilities can be Replacement Effects.
366.
Replacement Effects intercede during the execution of a Game Effect and alter its execution.
366.1.
A Replacement Effect can be identiï¬ed by the presence of the term "instead." Example: Zhonya's Hourglass reads "The next time a friendly unit would die, kill this instead. Recall that unit exhausted." This is a replacement effect that alters the execution of any Game Effect that would kill a friendly unit.
367.
A Replacement Effect can alter the typical ï¬‚ow of play, including other cards' executions.
368.
If more than one Replacement Effect applies to the same event being executed, then the owner of the object being acted on determines the order the Replacement Effects will apply.
368.1.
If it is a player being acted on, that player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply.
368.2.
If the affected object is an Uncontrolled Battleï¬eld then the Current Turn Player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply.
383.3.
Delayed Replacements are Replacement Effects that can be recognized by specifying the effect they are replacing at a speciï¬c time, or â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ in the description of the effect as it resolves.
418.5.
Burning Out is a Replacement Effect. See rule 364. Replacement Effects for more information.
Resolving
154.
When a spell is successfully played, a player executes the rules text of the spell. This is called Resolving the spell.
154.1.
Spells have their rules text executed from top to bottom when they are Resolved.
154.3.
While a spell or ability on the chain is Resolving, no other spells or abilities can be ï¬nalized on the chain or resolved, including triggered abilities or game effects that would occur as a result of the execution of the spell.
320.
While a Cleanup is occurring, Chain Items cannot be Resolved.
Reveal
411.
Reveal
411.1.
Revealing is the act of presenting a card to all players from a zone that one or more players do not have access to the information of.
411.1.a.
Revealed is a temporary state and is not a zone.
411.1.a.1.
Other cards, including the card being revealed, can reference the act of being Revealed.
411.1.a.2.
Cards remain in the zone they are being Revealed from. Example: If a card is being Revealed from the top of a player's Main Deck, it is still the top card of that player's Main Deck.
411.1.b.
Unless otherwise described, Revealed cards do nothing else beyond become temporarily known information to all players.
411.2.
Revealing is a Limited Action.
411.2.a.
Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects.
411.4.
Game Effects can manipulate or modify the cards Revealed while they are Revealed
411.4.a.
While cards are Revealed, those cards can be further manipulated, or accessed. They can even have their destination modiï¬ed for when the Reveal ends. Example: "Reveal 2 cards from the top of your Main Deck. Put one into your hand and Recycle the other" would be executed by taking the top two cards from your Main Deck to the table, and once every player present has had a chance to understand them you would make the selection of one of them to add to your hand. The one you did not select would then be Recycled to the bottom of the Main Deck.
418.1.c.
If an instruction directs a player to look at or reveal cards in excess to the number of cards in a playerâ€™s Main Deck, that player looks at or Reveals as many as possible, but does not Burn Out, then proceeds with the rest of the instruction.
466.8.e.1.b.
Revealing Cards is still a game action and cannot be done unless instructed. See rule 411. Reveal for more information.
Revealing Cards
466.8.e.1.b.
Revealing Cards is still a game action and cannot be done unless instructed. See rule 411. Reveal for more information.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers
380.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers are a type of Triggered Ability that create one or more Chain Items when their condition is met.
380.1.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers can be recognized by the phrase â€œDo this:â€ or â€œDo one of the following:â€.
380.1.a.
â€œDo thisâ€ can be followed by â€œN times.â€ The Reï¬‚exive Trigger will thus be added to the chain N times when its condition is met.
380.2.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers will be preceded by their conditions, if any. If no condition is present in the ability then the Reï¬‚exive Trigger will always be added to the Chain.
380.3.
If present, the Condition of a Reï¬‚exive Trigger will follow the same format as a Triggered Ability.
381.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers use the Chain.
381.2.
If a Reï¬‚exive Trigger creates more than one Pending Item it creates them all in order, but does not go beyond the ï¬rst step of adding them to the Chain. See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
Riftbound
128.1.
The back side of a card is the side with the Riftbound logo.
175.
Tokens can be represented by anything. Printed tokens are included in Riftbound booster packs, but they are not required to play a token.
411.2.b.
During the course of a game of Riftbound, a player may choose to show Private information to one or more other players. This does not count as revealing and does not trigger any effects that trigger when cards are revealed.
459.
There are multiple methods of playing Riftbound.
702.1.
Buffs can be tracked with a buff reminder card from a Riftbound booster pack or with any spare object in your surroundings.
Rules Text
134.
Rules Text
134.1.
All cards have a section that describes how they affect the game. This section is known as the Rules Text of the card.
134.4.
A cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
134.4.a.
The presence of text, rules, Keywords, and other effects can still be referenced and detected by other game effects, even while Rules Text is Inactive.
135.1
Some cards have a separate section of text below the Rules Text. This is referred to as the Effect Text.
135.2.c
The abilities in the Effect Text section of a card are appended to the Rules Text of the card to which the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
421.1.c.
The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text.
421.1.e.
Attaching one or more cards will cause those cardsâ€™ Rules Text to become Inactive for as long as they remain Attached. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
422.1.c.
The card being Detached has its Effect Text become Inactive and its Rules Text cease being Inactive.
422.1.d.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text.
457.2.
When Rules Text becomes Inactive for any reason, it loses its Timestamp. When it ceases to be Inactive, a new Timestamp is established.
718.2.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Rules Text is Inactive. See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
718.3.
While in this state, Abilities in the cardâ€™s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
719.1.
The Effect Text of all cards Attached to this card are appended to the Rules Text of this card for as long as they remain Attached.
723.
Rules Text is never Inactive by default.
744.5.
Whether or not a Gear has Equip may be referenced even if the Rules Text of the Gear is Inactive. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
Rune
103.3.a.
12 Rune Cards
106.2.e.
The Base also houses each player's Runes that are on The Board.
132.5.a.
Runes
156.
Runes
157.
Rune is a Card Type.
157.1.
A Rune is not a Main Deck card.
157.2.
Runes are kept in the Rune Deck.
157.2.a.
Exactly 12 Rune cards chosen during Deck Construction. See rule 103.3. Rune Deck for more information.
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
158.
Runes produce the resources needed to pay costs.
159.
Runes produce Energy and Power.
159.2.a.1.
Power's Domain usually corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that produced it.
160.2.b.1.
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled.
185.3.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
403.1.b.
Runes are Recycled to the Rune Deck.
417.1.
Channeling is the action of taking one or more Runes from the top of a player's Rune Deck and putting them on the board.
Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities
732.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities.
Rune Deck
103.3.
Rune Deck
107.4.
The Rune Deck Zone
107.4.a.
The space for the player's Rune Deck.
114.2.
The Rune Deck is placed in the Rune Deck Zone.
126.1.
For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battleï¬elds, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay. Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
128.2.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battleï¬elds and Champion Legends.
132.5.
Rune Deck Cards begin the game in the Rune Deck.
157.2.
Runes are kept in the Rune Deck.
157.2.a.
Exactly 12 Rune cards chosen during Deck Construction. See rule 103.3. Rune Deck for more information.
157.2.b.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck. See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
315.3.b.
The Turn Player channels 2 runes from their Rune Deck. See rule 417. Channel for more information.
315.3.b.1.
If there are fewer than 2 runes in the Rune Deck, they channel as many as possible.
403.1.b.
Runes are Recycled to the Rune Deck.
403.1.c.
Each player Recycles cards to their own Main Deck and Rune Deck, regardless of which player is instructed to perform the Recycle action.
403.5.a.
If 2 or more cards are Recycled to the Rune Deck simultaneously, they are placed on the bottom of that deck in the order of their owner's choosing.
417.1.
Channeling is the action of taking one or more Runes from the top of a player's Rune Deck and putting them on the board.
Rune Pool
130.1.
Main Deck cards have a Cost, listed in the upper left corner of the front face of the card. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
134.2.e.5.b.
When Added to a playerâ€™s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain.
162.
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs.
162.1.
When a card adds Energy or Power, it is added to the controlling player's Rune Pool.
162.2.
Players must ï¬rst add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs.
163.
Every player's Rune Pool empties at the end of each player's draw phase and the end of each player's turn.
164.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool. See rule 416. Add for more information.
315.4.d.
As the Draw Phase ends, each player's Rune Pool empties. See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
317.3.b.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost.
354.1.a.
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs. See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
416.1.
Adding is the action of putting resources into a player's Rune Pool.
S
Same Layer
455.
If more than one effect applies to the same Game Object in the Same Layer, or to each other in the same layer, then both effects will apply but their order may be determined by Dependency.
Score Abilities
448.2.
Trigger Score abilities at the Battleï¬eld that Scored.
Scoring
315.2.b.1.
Holding occurs at this time. See rule 445. Scoring for more information.
445.
Scoring
446.
A player Scores in one of two ways:
446.1.
Conquer: A player gains Control of a Battleï¬eld they did not yet Score this turn.
446.1.a.
In Modes of Play with teammates, Battleï¬elds under the Control of a teammate during the Beginning Phase are also disqualiï¬ed from being Scored through Conquer by any means.
447.
A player may only Score, from either method, once per Battleï¬eld per turn.
448.
When a player Scores, two things occur:
448.1.b.
When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score, and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play, the following occurs:
448.1.b.1.
If the player has Scored through Hold, that player scores the Final Point.
448.1.b.2.
If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has Scored every Battleï¬eld through either method this turn, that player scores the Final Point. If the player has Scored through a Conquer and has not Scored every Battleï¬eld this turn, that player draws a card.
448.2.
Trigger Score abilities at the Battleï¬eld that Scored.
448.2.c.
These will only trigger when the Battleï¬eld is Scored; I.E. These cannot be triggered more than once per turn for a player.
466.8.f.1.
When scoring the Final Point from Conquer, a player must Score each Battleï¬eld in the same turn, excepting any that were occupied by their ally during that turnâ€™s Beginning Phase.
Seating
115.1.b.
If not otherwise speciï¬ed, Seating then determines the sequence, play proceeding clockwise from the First Player.
Secret
127.3.
Secret: This level of Privacy indicates that neither player may read or look at the face of the card.
128.3.
The back side of a card is presented to conceal information for Private and Secret information cards. For example, cards in the Main Deck and cards in hand have their back side presented.
408.4.
If a facedown card would be put into a zone whose Privacy is Private or Secret, or if the game ends, its owner reveals it to all players. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
411.2.a.
Players may only Reveal cards from Private or Secret zones when instructed to do so by Game Effects.
Secret Information
103.2.e.
During Gameplay, the Main Deck is Secret Information.
107.3.c.
The order of cards in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
107.4.c.
The order of runes in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play. See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
Setup
104.
Setup
127.1.
A card will always exist in one of the many Zones described during Setup.
460.5.
Setup: Any changes to initial setup required for this mode.
462.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone.
463.5.
Setup: Each player selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are set aside and will not be used for this round of play. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed in the Battleï¬eld Zone. After this game, the Battleï¬elds that were used are to be removed and not selected again for this Match. One of the remaining Battleï¬elds that were set aside must be chosen instead.
464.5.
Setup: Each player randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are discarded and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the three Players before play and will be used for this game.
465.5.
Setup: Each player who is not going ï¬rst randomly selects one (1) of their three (3) Battleï¬elds. The other two are removed and will not be used for this game. The selected Battleï¬elds are placed between the players before play and will be used for this game.
466.5.
Setup:
Shield
740.
Shield
Showdown
143.1.c.
This action cannot be performed during a Showdown.
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
148.2.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
155.2.a.1.
This indicates that, in addition to being able to be played during an Open State, this spell may also be played during Open States during Showdowns.
184.3.d.
The state of a Battleï¬eld being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
308.
At any given time, the turn is in either a Neutral State or a Showdown State.
308.1.
If a Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Showdown State.
308.1.a.
Only cards and abilities with the Action or Reaction keywords can be played or activated in a Showdown State.
308.2.
If no Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Neutral State.
310.1.
Neutral Open: There is no Showdown in progress and no Chain exists.
310.2.
Neutral Closed: There is no Showdown in progress and a Chain exists.
310.3.
Showdown Open: A Showdown is in progress and no Chain exists.
310.4.
Showdown Closed: A Showdown is in progress and a Chain exists.
312.2.b.
When the turn is in a Showdown State and they gain Focus.
316.4.f.
Combat will also include a Showdown.
316.5.
Showdowns
316.5.a.
A Showdown occurs when a Combat occurs.
316.5.b.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battleï¬eld when the Contested status is applied to a Battleï¬eld with no current controller.
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
322.8.a
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battleï¬eld that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested
322.9
6a. If Units of an opposing player are present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Showdown staged before it can be Opened, the Showdown will cease being Staged
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there.
325.2.
During a Showdown
337.
Showdowns
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
339.
The State of the turn is partially determined by whether or not a Showdown is in progress.
339.1.
The turn is said to be in a Showdown State if a Showdown is in progress.
339.1.a.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State.
339.1.b.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State.
339.2.
The turn is said to be in a Neutral State if no Showdown is in progress.
340.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State.
340.1.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the ï¬rst step of Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
340.2.
If Control of a Battleï¬eld is Contested and the Battleï¬eld in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battleï¬eld to become Contested.
341.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battleï¬eld gains Focus.
342.
When a Showdown begins, it may or may not begin with an Initial Chain.
342.1.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities.
342.1.b.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed.
343.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority.
344.
During a Showdown, the player with Focus may do one of the following:
344.3.a.
If all Players have passed once in sequence, the Showdown ends.
345.
If all players pass Focus without playing a spell or activating an ability, then the Showdown Closes.
345.1.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Combat, proceed with the remaining steps of Combat to resolve the phase. See rule 441. The Steps of Combat for more information.
345.2.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Contested being applied to a Battleï¬eld without a controller, do one of the following:
429.
Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move.
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.
442.1.
A Showdown opens at this time.
442.1.c.1.
Otherwise the Showdown continues, with the State Open as normal.
443.1.
When the Showdown closes, Attackers and Defenders resolve Combat Damage at the Battleï¬eld that was attacked, using their current Might.
652.5.b.1.
If the removed player had Focus in a Showdown, the next Player in order receives Focus.
652.5.b.2.
If the player being removed creates a state where all Players have Passed their Focus, the Showdown ends and play proceeds as necessary, E.G. Combat is resolved or a Cleanup is completed.
732.1.b.
Action grants the corresponding card or effect permission to be played or activated during Showdowns, even when it is not the Controlling player's turn.
739.2.
The corresponding card or effect with this keyword is not restricted to Closed States or Showdowns. This permission is inclusive of all other timings and options available to the ability as written, Action's permissions, or by default.
Showdown Closed
310.4.
Showdown Closed: A Showdown is in progress and a Chain exists.
Showdown Open State
313.1.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
Signature
103.2.d.
Your deck may only contain 3 total Signature cards that have the same Champion tag as your Champion Legend.
132.7.b.
Signature is a supertype that may apply to game objects of any card type. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding. See rule 103.2.d.for more information about Signature cards.
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
Silver Rule
050.
Silver Rule
Simultaneously
143.3.c.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously.
Special Cleanup
317.2.a.
Invoke an End of Turn Special Cleanup. See rule 318. Cleanups for more information.
323.
Special Cleanups are Cleanup steps invoked at speciï¬c times that have additional steps not present in a normal Cleanup.
323.1.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and deï¬ned by the sub-section that invokes it. Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section deï¬nes what steps are added to the Cleanup.
323.2.
If events during a Special Cleanup require another Cleanup, a normal Cleanup is invoked, not another iteration of the Special Cleanup.
Special Cleanup Require
323.2.
If events during a Special Cleanup require another Cleanup, a normal Cleanup is invoked, not another iteration of the Special Cleanup.
Spells
132.4.b.
Spells
149.
Spells
185.2.
For Spells, they are the Spell's Controller.
316.4.b.
This could be the result of a Standard Move Standard Action, a Spell, or other Game Effect.
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
348.2.
Spells create game effects that are executed, then the card is placed in the trash when Played.
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
356.3.
A Spell lingers on the Chain.
358.
An Ability is the structured rules and capabilities of Game Objects or Spells.
372.
Activated abilities are present on Game Objects and some Spells.
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.
388.1.
When an Ability ï¬nishes the steps of playing it becomes a Chain Item just like a Spell.
394.5.
Otherwise, execute the Ability just like a Spell, then clear the Chain Item from the Chain.
427.
Spells, Abilities, or other effects may cause a Move to occur.
732.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities.
732.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Action is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
739.4.b.
Whether or not a Spell has Reaction is a characteristic of that Spell and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
746.1.a.
Repeat is present on Spells.
Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities
738.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities.
739.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities and Permanent Abilities.
Spending
702.2.b.
Spending a Buff removes a single Buff counter from a Unit.
Splitting
352.14.
Splitting
715.3.
If the Deal action Splits damage, then the Bonus Damage applies to the amount of Damage that will be Split. This can alter the number of targets eligible to be chosen. Example: Volibear, Furious is a unit that says in part â€œWhen I attack, deal 5 damage split among any number of enemy units here.â€ A player attacks with Volibear, Furious while they also control Annie, Fiery, a unit that says â€œYour spells and abilities deal 1 Bonus Damage.â€ Volibear, Furious now deals 6 damage split among any number of enemy units at its location, and can choose to split that damage among up to 6 units rather than the usual 5.
Sprite Token With Temporary
181.2.
A 3[M] Sprite token with Temporary is a domainless unit token with 3 Might, the Fae tag, and the Temporary keyword. See rule 742. Temporary for more information.
Staged Combat
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
439.2.
If Staged Combats stop being Staged before the Steps of Combat are initiated, they are not resolved or executed.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.
Standard Move
143.
Units have the Inherent Ability to perform a Standard Move.
143.4.
The Destinations where Units can Move to with their Standard Move are restricted:
143.4.c.
Ganking is a unique ability that affects a Unit's Standard Move
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
407.2.b.
The Standard Move inherent to Units may also cause Movement. See rule 142for more information on the Standard Move.
407.3.
The Standard Move inherent to Units is a Discretionary Action.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
426.
Players may choose to move their Units with the Standard Move. See rule 142.for more information on the Standard Move.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
466.8.c.2.
Players may not issue Standard Movement to their Teammate's Units.
Standard Move Standard Action
316.4.b.
This could be the result of a Standard Move Standard Action, a Spell, or other Game Effect.
Start Of Turn
315.
Start of Turn
316.1.
When all steps of the Start of Turn have been completed, the Action Phase begins.
Started
334.1.a.5.
This can be an additional card to the item that Started the Chain in the case of the ï¬rst Active Player after creating the Chain.
State
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
316.5.b.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battleï¬eld when the Contested status is applied to a Battleï¬eld with no current controller.
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
322.8.a
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battleï¬eld that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested
322.9
6a. If Units of an opposing player are present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Showdown staged before it can be Opened, the Showdown will cease being Staged
322.10.
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players.
322.10.a.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battleï¬eld as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there.
322.11
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battleï¬eld that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there.
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there.
330.
The State of the Turn is partially determined by whether or not the Chain currently exists.
339.
The State of the turn is partially determined by whether or not a Showdown is in progress.
410.
Stun
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
439.
Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleï¬eld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated.
439.2.
If Staged Combats stop being Staged before the Steps of Combat are initiated, they are not resolved or executed.
442.1.c.1.
Otherwise the Showdown continues, with the State Open as normal.
State Closes
442.1.c.
The State Closes if an Initial Chain was created.
Statements Of Fact
361.2.
They can be recognized by being statements of fact.
States Of The Turn
313.1.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
316.2.b.
This is denoted as a Neutral Open State, and only the Turn Player has the ability to play spells or activate abilities. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
351.1.
This Closes the State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
398.1.a.
A Discretionary Action is a Game Action that may be performed at any time during a player's turn during a Neutral Open State. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
Step 1: Finalize
333.
Step 1: Finalize
Step 1: The Showdown Step

Step 2: Execute
334.
Step 2: Execute
Step 2: The Combat Damage Step
