Step 2: The Combat Damage Step
Step 3: Pass
335.
Step 3: Pass
Step 3: The Resolution Step
444.
Step 3: The Resolution Step
Step 4: Resolve
336.
Step 4: Resolve
Steps Of Combat
316.4.e.
Play proceeds following the steps of combat. See rule 441. Steps of Combat for more information.
345.1.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Combat, proceed with the remaining steps of Combat to resolve the phase. See rule 441. The Steps of Combat for more information.
439.
Combat is considered Staged if there are units controlled by two opposing players at a Battleï¬eld but the Steps of Combat have not been initiated.
439.2.
If Staged Combats stop being Staged before the Steps of Combat are initiated, they are not resolved or executed.
441.
The Steps of Combat
Stun Units
410.2.a.
Players may only Stun Units when directed to by Game Effects.
Stunned Unit
410.1.a.1.
A Stunned Unit can not be Stunned again. Example: Eclipse Herald has the ability "When you stun an enemy unit, ready me and give me +1 [M] this turn." Its controller plays a spell that reads "Stun a unit." They may choose a unit that's already stunned, but if they do, Eclipse Herald will not trigger.
410.1.a.2.
Stunned Units lose the Stunned status at the beginning of the next Ending Step.
410.1.b.
A Stunned Unit does not contribute its might to damage in combat.
410.1.c.
A Stunned Unit must still have damage applied to it equal to, or greater than, its full might value to be killed.
Stunning
410.1.
Stunning is the act of selecting one or more Units on the Board and rendering them Stunned.
410.1.a.
Stunned is a binary state. A Unit is Stunned or it isn't.
410.2.
Stunning is a Limited Action.
Sub-categories
132.1.
A card can have one or more Categories and Sub-Categories based on the properties of its front and back sides.
132.2.
These Categories and Sub-Categories dictate the behaviors of the card during play.
Sub-phase
316.5.a.1.
Showdowns that occur as a result of Combat are a Sub-Phase of Combat.
Supertypes
132.7.
Supertypes are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed before a cardâ€™s type.
Swap
420.
Swap
420.1.
Swapping is the act of increasing one numeric value and decreasing another numeric value on some number of Game Objects such that their values are reversed.
420.1.a.
Swapping creates two different effects that apply to each attribute. One that Increases one value and one that Decreases the other.
420.1.c
If both attributes are the same numeric value, Swapping has no effect.
420.2.
Swapping is a Limited Action.
Symbols
134.2.e.
Symbols
T
Tags
132.8.
Tags are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed after a cardâ€™s type.
132.8.a.
Tags have no innate rules meaning, but may be referenced by game rules and card effects.
132.8.b.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
142.1.
Tag: A Unit has zero or more Tags representing one or more champions, regions, factions, or species it belongs to.
179.1.c.
Tokens may have one or more tags.
718.5.a.
Attached cards still have all Types and Tags while Attached.
Tank
443.1.d.5.
A player must obey all requirements and restrictions on damage assignment if able. Example: A player is assigning damage to the following units: a unit with Tank ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."); Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last."); and another unit without any abilities. That player must assign combat damage ï¬rst to the unit with Tank, then to the unit with no abilities, then to Caitlyn.
443.1.d.6.
If multiple Units have abilities or effects that require a player to assign them damage with the same priority, that player may assign damage to those units in any order. Example: A player is assigning damage to the following units: two units with Tank ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst.") and one unit with no abilities. That player chooses one of the units with Tank and assigns combat damage to it. Then they must assign any remaining damage ï¬rst to the other unit with Tank, then to the unit with no abilities.
741.
Tank
Targeting
352.5.
Targeting
352.6.
When a card Chooses one or more speciï¬c Game Objects to affect, it is Targeted.
352.11.
Some cards identify a group of Targets with Targeting Requirements that must be met by the group as a whole.
352.14.a.
If a card speciï¬es that an amount of damage may be split among some number of Units, then each Unit chosen is Targeted.
352.14.b.
The Targets are chosen when the spell or ability is ï¬nalized on the chain.
352.14.c.
A number of Targets can only be chosen up to, and not exceeding, the initial amount of damage available when the spell is played. Example: A player playing a spell that instructs them to "Split 5 damage" may only choose up to 5 units, but may choose fewer.
352.14.d.
Each Target is valid, and contributes to Chosen triggers individually.
352.14.f.
Each Target must receive a valid amount of damage.
352.14.h.
If, at resolution of the spell or effect, there are more Targets than available damage to divide, then the player who controls the effect dealing damage determines which Targets cease being Targets.
352.14.i.
Any costs that were paid, or effects that were triggered as a result of those Game Objects being chosen as Targets remain in effect, paid, or otherwise triggered.
356.3.e.7.
If all of an instruction's Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, that instruction will not execute.
356.3.e.8.
If an instruction has more than one Target and fewer than all of the Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, the instruction will execute, with only the Targets available and valid being operated on.
440.2.b.
Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base, where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting.
737.1.d.
Some choices made while playing a card from Hidden are restricted to the battleï¬eld where it was hidden. A card cannot be played from Hidden if it is a spell with no valid targets under these restrictions. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information.
744.1.b.1.
Equipâ€™s choice is a Target.
Targeting Requirements
352.11.
Some cards identify a group of Targets with Targeting Requirements that must be met by the group as a whole.
Teams
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
466.8.a.
Players may play spells during their Teammate's Turn.
651.4.
If the player has Teammates due to the Mode of Play, that playerâ€™s Teammates also lose and are removed from the game.
Temporary
181.2.
A 3[M] Sprite token with Temporary is a domainless unit token with 3 Might, the Fae tag, and the Temporary keyword. See rule 742. Temporary for more information.
742.
Temporary
Temporary Modiï¬cations
109.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modiï¬cations of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities. Examples: Damage is cleared. Buffs are removed. Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
Timestamp
457.
If more than one effect applies in the same layer but no dependency is established, then Timestamp order is applied to the effects within that layer and sublayer
457.1.
When an effect begins applying, it establishes a time for which it is compared against other Game Effects for purposes of resolving Layered effects as its Timestamp.
457.1.a.
Timestamps are not rote values.
457.1.b.
Timestamps are relative comparisons between effects and when they began applying to the game.
457.1.c.
Timestamps are not referenced by Game Effects in any way. They are only used to ï¬nalize layered effects.
457.2.
When Rules Text becomes Inactive for any reason, it loses its Timestamp. When it ceases to be Inactive, a new Timestamp is established.
457.3.
Effects are applied such that the earliest Timestamp within each Layer and Sublayer applies ï¬rst, followed by other Effects in that Layer and Sublayer in chronological order.
Token
132.7.c.
Token is a supertype applied to temporary game objects of any card type. See rule 173. Tokens for more information.
173.
Tokens
174.
Tokens are Game Objects created by spells and abilities during play.
347.2.
Tokens are not cards, but can still be Played. See rule 173. Tokens for more information.
Top-most Card
421.1.
Attaching is the act of linking two cards on the board together to combine their effects in some way. This causes one or more cards to become Attached and at least one card to become a Top-Most Card. See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
421.1.a.1.
One card will be designated as the one being Attached, and thus become Attached. The other will become the Top-Most Card.
421.1.b.
This is represented by physically laying the Top-Most card on top of the other or others such that all Effect Texts and Might Bonuses are showing, but nothing else from the card or cards Attached.
421.1.b.1.
In the situation where there is more than one card attached to the Top-Most card, they should be stacked in such a way that all Effect Text boxes and Might Bonuses are readable. The order of the Attached cards has no bearing on the application of effects.
421.1.c.
The Top-Most card has all Effect Text of all cards Attached to it appended to its Rules Text.
421.1.d.
The Top-Most Card has its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of all cards Attached to it.
421.4.
When a card Attaches to a card, its location becomes the same as the new Top-Most Card.
422.1.
Detaching is the act of unlinking two cards that are currently linked through the act of Attaching. This causes one to cease being Attached, and potentially causes the other to cease being a Top-Most card.
422.1.b.1.
To represent this, these cards should no longer be placed under the card they were previously placed under as Top-Most Card.
422.1.b.2.
If the Top-Most Card no longer has any cards Attached to it after this, it is no longer a Top-Most Card.
422.1.d.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have the Effect Text of the card being Detached appended to its Rules Text.
422.1.e.
The Top-Most Card ceases to have its Might modulated by the Might Bonus of the card being Detached.
422.4.
When a card Detaches from a Top-Most Card, its location is the same as the Top-Most Card from which it Detached.
422.4.b.
If the Attached card was Detached because the Top-Most Card changed zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, then the location that the Attached Card will Detach to is the last location the Top-Most Card was at before changing from a board zone to a non-board zone.
718.3.
While in this state, Abilities in the cardâ€™s Effect Text are appended to the Rules Text of the Top-Most Card.
718.4.
While in this state, the cardâ€™s Might Bonus modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by the value listed.
718.6.
Attached cards cannot be moved separately from the Top-Most Card they are Attached to.
718.7.
A card may be Attached only to a single Top-Most card at a time.
718.8.
Attached cards may have different Controllers from their Top-Most card.
718.8.a.
Changes in Control of the Top-Most card do not impact Control of Attached cards and vice versa.
718.8.b.
An Attached card still appends the abilities in its Effect Text to the Rules Text of the Top-Most card and modulates the Top-Most Cardâ€™s Might by its Might Bonus.
719.
A Top-Most Card is a card that has one or more cards linked to it through the process of Attaching.
719.2.
This card ceases being a Top-Most Card when there are no longer any cards Attached to it.
719.3.
A Top-Most Card and all cards Attached to it are at the same location.
719.3.a.
When the Top-Most Card moves, all Attached cards move with it.
719.4.
The Exhausted and Ready state of the Top-Most card does not affect nor change the status of the Attached cards and vice versa.
719.5.
When a Top-Most Card changes zones from a board zone to a non-board zone, all Attached cards Detach from it, remaining in their current zones.
719.5.a.
The player that controls the Top-Most Card that changed zones decides the order these cards Detach in, and thus the order of any relevant effects that occur due to the Detach occurring.
744.1.b.2.
The chosen Unit will become the Top-Most Card for the Attach action.
744.3.
Equipped is the state of a Top-Most Card being Attached by one or more cards that are Equipment.
744.3.b.
A Top-Most Card is Equipped as long as one or more of its Attached cards are Equipment.
744.3.c.
The state of being Equipped corresponds to a Top-Most card having a card with Equip that is Attached to it.
747.1.c.5.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost canâ€™t be paid, if it canâ€™t be detached from its current Top-Most card, or if it canâ€™t be attached to the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, it stays in its current location, Attached to anything it was already Attached to.
Total Cost
353.1.c.
Further additional costs and/or cost increases applied in subsequent steps may raise the card's Total Cost above zero. Example: Legion Rearguard is a Fury unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and has Accelerate. A player plays Legion Rearguard and is instructed to ignore its costs, but chooses to pay the Accelerate cost. They ignore Legion Rearguard's Base Cost of 2 Energy, but the optional additional cost of 1 Energy and 1 Fury Power is added to its Total Cost and must be paid.
Trash
107.1.
The Trash
140.1.b.
While in the Trash:
140.1.b.3.
Units can be affected by spells and game effects that target Units in the Trash.
146.1.b.
While in the Trash
146.1.b.3.
Gear can be affected by spells and game effects that affect Gear in the Trash.
153.
A spell creates a game effect according to its instructions and is then placed in the Trash of the player who owns it.
322.4.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash.
322.7.
5. Recall all Gear at Battleï¬elds. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battleï¬elds that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash.
356.3.d.
Otherwise, execute the game effect of the spell, from top to bottom of the rules text of the card and then place the card in the Trash of the owning player.
409.1.a.
The player who is performing the action chooses which cards to send to their Trash, and may use Private Information to do so.
412.1.a.
A card that is Countered does nothing and is then placed in the Trash.
415.1.a.1.b.
When a unit with a Deathknell is to be put in the Trash due to a Kill Instruction, it ï¬rst has its Deathknell added to the chain as a Pending Item. Note the unitâ€™s location, attributes, and other relevant information to process its Deathknell when ï¬nalized before completing this Kill Instruction.
418.1.b.
If a player must put one or more cards from their Main Deck in any other zone, such as the Trash, in excess of the number of cards in their deck they will do so as much as possible, perform this action, and then complete the remaining number required by the instruction.
734.1.d.
The Trigger for this effect is the Permanent being Killed and sent to the Trash.
734.1.d.1.
If the Permanent with the effect is not sent to the Trash, for example because its "killed" event was replaced with a recall, the Deathknell will not occur.
734.1.d.3.
Before the card with Deathknell is moved to the Trash, note its location, its attributes, and any other details related to the effect of its Deathknell to process the trigger after it has been Finalized.
Trigger
376.2.c.
The Condition of a Trigger is evaluated after a potentially inciting event has been processed.
376.2.c.1.
If a Game Object with a Triggered Ability that is active in a speciï¬c zone, it is evaluated and subsequently triggered if it enters that zone at the same time that its Triggerâ€™s condition is met. Example: Immortal Phoenix says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ This ability triggers if Immortal Phoenix is in your trash immediately after you kill a unit with a spell, even if the unit you killed with a spell was that Immortal Phoenix.
376.2.c.2.
A Game Object will not be able to successfully be able to evaluate its Trigger Condition, however, if it leaves the zone that its Trigger is active from at the same time that its Trigger is satisï¬ed. Example: Viktor, Leader says â€œWhen another non-Recruit unit you control dies, play a 1 [M] Recruit unit token into your base.â€ This ability triggers if Viktor is on the board immediately after another non-Recruit unit you control dies. It does not trigger if Viktor and another non-Recruit unit you control die during the same game action (for instance, if they are both killed in the same Cleanup due to the damage dealt by Unchecked Power).
376.3.b.
If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain.
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.
390.3.b.
If there are legal options to choose, the abilityâ€™s controller must choose them. They may not decline this stage of playing a Trigger.
725.1.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Attaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Attaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Attaches.
725.2.
If an Attached card has a Passive or Replacement ability that applies during the process of Detaching or a Triggered ability that triggers off of Detaching, that text exists and can be processed as it Detaches.
734.2.a.
The controller will choose the order to add these Triggers to the chain.
Trigger Condition
376.2.c.2.
A Game Object will not be able to successfully be able to evaluate its Trigger Condition, however, if it leaves the zone that its Trigger is active from at the same time that its Trigger is satisï¬ed. Example: Viktor, Leader says â€œWhen another non-Recruit unit you control dies, play a 1 [M] Recruit unit token into your base.â€ This ability triggers if Viktor is on the board immediately after another non-Recruit unit you control dies. It does not trigger if Viktor and another non-Recruit unit you control die during the same game action (for instance, if they are both killed in the same Cleanup due to the damage dealt by Unchecked Power).
Triggered Abilities
166.9.
Battleï¬elds can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
170.7.
Legends can have Triggered Abilities. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
303.2.a.
If one or more actions, game effects, or Triggered Abilities are activated simultaneously, then Turn Order is referenced to organize the sequence of actions. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
342.1.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities.
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
342.1.b.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed.
352.4.b.
This does not include making choices for Triggered Abilities of permanents, even if those abilities trigger when the permanent is played. Example: A unit with a triggered ability that says "When I'm played, kill a unit" does not require you to choose a target as it's played. The target will be chosen when the ability triggers. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
358.1.
An Ability has multiple structures. -Passive Abilities -Replacement Effects -Activated Abilities -Triggered Abilities -Delayed Abilities
376.
Triggered Abilities are repeatable effects that happen when a Condition is met.
376.1.
Triggered Abilities can usually be recognized by the word "when" followed by a game action or event; the word "at" followed by a point in time during the turn sequence; or the phrase â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ followed by a game action or event. Examples: "When you conquer here, you may spend a buff to draw 1." "At the end of your turn, ready 2 runes." â€œThe ï¬rst time I move each turn, you may ready something else that's exhausted.â€
376.2.
Triggered Abilities have a Condition and an Effect.
376.2.c.1.
If a Game Object with a Triggered Ability that is active in a speciï¬c zone, it is evaluated and subsequently triggered if it enters that zone at the same time that its Triggerâ€™s condition is met. Example: Immortal Phoenix says â€œWhen you kill a unit with a spell, you may pay [1][C] to play me from your trash.â€ This ability triggers if Immortal Phoenix is in your trash immediately after you kill a unit with a spell, even if the unit you killed with a spell was that Immortal Phoenix.
376.3.
When a Condition is met, a Triggered Ability behaves like an Activated Ability and is placed on the Chain.
376.3.a.
Triggered Abilities can be put on the Chain during Closed States or Open States on any player's turn.
376.3.b.
If more than one Triggered Ability is Triggered simultaneously, then the player that controls the Abilities selects the order to place them on the Chain.
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.
376.4.a.
Play Effects are Triggered Abilities with the Condition that the Permanent that has the Play Effect being played to the board.
376.4.a.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Permanent these effects correspond to is ï¬nalized and enters the board.
376.4.a.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Play Effects.
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action.
376.4.b.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Conquer Effects.
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action.
376.4.c.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Hold Effects.
376.4.d.
Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.d.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Attack Triggers.
376.4.e.
Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
376.4.e.3.
These Triggered Abilities can be referred to as Defend Triggers.
377.2.
Triggered Abilities of Permanents are only able to have their Conditions evaluated while on the Board.
378.1.
Triggered Abilities on cards outside of the Board rely on the Information Level of the zone they are in.
378.2.
Triggered Abilities outside of the Board will self-describe their context. Example: The triggered ability "When you conquer, you may discard 1 to return this from your trash to your hand." triggers while the card it's on is in the trash, and not anywhere else.
380.
Reï¬‚exive Triggers are a type of Triggered Ability that create one or more Chain Items when their condition is met.
380.3.
If present, the Condition of a Reï¬‚exive Trigger will follow the same format as a Triggered Ability.
383.2.
Delayed Triggers are Triggered Abilities that can be recognized by describing a speciï¬c time of the turn, or by structuring a Triggered Ability with a speciï¬c frame of time as a restriction.
390.3.
If there are not enough options to make legal choices for a Triggered Ability that has been put on the chain, remove it from the Chain now. It ceases to be a Pending Item but never becomes a Chain Item.
391.1.b.
Triggered Abilities will typically not have a base cost associated with them when placed on the chain due to their conditions.
392.2.
At this stage, players may decline to pay for Triggered Abilities that have incurred a cost. If they do, the ability will cease being a Pending Item and be removed from the Chain. It never becomes a Chain Item.
409.1.b.
â€œWhen I am discardedâ€ abilities or other Triggered Abilities that trigger on discarding are executed after discarding has occurred.
434.1.
They do not cause Triggered Abilities to trigger that are triggered by Move actions.
442.1.b.
Finalize items on the Initial Chain if establishing Attacker and Defender has caused Triggered Abilities to become Pending.
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
734.1.
Deathknell is a Triggered Ability keyword.
742.1.
Temporary is a Triggered Ability keyword.
743.1.
Vision is a Triggered Ability keyword.
744.2.a.
This is an event other Game Effects and Triggered Abilities can reference.
745.1.
Quick-Draw is a Triggered Ability keyword. It is also a Permissive keyword.
747.1.
Weaponmaster is a Triggered Ability keyword.
Turn Order
115.
Determine Turn Order using any fair random method agreed on by all players.
115.1.
Turn Order is established as a repeating set of the players.
115.1.c.
Turn Order repeats until the game ends.
301.
The Turn
303.2.a.
If one or more actions, game effects, or Triggered Abilities are activated simultaneously, then Turn Order is referenced to organize the sequence of actions. See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
306.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn.
312.2.d.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes.
317.4.
The Turn Player then becomes the next player in Turn Order.
330.
The State of the Turn is partially determined by whether or not the Chain currently exists.
334.1.c.1.
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass.
335.2.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute.
342.1.a.
These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain ï¬rst by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
344.4.
Otherwise, Focus passes to the next Player in Turn Order.
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.
442.1.b.1.
The Attacking player, who has Focus, places Triggered Abilities on the Chain ï¬rst, followed by all non-Defender players in Turn Order, followed by the Defending Player.
466.8.a.
Players may play spells during their Teammate's Turn.
652.5.a.1.
If the removed player was the Turn Player, play proceeds in Turn Order to the next available player in order.
Turn Player
115.1.b.1.
The First Player is the player who becomes the Turn Player ï¬rst.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
304.
The Turn Player is the player taking the current turn.
305.
When there are no items on the Chain and the Turn Player cannot or chooses not to perform any Discretionary Actions, the current phase or step of the turn ends and the next phase, step, or turn begins.
306.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn.
315.1.a.
The Turn Player readies all Game Objects they control that are able to be readied. See rule 402. Ready for more information.
315.2.b.2.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battleï¬elds held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualiï¬ed from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
315.3.a.
The Turn Player gains their additional runes for the turn.
315.3.b.
The Turn Player channels 2 runes from their Rune Deck. See rule 417. Channel for more information.
315.4.a.
The Turn Player gains their additional card for the turn.
315.4.b.
The Turn Player draws 1.
315.4.b.1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out. See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
315.4.b.2.
After completing the Burn Out the Turn Player still Draws 1.
316.2.b.
This is denoted as a Neutral Open State, and only the Turn Player has the ability to play spells or activate abilities. See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
316.2.b.1.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction.
316.2.c.
In Modes of Play with Teammates, spells may be played by Teammates of the Turn Player during this time, but the actions of the Turn Player take precedence.
317.4.
The Turn Player then becomes the next player in Turn Order.
322.13.
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. A Showdown begins there.
322.14.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battleï¬elds, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battleï¬elds. Combat begins there.
332.2.
The Active Player is a designator similar to, but distinct from, Turn Player.
332.3.
Similar to the Turn Player, this designation will pass between players over the course of play.
376.3.b.1.
If multiple players separately control Triggered Abilities that are Triggered simultaneously, then starting with the Turn Player and proceeding in Turn Order, each player orders their Triggered Abilities on the Chain.
439.1.
If more than one Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ï¬rst.
652.5.a.1.
If the removed player was the Turn Player, play proceeds in Turn Order to the next available player in order.
Two Set Points
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
Type
179.1.d.
Tokens have a type. They follow all rules for their type unless otherwise speciï¬ed. Example: A token unit is a unit. It enters exhausted, can take the standard move action, deals damage equal to its Might in combat, is destroyed if it takes damage equal to or greater than its might, can be chosen or otherwise affected by spells or abilities that choose or affect units, etc.
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
718.5.a.
Attached cards still have all Types and Tags while Attached.
U
Unavailable
356.3.e.7.
If all of an instruction's Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, that instruction will not execute.
356.3.e.8.
If an instruction has more than one Target and fewer than all of the Targets become Invalid or Unavailable by the time the spell is ï¬nished being played, the instruction will execute, with only the Targets available and valid being operated on.
356.3.e.9.
The process for a card's choice becoming Invalid or Unavailable is referred to as mistargeting. Example: A spell has the instruction "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld." Before that instruction can execute, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The instruction will not be executed, because it speciï¬es that the unit it chooses must be at a Battleï¬eld, and by the time it attempted to execute, the unit was no longer valid as a choice.
356.3.e.10.
It is possible for none of a spell's instructions to be executed as it resolves, due to all of them requiring targets to act on and all of those targets becoming Invalid or Unavailable. In this case, the spell has no effect but is still considered played. Example: A player plays a spell that reads "Deal 2 to a unit at a battleï¬eld" with no other instructions, and chooses an enemy unit at a battleï¬eld. They also control a unit with the ability "When you play a spell, give me +1 [M] this turn." Before the spell resolves, the chosen unit is moved to its base. The spell resolves and its only instruction cannot be executed, but the unit's ability still triggers as the spell resolves and gives it +1 [M].
Uncontrolled
184.2.a.
A Battleï¬eld is Controlled or Uncontrolled.
184.6.b.
While a Battleï¬eld is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise speciï¬ed, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arenaâ€™s Greatest is a battleï¬eld that reads â€œAt the start of each player's ï¬rst Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.â€ This ability will usually trigger while the battleï¬eld has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.
322.6.
4. Battleï¬elds with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled.
322.8.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battleï¬eld that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
444.2.d.
If there are no Units remaining here controlled by any player, the Battleï¬eld becomes Uncontrolled.
Uncontrolled Battleï¬eld
368.2.
If the affected object is an Uncontrolled Battleï¬eld then the Current Turn Player decides the order the Replacement Effects will apply.
Unique Abilities
185.3.b.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Unique Abilities.
Unique Rules
460.8.
Unique Rules
466.8.
Unique Rules
Unit
108.2.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information. Examples: If a Unit is Buffed If a Gear is Exhausted Etc.
132.4.a.2.
Unit and Gear are permanent types.
139.
Units
140.
Unit is:
140.1.a.1.
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battleï¬eld or their Base.
140.1.a.2.
Units and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
140.1.a.3.
Units can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, affects, or game actions that specify Units.
140.1.a.4.
Units can be Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
140.1.b.1.
Units are treated as Cards, similar to when in the Hand.
140.1.b.2.
They retain the properties of being a Unit, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that target Units on the Board.
140.1.b.3.
Units can be affected by spells and game effects that target Units in the Trash.
141.
Damage is a marked value that is applied to Units.
141.3.
Damage tracks how close a Unit is to being Killed. See rule 415. Kill for more information.
142.
Units have multiple Intrinsic Properties unique to them:
142.1.
Tag: A Unit has zero or more Tags representing one or more champions, regions, factions, or species it belongs to.
142.2.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects.
142.2.a.
If a Unit ever has nonzero damage marked on it equalling or exceeding its Might, it is Killed.
142.3.
Units can have damage marked on them.
142.3.a.
When spells, abilities, or other game effects deal damage, Units mark that damage on them temporarily. This can be tracked with coins, dice, or other markers, or by memory.
142.3.b.
Damage is Healed from Units at two speciï¬c times:
142.4.
Units enter the Board exhausted.
143.
Units have the Inherent Ability to perform a Standard Move.
143.2.
Exhausting the Unit is the Cost for this action.
143.3.
Players may perform multiple Units' standard move simultaneously.
143.3.c.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously.
143.4.
The Destinations where Units can Move to with their Standard Move are restricted:
143.4.a.
Units may move from their Base to a Battleï¬eld.
143.4.b.
Units may move from a Battleï¬eld to their Base.
143.4.c.
Ganking is a unique ability that affects a Unit's Standard Move
143.4.c.1.
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battleï¬eld to Battleï¬eld. See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
144.
Units may have Activated Abilities.
144.2.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
159.2.b.
Some Power is Universal and can be used to pay for costs of any Domain.
166.6.
Any number of Units can be present at a Battleï¬eld.
184.3.a.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battleï¬eld when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battleï¬eld Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
184.3.a.1.
Units moving to or being played to a battleï¬eld apply Contested status if that battleï¬eld is not already contested and that Unitâ€™s controller does not already control that battleï¬eld.
184.4.
Control is established by having Units at a Battleï¬eld at the end of a Showdown or Combat after applying the contested status.
184.4.a.
If a player controls Units at a Battleï¬eld, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battleï¬eld for as long as they have Units at that Battleï¬eld.
184.4.c.
If a player has no Units at a Battleï¬eld, they lose Control of that Battleï¬eld immediately, unless it is Contested.
316.4.a.
A Combat phase occurs as a result of Units controlled by opposing players being present at the same Battleï¬eld.
317.2.b.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€
322.3
2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
322.4.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash.
322.5.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress
322.5.a.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now
322.5.b.
If there are Units present at the Battleï¬eld the Combat is taking place at, but have the opposite designation of their controller, they lose that designation, and gain the same designation as their controller now
322.5.c.
If there are Units at locations other than the Battleï¬eld that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
322.6.
4. Battleï¬elds with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled.
322.10.a.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battleï¬eld as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there.
333.1.c.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute. See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
345.2.b.
If two playersâ€™ Units remain at the Battleï¬eld, Control cannot be established and the Battleï¬eld remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
352.2.
For Units, choose a valid Location where that Unit will be placed upon being Played.
352.2.b
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit..
352.3.
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
352.14.a.
If a card speciï¬es that an amount of damage may be split among some number of Units, then each Unit chosen is Targeted.
355.2.
Ensure that the outcome of the effect of this card being played would not create an illegal state. Example: Check that a spell's execution does not create a state where a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by 3 different players.
356.2.c.
If it is a Unit, it enters the Board exhausted at the Location that was chosen.
376.4.a.1.
These are commonly structured as â€œWhen you play meâ€¦â€ for Units and â€œWhen you play thisâ€¦â€ for Gear.
376.4.b.
Conquer Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit participating in, and successfully Conquering a Battleï¬eld.
376.4.b.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Conquer action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Conquer action.
376.4.b.2.a.
The Conquer Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit(s) these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player gains control of it and gains 1 Victory Point from Conquering.
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
376.4.c.2.
This category of Triggered Abilities encompasses only those that are triggered from Units that were present during the Hold action, or Abilities that reference the player that performed the Hold action.
376.4.c.2.a.
The Hold Abilities of Units are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to are present at a Battleï¬eld when a player maintains control of it and Gains 1 Victory Point during their Beginning Phase from Holding.
376.4.d.
Attack Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Attacker designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.d.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Attacker designation during Combat.
376.4.d.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Attacker designation multiple times in the same combat.
376.4.e.
Defend Triggers are Triggered Abilities that trigger when a Unit gains the Defender designation for the ï¬rst time during a combat.
376.4.e.2.
These Triggered Abilities are put on the Chain as Pending Items after the Unit these effects correspond to gains the Defender designation during Combat.
376.4.e.2.a.
These triggers can only become fulï¬lled once per combat, despite a Unit being able to gain and lose the Defender designation multiple times in the same combat.
385.
Delayed Abilities are not associated with Units or Gear; they are created by other Abilities or Spells. As such they are executed when their condition and/or speciï¬ed time occurs regardless of whether the source of the Delayed Ability is still on the board or not.
388.2.
When an Ability with the [Add] action is ï¬nalized it resolves immediately instead of becoming a Chain Item, like a Unit or Gear.
398.1.b.3.
As long as it does not result in any forbidden action being taken or game state being created. Example: A player can't use the Standard Move discretionary action to move a unit to a Battleï¬eld that's already occupied by Units controlled by two other players.
401.1.b.
A Unit that is already Exhausted cannot be Exhausted again.
401.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Exhausted while it is already Exhausted, nothing additional happens.
402.1.b.
A Unit that is already Ready cannot be Readied again.
402.1.c.
If a Unit is instructed to be Readied while it is already Ready, nothing additional happens.
404.1.b.
To Deal Damage to Units, mark the speciï¬ed amount of Damage on the Unit.
404.1.d.
Damage can be Dealt to more than one Unit at the same time.
404.6.c.
Damage Dealt as a result of being assigned during Combat has the Units as its source.
405.1.
Damage being cleared from Units is Healing.
405.2.
More than one Unit can be Healed at the same time.
407.2.b.
The Standard Move inherent to Units may also cause Movement. See rule 142for more information on the Standard Move.
407.3.
The Standard Move inherent to Units is a Discretionary Action.
407.3.a.
The Cost is Exhausting one or more Units.
407.3.b.
The Effect is Moving those Unit.
410.1.
Stunning is the act of selecting one or more Units on the Board and rendering them Stunned.
410.1.a.
Stunned is a binary state. A Unit is Stunned or it isn't.
413.1.
Bufï¬ng is the action of placing a Buff counter on a Unit. See rule 701. Buffs for more information.
415.5.a.
The Killed Unit or Gear is said to be Killed by that Game Object.
415.5.b.
A spell or ability that contains a Kill instruction is responsible for Killing the Unit or Gear.
415.5.c.
When one or more Units is killed due to a Cleanup, the spell or ability that resolved immediately prior to that Cleanup that applied damage to the Unit or Units is responsible for that Kill action.
425.2.a.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have permanents at that Battleï¬eld.
425.2.b.
If an action would require a Move that would cause a Unit to become present in a Location where it cannot move for any reason, such as a Battleï¬eld with two players that are not the controller of the Unit performing this Move action are in a Combat or such a Combat is Staged, it instead Recalls. See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
425.3.
Units are the only Permanents that can Move.
426.
Players may choose to move their Units with the Standard Move. See rule 142.for more information on the Standard Move.
428.
The Destination becomes Contested if it is a Battleï¬eld not controlled by the controller of the Unit or Units that moved.
429.
Units may cause a Showdown without a Combat when they Move.
429.1.
A Showdown is opened when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested while it has no Units present from any player other than those that just moved.
430.
Units may cause Combat when they Move.
430.1.
A Combat is triggered when a Move causes a Battleï¬eld to become Contested and Units controlled by opposing players. See rule 437. Combat for more information.
438.
A Combat occurs when a Cleanup occurs, there are no items on the Chain, and a Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by two opposing players.
439.1.
If more than one Battleï¬eld has Units controlled by opposing players at it at the same time, the Turn Player decides which Combat to resolve ï¬rst.
440.
Combat can only occur between Units controlled by exactly two players.
440.1.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid Destinations for Moves of all kinds (Standard Moves or otherwise) by Units controlled by Players who don't already have Units at that Battleï¬eld. See rule 425.2.a.for more information on Invalid Destinations.
440.2.
In Modes of Play with more than two players, Battleï¬elds with Staged Combats or Combats in Progress are Invalid to be chosen as a location to play one or more Units by a player not involved in that Combat by any means,
440.2.a.
If an effect would require a Unit be played to a Battleï¬eld with a Staged Combat or a Combat in Progress, where the controller of the played unit is not a participant, instead the Unit is played to its controller's Base.
440.2.b.
Any subsequent reference to "here" in the corresponding effect is reassigned to the Controller's Base, where the Unit was played. Any further effects that may be invalidated are invalidated as if the effect was mistargeted. See rule 352.5. Targeting for more information on Mistargeting.
442.1.a.3.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Attacker becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment, it will gain the Attacker designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
442.1.a.4.a.
If a Unit controlled by the Defender becomes present at this Battleï¬eld after this moment it will gain the Defender designation during the Cleanup phase following the action that caused it to become present
443.1.d.
Starting with the Attacker, each player assigns an amount of damage equal to their summed Might among the other's Units.
443.1.d.3.
Units must have lethal damage assigned to them in full before damage is assigned to a different Unit. Example: If a player has 5 damage to distribute among four 3 Might units, they may not choose to assign 2 damage to one of the units and 1 damage to each of the remaining 3. They must assign at least 3 damage to one, and the remaining 2 to another.
443.1.d.4.
Units cannot have more damage assigned to them than the minimum required to constitute lethal damage unless no further units remain to have damage assigned to them.
443.1.d.6.
If multiple Units have abilities or effects that require a player to assign them damage with the same priority, that player may assign damage to those units in any order. Example: A player is assigning damage to the following units: two units with Tank ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst.") and one unit with no abilities. That player chooses one of the units with Tank and assigns combat damage to it. Then they must assign any remaining damage ï¬rst to the other unit with Tank, then to the unit with no abilities.
443.1.d.7.
If a Unit has one or more Abilities or effects applying to it that demand it be assigned damage in a speciï¬c way that is exclusionary, then the assigning player chooses only one of those abilities to apply when assigning damage. Example: Caitlyn, Patrolling ("I must be assigned combat damage last.") has been given the Tank ability ("I must be assigned combat damage ï¬rst."). A player is assigning damage to this Caitlyn with Tank and two units with no abilities. That player canâ€™t fulï¬ll both of Caitlynâ€™s damage requirements, so they may choose to assign damage to Caitlyn ï¬rst, fulï¬lling the Tank requirement, or last, fulï¬lling Caitlynâ€™s printed requirement. They canâ€™t choose to apply damage to Caitlyn in between the other two units, because that wouldnâ€™t fulï¬ll either requirement.
444.1.a.1.
Insert â€œ2c. Heal all Units.â€
444.1.a.3.
Insert â€œ2e. Remove Attacker and Defender Designation from all Units and Players.â€
444.2.
2. If no Showdown or Combat is staged at this location, the player with Units remaining here Establishes Control.
444.2.d.
If there are no Units remaining here controlled by any player, the Battleï¬eld becomes Uncontrolled.
466.8.c.2.
Players may not issue Standard Movement to their Teammate's Units.
466.8.d.
Friendly describes controlled Game Objects by a player or their Teammate. Example: "When I am played, ready a friendly unit" could target a player's own Units or their teammate's Units.
702.
Buffs are objects placed on Units.
702.2.a.
To Buff a Unit, a player chooses a Unit and then places a buff on it. That Unit is Buffed for as long as the buff remains on it.
702.2.b.
Spending a Buff removes a single Buff counter from a Unit.
702.2.b.1.
A buff cannot be spent from a Unit that does not have a buff.
702.3.
There can only be one Buff on a Unit at a time.
702.3.a.
If a Buff is added, or instructed to be added, on a Unit that already has a Buff, it is not placed instead.
703.
Each Buff individually contributes +1 Might to a Unit.
705.
If a Unit leaves play, remove all Buffs from it.
708.
A Unit "is Mighty" as long as its Might is 5 or greater.
709.
A Unit "becomes Mighty" at the moment its Might changes from being less than 5 to being 5 or greater. Example: A Unit with Might 4 that gets +1 [M] becomes Mighty. Example: A Unit with Might 5 that gets +1 [M] does not become Mighty, because it was already Mighty.
731.1.
Accelerate is a Unit ability.
732.1.a.
It can be present on Spells, Units, Rune Abilities, Legend Abilities or Permanent Abilities.
732.3.
Action does not alter the function of any instruction of the corresponding card or effect it is on. It is only permission. Example: Playing a Unit with Action still has the inherent restrictions of playing Units without Action. It can only be played to the controlling player's base or a battleï¬eld they control.
739.3.a.
Playing Units with Reaction still has the inherent restrictions of playing Units without Reaction. It can only be played to the controlling player's base or a battleï¬eld they control.
744.1.b.
Equip has a cost to activate and Attaches the card with Equip to a chosen Unit when the cost is paid.
744.1.b.2.
The chosen Unit will become the Top-Most Card for the Attach action.
744.2.
When the Attach action completes from this keyword, the Unit that was chosen is considered to have been Equipped by the Gear with this ability.
745.1.d.
Quick-Draw is functionally short for â€œ[Reaction]â€ and â€œWhen you play this, attach it to a Unit you control.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.a.
Weaponmaster is present on Units.
747.4.
Weaponmaster, and whether or not a unit has Weaponmaster, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
Units Cannot Move
143.4.a.1.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present.
427.2.
Units cannot Move to a Battleï¬eld that already has units from 2 other players present by any means.
Unordered
107.1.e.
The cards in the Trash are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized.
107.5.e.
The cards in the banishment are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized.
V
Valid
352.2.a
By default, Valid locations include the controllerâ€™s Base or a Battleï¬eld the controller controls.
352.2.b
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit..
Victory Points
376.4.c.
Hold Effects are Triggered Abilities with a Condition of a Unit being present at a Battleï¬eld during the Beginning phase when a player scores Victory Points from Holding.
Victory Score
322.1.
1. If a player has as many points as the Victory Score, that player wins.
448.1.b.
When a player tries to earn a Point through a Score, and their current Point Total is 1 point from the Victory Score of the Mode of Play, the following occurs:
449.
When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play, they Win the Game immediately.
460.3.
Victory Score: The point total a player or team must reach to win.
460.3.a.
Victory Scores can be any positive number.
462.3.
Victory Score: 8
462.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
463.3.
Victory Score: 8
463.6.
Format: Best of 3. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the game. The winner of that game earns One Set Point. Players then reset the game state, remove the Battleï¬elds in play from the game, choose new Battleï¬elds from those set aside, and play again. The ï¬rst player to earn Two Set Points wins.
464.3.
Victory Score: 8
464.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
465.3.
Victory Score: 8
465.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst player to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
466.3.
Victory Score: 11
466.6.
Format: Best of 1. The ï¬rst team to reach the Victory Score in Points wins the Match.
Vision
454.2.b.
Effects for this layer can be identiï¬ed by the phrase "become(s)," "give," "lose(s)," "have," "has," "is," or "are" in the text. Example: A permanent has the ability "Other friendly units have [Vision]." Other friendly units gain the Vision keyword in this layer.
743.
Vision
W
Weaponmaster
725.3.
If an Attached card has an Equip ability, the Weaponmaster keyword can reference that Equip ability and any abilities that passively modify that Equip ability.
747.
Weaponmaster
747.1.
Weaponmaster is a Triggered Ability keyword.
747.1.a.
Weaponmaster is present on Units.
747.1.b.
Weaponmaster is a Play Effect that chooses an Equipment you control and allows you to pay its Equip cost at a discount, regardless of the usual timing of the Equip ability, to Attach that Equipment to the unit with Weaponmaster.
747.1.c.
Weaponmaster is functionally short for: â€œWhen you play me, choose a Card you control with the Equipment tag. Necessary portions of its Rules Text are no longer Inactive if they are currently Inactive. Pay the cost of its Equip ability, reduced by [A], to attach it to this unit.â€ See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
747.1.c.1.
Weaponmaster can choose an Equipment whether it has an Equip ability or not.
747.1.c.2.
The cost of the Equip ability is determined as though that Equip ability was being activated choosing the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, as modulated by any abilities that alter Equip costs.
747.1.c.5.
If the chosen cardâ€™s Equip cost canâ€™t be paid, if it canâ€™t be detached from its current Top-Most card, or if it canâ€™t be attached to the unit with the Weaponmaster ability, it stays in its current location, Attached to anything it was already Attached to.
747.1.c.6.
The Equip ability is not activated this way, and the unit with the Weaponmaster ability is not chosen.
747.2.
Multiple instances of Weaponmaster trigger separately, and can choose different targets.
747.2.a.
If you choose the same target with multiple instances of Weaponmaster, each will resolve separately.
747.3.
Weaponmaster has no function while on the board.
747.4.
Weaponmaster, and whether or not a unit has Weaponmaster, is a characteristic of the Unit and may be checked or referenced by other Game Effects.
While
361.3.a.
Conditional Passive Abilities can be recognized by the occurrence of "if" or "while" as part of the statement of the ability. Example: "While I'm attacking or defending alone, I have +2 [M]." Example: "If an opponent controls a battleï¬eld, I enter ready."
376.1.
Triggered Abilities can usually be recognized by the word "when" followed by a game action or event; the word "at" followed by a point in time during the turn sequence; or the phrase â€œthe [Nth] timeâ€ followed by a game action or event. Examples: "When you conquer here, you may spend a buff to draw 1." "At the end of your turn, ready 2 runes." â€œThe ï¬rst time I move each turn, you may ready something else that's exhausted.â€
376.2.a.
The Condition follows the When.
Win The Game
449.
When a player accrues Points equal to the Victory Score for their Mode of Play, they Win the Game immediately.
Window Of Opportunity
316.5.c.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction. See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
338.
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
Windows Of Opportunity
325.
Players can act during the following Windows of Opportunity that occur during the course of regular play:
Wins
466.6.a.3.
If one player Wins, then the entire team wins.
651.1.
If only one other player is remaining after a player has conceded, the player remaining Wins.
Z
Zones
106.1.
The Board is divided into several Zones.
127.1.
A card will always exist in one of the many Zones described during Setup.
356.3.e.2.
A target is illegal as the spell resolves if it no longer meets the targeting requirements of the spell, or if it has changed Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone.
356.3.e.4.
If a target changes Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone and then returns to its original zone, it is no longer a legal target, because it's not treated as the same object. Examples: An enemy unit at a battleï¬eld is no longer a legal target if it is no longer an enemy, no longer a unit, or no longer at a battleï¬eld. A unit with 3 or less Might is no longer a legal target if it is no longer a unit or if its Might is greater than 3. Something that's exhausted is no longer a legal target if it is no longer exhausted. (It can't stop being "something.") A spell that's played from hidden can normally only target its own battleï¬eld or something at that battleï¬eld. A target for such a spell may cease to be a legal target if it moves from the battleï¬eld where that spell was played, even if the spell has no location targeting requirement otherwise.
